IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We anticipate that the research proposed will provide novel and critically important tools in artificial intelligence for the detection of substance misuse from the electronic health record (EHR). Development and validation of the substance misuse classifier would enable a standardized approach to perform screening on all patient encounters on a daily basis in health systems. We will rigorously develop and test substance misuse classifier retrospectively and then examine its performance prospectively in both a naïve and mature screening program. This will serve as the first step towards a comprehensive universal screener that leverages available data in the EHR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human gut microbiome is a complex microbial ecosystem which impacts health in a myriad of ways. The proposed studies seek to determine the adaptations that allow different microbes to coexist within the gut. Results from these studies will advance a basic understanding of the gut microbiome and could clarify the significance of changes in the microbiome that occur in various diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Gene editing allows the potential of HIV patients to be cured by transplantation of a patient’s own blood stem cells after editing by deletion of required factors and addition of factors that inhibit virus replication. While stacking of these inhibitory factors in the primary infected cell, the CD4+ T cell, shows great promise there is a large variability in how efficiently the virus is inhibited. This proposal aims to understand the biology behind the virus and the knock-in factors in relation to human-specific differences in these and other cells relevant for infection in order to improve gene editing therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Neural circuits that transmit sound from the ear to the brain rely on precise connections with their appropriate partners. Disruption of this can lead to sensorineural hearing loss, or “nerve deafness”. The work described here, aims to understand how neural circuits in the auditory system are established in normal hearing to better understand disease, and improve prevention and treatment strategies.

PHR: Project narrative Lysosomes are major digestive organelles that sustain cellular homeostasis by degrading damaged proteins and organelles and recycling the constituents back into the cytoplasm. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Physician-scientists have an important role in developing new therapies for disease. However, the numbers of physician-scientists have been declining. This grant develops a research program to train physician-scientists in neurology using an innovative program of laboratory or clinical research training, close mentoring and didactics in grant writing and research ethics. Relevance to Public Health: This grant will develop physician scientists in neurology that will develop new therapies for human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is a massive public health problem, and new drug regimens are sorely needed. To address this need, we are assembling a multifactorial pipeline of experiments and computation to understand how drugs interact and to drive regimen development for TB. Our work will establish a tool for rapid assessment of TB drug combinations and a framework for applying this approach to other conditions where new multidrug therapies are needed.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pakistan, a low-middle income, and 5th most populous country has limited capacity to address its existing non-communicable disease (NCD) crisis. Leveraging existing infrastructure at the Aga Khan University’s flagship program in Karachi, Pakistan, the extensive Aga Khan Development Network and long-standing collaborations with Duke University, we have designed a robust, integrated, multi-disciplinary research- training program targeting cardio-cerebrovascular diseases and their risk factors with a prioritization of surveillance and implementation research methods that leverage big data and m-health. We expect that this program will directly increase Pakistan’s research capacity, a critical element in a comprehensive NCD response. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will increase our understanding of how the immune system causes disease when it incorrectly recognizes and responds to self-molecules as a threat. By providing understanding of autoimmunity to lipids or “fats” the outcome of this proposal has the potential to redefine Type 2 Diabetes as an autoimmune disease. This will provide new strategies for management of Type 2 Diabetes and new targets for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to opioids in the womb can lead to severe neurological and psychiatric disorders that last till adolescence or even adulthood. To understand how these conditions occur, and how to treat them, we will study, in mice, how exposure to opioids in the womb affect the adolescent brain. We will provide critical new information on the circuit, cellular, and molecular processes disrupted by this exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 155 million people living in the world today have survived tuberculosis (TB) and many will continue to suffer from post-TB lung disease (PTLD). If successful, the proposed studies will help target interventions that can mitigate ongoing morbidity by better characterizing changes in lung function following TB treatment and facilitating earlier identification of patients at risk for developing PTLD in resource-limited settings where spirometry is not currently feasible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In sub-Saharan Africa, men consistently lag behind women along each step of the HIV care cascade and contribute to HIV transmission among women. HIV disclosure is a key step in HIV prevention, however, few evidence-based resources exist to support HIV disclosure among men with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. I propose to develop and pilot test an HIV disclosure intervention to support men with HIV with STI symptoms who are either not accessing antiretroviral therapy or are accessing antiretroviral therapy but without viral suppression, with the goal of engaging men in care and decreasing partner HIV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Section We will harness a recent breakthrough in plasmon-enhanced fluorescence technology to create a new antigen test for Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Ng) that is as accurate and reproducible as gold standard nucleic acid amplification tests, but one that is cheaper, faster, and simpler. We will verify the efficacy of Ng antigen test by utilizing remnant urine samples from patients with suspected Ng infection. If successful, this test will have a tremendous positive impact immediately as it will transform the diagnostic landscape for Ng testing by its scalability with an inexpensive test strip and minimal battery-powered portable equipment, without relying on skilled personnel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Studies in this proposal will explore how the noncanonical Wnt ligands, Wnt11 and Wnt5a, that are expressed by primitive mesenchymal stem/progenitor cells (MSC) in the bone marrow (BM), preserve self-renewal and multilineage developmental potential of both bone-forming MSC and blood-forming long-term self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells (LT-HSC). These Wnt ligands significantly enhance expansion of LT-HSC in vitro when LT-HSC are co-cultured for extensive time periods with primary MSC. Insights gained from studies in this proposal may therefore have significant application in efforts aimed to preserve LT-HSC and MSC function in vitro during manipulations used in various gene targeting approaches, for improving the efficacy of bone marrow transplantation, and for development of protocols to enhance bone regeneration following injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is aimed at exploring the cross talk between the exocrine and endocrine cells of the pancreas. The focus is centered on understanding the intercellular communication between key players in the pancreatic niche that can directly impact the function of islet cells. The long-term objective is to use the information obtained from the experiments in these studies to gain a higher resolution understanding of the mechanisms that underlie the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The unprecedented availability of increasingly complex, voluminous, and multi-dimensional data and the emergence of data science as a field to harness it provide ideal opportunities to address the multi-faceted public health challenges faced by countries in sub-Saharan Africa. However, there is a severe lack of well-trained data scientists and home-grown educational programs to enable context-specific training. This proposal describes a plan to establish sustainable research training programs and to train a new generation of data scientists with skills, knowledge, mentoring, professional skills, and research immersion to position them for rigorous, biomedically grounded, and ethically conscious public health data science practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although the cellular metabolism seems to play a critical role in dictating the severity of pathogenic infection (i.e., asymptomatic, mild, and severe) or in controlling both genetic and epigenetic phenomena in a cancer cell, whether or to what extent dynamic metabolic shifts occur in the host’s immune system and if the changes in temporal ‘reactomics’ (defined as a combination of reaction mechanisms, regulations, and kinetic parameters) are the dominant drivers of metabolic reprogramming in a cancer cell, still remain to be explored. To this end, computational systems modeling framework provides the capability to represent these diseases as integrated/interacting systems and probe the changes in metabolic dynamics or temporal reactomics which can, ultimately, lead to identify alternate drug targets and help develop effective therapeutics. The proposed work aims to develop a comprehensive computational modeling and data integration platform to simulate the dynamic changes in metabolism and temporal reactomics that can be used to identify targets (i.e., genes/proteins/reactions) as either prognostic biomarkers or therapeutic targets or both to assess and/or intervene progression and worst outcomes during a disease period.

PROJECT_TITLE: A Predictive Modeling Framework to Dissect the Dynamic Immunometabolic Responses to Pathogenic infection and the Kinetic Reprogramming of Metabolism in Cancer Cell System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Low back pain (LBP), the leading cause of disability, is often attributed to pathological disc mechanics; unfortunately, in vivo measures of structural changes from magnetic resonance images, which are believed to relate to pathology, have had very little success discriminating pathology from natural aging. To study and treat LBP, a technique needs to be developed to quantify disc mechanical function in vivo; the goal of this proposal is to provide this technique, establish a new degeneration classification, and predict the mechanical state throughout the disc for in vivo movements. The overall impact of this research will establish techniques for basic and clinical research to address mechanisms of degenerative disc disorders, and in the longer term, a clinical tool for diagnosis and assessment of disc treatment for LBP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have previously identified the role of the Interleukin-15 (IL-15) in the development of of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) in humans and mice. In order to understand how IL-15 is produced and how it drives the colonization of neoplastic T-cells in the skin, we have proposed a series of studies that will examine the interactions between tunor cells, immune cells and skin cells. These studies will also examine the efficacy of IL- 15 blocking antibodies that can prevent the progression of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Human centromeres, defined by a repetitive DNA sequence called alpha satellite that is present in thousands of copies on each chromosome, are genetic loci that are required for genome stability. Alpha satellite size and sequence variation negatively affects centromere assembly and chromosome stability. This research will use artificial chromosome technology to test competency of specific alpha satellite DNA conformations in de novo centromere formation and use CRISPR-based methods to rehabilitate centromeres and/or rescue chromosome defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The genomes of cyanobacteria and sponge-associated microbes encode numerous compounds that could provide the basis for new drugs. Discovery and development of these chemicals as drug candidates, however, is challenging due to their low availability in Nature. The proposed multidisciplinary research will address this limitation and should provide the methodology to increase the number of new natural products as starting points for drug discovery and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preservation of mobility is one of the biggest health concerns of elderly population associated with aging. Identification of cost-effective therapies that can preserve independence and healthy mobile capacity in the elderly would have a cumulative effect, influencing many other aspects of mental and physical health in a wide population demographic. Here we propose to investigate whether the proteins named Sestrins, which are natural inhibitors of diverse age-associated diseases, can be used as a new molecular target to preserve mobile capacity and quality of life in later ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular nanomachines called ribosomes make proteins; they begin protein synthesis at start sites and end protein synthesis at stop sites located in mRNA, which is the blueprint they use to make protein. We and others have discovered additional start and stop sites in many RNA blueprints that direct protein synthesis but which are upstream of the main start and stop sites that direct the construction of the major protein specified in the RNA blueprint. This proposed work aims to gain a precise and complete understanding of how and why an RNA blueprint tells ribosomes to use these upstream protein synthesis sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The COVID-19 pandemic has taken the lives of millions, but millions more have survived infection, revealing a large number of effects on the human body, but whether these effects go away with time remains unknown. One understudied area is how contracting COVID-19 impacts the skeleton which is particularly concerning for older people that are more susceptible to both COVID-19 and bone loss associated with osteoporosis. The studies in this application will examine how bone loss changes based on age at the time of infection and the severity of COVID-19 disease, and will demonstrate how cells that breakdown bone, function to decrease bone mass.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood adversity is associated with higher risk of youth-onset depression, disruptions in cognitive and learning processes, and poor response to front-line depression treatments. Poor treatment response in adversity-exposed youths is largely unexplained, and the proposed research will be the first to examine how adversity and related impairments in learning processes (i.e., sub-processes of cognitive control) influence the acquisition of therapy skills, a primary treatment process in evidence-based psychotherapies. The research strategy presents a critical first step in identifying how childhood adversity impacts treatment effectiveness, and it has the potential to inform intervention research aimed at tailoring and optimizing depression interventions in this vulnerable youth population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it offers novel molecular analysis capabilities for detecting epigenetic alterations in various sources of DNA from limited tissue biopsies and liquid biopsies. The validation of this technique will provide opportunities to cancer research that have been limited by technology and the availability of limited clinical biospecimens, e.g., multi-omics studies and liquid biopsy-based early cancer detection. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission, in particular to the RFA- CA-21-004 that pertains to novel technologies and molecular analysis for clinical cancer research that will help reduce the morbidity and mortality of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: In our previous K24 cycle, Dr Gorno Tempini expanded and formalized her POR mentoring and undertook novel research into the susceptibility of the language system to neurodegeneration. This proposed renewal will train the next generation of clinician scientists in language disorders and neurodegenerative disease through didactics, group, and one on one mentoring sessions. The research project will develop novel automated and imaging measures of speech production impairments in PPA.

PHR: The project will systematize and disseminate data pipeline designs from leading neuroscience projects imple mented in the open-source DataJoint framework. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative How homeostatic setpoints are determined and represented in the brain remain unanswered questions for all motivated behaviors. In this proposed study, using mating induced resetting of protein intake target in Drosophila as a model system, we aim to elucidate the circuit and molecular substrates mediating the determination of homeostatic setpoint. This study should provide insights into the fundamental principles for the organization and modulation of homeostatic setpoint for motivated behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive neurologic disease of the brain leading to the irreversible loss of memory and cognitive performance which become severe enough to impede social or occupational functioning. This chronic, debilitating disorder results in a devastating burden on the families and caregivers of patients, with the rising costs of care in the United States exceeding $170 billion a year. The goal of this SBIR proposal is to develop a novel and orally effective small molecule for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. The drugs described in this proposal act via a novel and highly differentiated mechanism of action and are postulated to exhibit an improved efficacy / safety risk compared to the current standard of care.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenes are genes that encode proteins that can affect chromatin’s spatial organization and regulate cell-type specific transcription. The role of these genes in programming early developmental cell-fate transitions can be best modeled in complex systems such as mouse development. We developed mouse models of epigene mutations in the histone acetyltransferase genes in order to understand the multi-organ effects of KAT6A and KAT6B across early development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research aims to develop highly specific, reproducible, and transferable multiplex targeted mass spectrometry assays to enable accurate monitoring of isoform-specific markers of endocrine and exocrine functions in type 1 diabetes (T1D) clinical research. These assays if developed successfully will make a significant contribution to more precise monitoring of pancreatic endocrine and exocrine function, the disease progression, as well as the efficacy of clinical interventions in T1D patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Our program seeks to identify novel inhibitors of malaria dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) to combat the continuing threat of drug resistant malaria to clinical control of the disease. Our lead optimization program has identified potent compounds with reduced resistance risk compared to past DHODH inhibitors, and we are currently optimizing the series to identify compounds with the properties needed to support dosing in humans. We also plan to use computational and experimental approaches to identify features of enzyme/ligand interactions that can inform design of drugs with reduce resistance risk, allowing us to identify a candidate for development with the best chance to avoid clinical resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (Three Sentences) There remains an important need for the development of effective and safe methods for diagnosis of breast cancer. Photoacoustic computed tomography (PACT), as the fastest growing imaging technology, is able to image breasts with rich contrast information at high spatiotemporal resolution using neither ionizing radiation nor exogenous contrast agents. In our proposed study, PACT will diagnose disease conditions in breasts with abnormal mammograms — leading to a more streamlined and accurate workup that reduces unnecessary benign breast biopsies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue structure and function requires coordination between the dynamic physical organization of cells and the genetic programs controlling cell phenotype. Our understanding of this coordination is poor due to limitations of existing experimental systems, but critically needed to understand development and combat pathologies such as cancer and cardiovascular disease. This proposal is designed to contribute new molecular and platform technologies that will uncover fundamental molecular control systems at cell-cell interfaces that orchestrate these physical and genetic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Prion diseases are fatal neurodegenerative disorders caused by the misfolding of the cellular prion protein into aggregates that target specific cell types and brain regions. Heparan sulfate (HS) proteoglycans promote the selective internalization and replication of conformationally variable prions (prion strains) in different neural cell types. These studies will help to define the molecular mechanisms of selective cell vulnerability in neurodegenerative diseases and may provide new therapeutic targets based on blocking HS:prion binding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE and Relevance to Public Health Our proposed study is an 18-month randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled clinical trial in 220 postmenopausal women aged 60 years and above. Our objective is to test the efficacy of a probiotic/prebiotic combination (“synbiotic”) on the skeleton in a clinical trial that is designed to provide mechanistic insights into the action of the symbiotic supplement. Understanding these mechanisms might lead to the development of medical food supplements to aid in the dietary management of aging associated bone loss. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROPOSAL NARRATIVE Cardiometabolic disease risk is emerging earlier in life than ever before and disproportionately affects racial and ethnic minority populations. This proposal will apply advanced methods in epidemiology and implementation science to identify, adapt, and test a multi-component intervention to address cardiometabolic disease risk in Samoan children. Results will inform action that can be taken at the earliest possible opportunity to mitigate cardiometabolic disease risk and reduce health disparities among Samoans and other Pacific Islander populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals living with the stress of HIV are at increased risk of substance abuse, including abuse of natural substances, such as the botanical, Mitragyna speciosa (kratom). This investigation will address the critical safety issue of botanical-HIV drug interactions as natural substances can alter therapeutic drug levels in the blood and thereby affect the safety and efficacy of HIV drugs. By enabling the fundamental understanding of interactions between HIV drugs and kratom, this project will provide a rationale for confirmatory clinical trials and ultimately, an improved efficacy of HIV treatment protocols.

PHR: Project Narrative The STAT5 signaling pathway is critical for T cell expansion, persistence, and function. The proposed research will characterize the transcriptomic and epigenetic features of antitumor CD4 T cells expressing a constitutively active form of STAT5 and establish the therapeutic utility of these genetically modified CD4 T cells in the context of adoptive T-cell therapy including the use of T cells expressing chimeric antigen receptors (CAR).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Mast cells (MCs) are innate immune cells that play a central role in sickness, allergies, and psychiatric diseases, yet the genetic and transcriptional mechanisms by which MCs are regulated remain poorly understood, and the means to target MCs to treat infection and stress-related diseases remain largely unavailable. We have uncovered a novel transcription factor in MC activation and modulation, ΔFosB, and our preliminary evidence suggests that its expression in MCs is essential for normal physiology and behavioral responses to immune challenge or chronic stress in mice. The proposed work will uncover the specific mechanisms by which ΔFosB regulates MC function in vivo as well as the key transcriptional targets of ΔFosB in MCs that may act as molecular handles for therapeutic intervention in MC-related diseases or infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type VI Secretion Systems (T6SS) are macromolecular nanomachines and important virulence determinants present in one-quarter of Gram-negative bacteria, including many that cause serious human diseases, and thus, they are an important new target for strategies to combat infections caused by the bacterial pathogens that use them. However, to develop these strategies, we must better understand the composition, structure, and function of the T6SS. This proposal seeks to fill the gaps in our understanding of the T6SS in Francisella, which is classified as a Tier 1 Select Agent and requires the T6SS for its extremely high infectivity and pathogenicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotics represent a landmark achievement of medical science and have saved countless lives. Unfortunately, their efficacy is rapidly declining due to the emergence of drug-resistant pathogens. This study combines mathematical tools from physics with quantitative experiments on pathogenic bacteria to investigate how the spatial arrangement of bacteria in microbial communities contributes to—and is shaped by—the spread of resistance to widely-used antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 1: Optimizing Treatment of GBM by FLASH The suboptimal therapeutic index of brain tumor therapies, including radiotherapy, is in great need of improvement. The proposed program seeks to evaluate ultra-rapid FLASH radiotherapy, a new radiation treatment approach that has shown strong promise for killing cancer cells with significantly less harm to surrounding healthy brain tissue than is possible with current technologies. In this project, we will compare FLASH and conventional dose rate irradiation in clinically relevant regimens and evaluate mechanistic endpoints to accelerate clinical translation of this novel paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The picornavirus 3CD protein is central to every stage of the virus life cycle, including in genome replication and encapsidation, and in the formation of virus-induced replication organelles. Our proposal seeks to elucidate structural states sampled by 3CD that are responsible for its many functions and which differentiate its functions from those of the related 3C and 3D proteins. Characterization of these various structural states will provide a framework for devising more effective anti-viral strategies against a range of current and emerging human virus pathogens, including rhinovirus, enterovirus, coronavirus and poliovirus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Radiotherapy remains a frontline treatment for primary and metastatic brain cancers, like Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), but can result in debilitating cognitive side effects. The proposed program seeks to evaluate FLASH, a new radiation delivery platform that has shown strong promise for eradicating cancer cells with significantly less harm to surrounding healthy tissue than is possible with current radiotherapies. This project involves a series of long-term neurocognitive studies that will provide insight into the mechanisms of how normal tissue damage is spared by FLASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative In the proposed project, we focus on neuroanatomy and neurofunctional connectivity in MDD. We aim to identify imaging signatures and subtypes in MDD by applying state-of-the-art harmonization, pattern analysis and machine learning methods to structural MRI and resting state functional MRI. The analytic methods allow us to quantify the neuroanatomical and neurofunctional connectivity patterns that comprise MDD to provide powerful predictive markers at the individual level. Our goal is to arrive at a new neuroanatomical-neurofunctional (NA-NF) dimensional coordinate system in MDD (COORDINATES MDD), whereby each dimension reflects a different pattern of brain alterations, hence capturing the underlying NA-NF heterogeneity in quantifiable, replicable and neurobiologically-based metrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative - Project 4: Mechanistic Basics of FLASH Effect: Role of O2 Recently, exciting and unexpected new data in several animal models strongly supports the premise that ultra- high dose rate irradiation termed FLASH radiotherapy (FLASH-RT) can result in significant sparing of normal tissue while preserving tumor responses, effectively leading to significant increases in the therapeutic window for improving radiotherapy outcomes in brain cancer. However, the mechanisms for this effect are currently unknown. Project 4 will build on the exciting preliminary data to determine how reactions of O2 with free radicals formed at the time of FLASH-RT may be the drivers of the remarkable differential responses of normal and cancer tissue to FLASH-RT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the glucocorticoid receptor has been shown to directly increase the expression of genes encoding gluconeogenic enzymes to promote hepatic gluconeogenesis, here we identify sphingosine-1-phosphate signaling as a unique pathway that is induced upon chronic glucocorticoid exposure, which can occur upon prolonged stress or glucocorticoid therapy. We will dissect the mechanisms governing sphingosine-1- phosphate signaling mediated enhancement of glucocorticoid induced hepatic gluconeogenesis. The knowledge gained from this proposed study will provide novel insights into therapeutic interventions against steroid induced hyperglycemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection fate is the product of interactions between host and pathogen coordinated through biological networks. I will systematically dissect host signaling and Mtb gene regulatory network activities that impact Mtb viability and host inflammation during Mtb infection in primary human monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs), a major infected host cell in vivo. This characterization will uniquely enable dissection of infection phenotypes in primary human host cells at an unprecedented scale and granularity, maximizing clinical relevance of biological insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with developmental language disorder (DLD) comprise ~7% of the U.S. population, and experience persistent difficulties with learning and memory into adulthood. This project seeks to advance our understanding of how to leverage the time of day of learning for the long-term retention of linguistic (speech) and non-linguistic category information in adults with and without DLD. This information will not only advance our understanding of learning and memory in adults with DLD, but will inform intervention practices for other disorders with compromised speech-sound representations (e.g. dyslexia, speech sound disorder).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Neurobehavioral Core (Core 3) Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most common and deadliest form of brain cancer. The proposed program seeks to evaluate FLASH, a new radiation delivery platform that has shown strong promise for eradicating cancer cells with significantly less harm to surrounding healthy tissue than is possible with current radiotherapies. This core will develop a unifying neurobehavioral testing platform that will determine the effects of FLASH and conventional radiation therapies on learning, memory and mood, multifaceted endpoints critical to therapeutic outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations affecting RNA splicing factors are common across many cancers, with particularly high frequencies in disease types with few effective, FDA-approved treatments. New therapies to treat these diseases are urgently needed. Here, we will create new precision therapeutics that selectively target and eliminate cells carrying cancer-causing mutations affecting RNA splicing factors.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Overall Research Plan Project Narrative Medical images offer great potential for supporting clinical diagnosis and care management; however, their utility for African researchers and clinicians are limited by the number of images available, insufficient linkage to relevant clinical data, limited data from African populations for proper image interpretation, and poor implementation in clinical practice. The Mbarara University Data Science Research Hub is designed to overcome these barriers through robust Data Management and Analysis and Administrative Cores, initially supporting projects in posterior segment eye disease and cervical cancer with plans for expansion to new projects and sites, as well as training in data science and implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cells constantly need to destroy membrane proteins, either because they are damaged or no longer needed. Failure to do this properly can lead to a variety of human health ailments such a neurodegenerative diseases and cancer. This proposal seeks to understand the different pathways that membrane proteins use to undergo degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CD8+ T lymphocytes are essential players in mounting protective cellular immune responses against pathogens and malignantly transformed cells. This proposal will mechanistically elucidate the dynamic interplay of genome organizers and chromatin architecture in programming CD8+ T cell homeostasis and differentiation to memory CD8+ T cells in response to viral infection and tumor microenvironment. Our proposed studies will lead to paradigm-shifting advances in scientific knowledge, and provide novel insights into devising more effective vaccines and therapeutics for infectious diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to determine how the oocyte modifies its calcium signaling machinery in preparation for fertilization. The findings could lead to treatments that improve oocyte quality during in vitro fertilization, thereby improving fertility in humans and domestic animals. This study will also explore how maternal aging impacts the oocyte calcium signaling machinery and how this correlates with inadequate egg activation which is common in oocytes from aged females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed work will investigate the molecular structure and mechanism of action of a group of kinesin proteins that modulate the ability of the microtubular cytoskeleton to elongate and shrink. Due to the role that these kinesins have in cell division and tumor growth they are also attractive targets for the development of anti-cancer drugs. Thus, the proposed studies may help the rational design of a new generation of drugs to treat cancer and human diseases associated with kinesin malfunction (kinesinopathies).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: This project utilizes an implantable microdevice to measure multiple drug responses directly within the native tumor of glioblastoma cancer patients. We will determine whether these local microdose drug responses are predictive of systemic drug sensitivity for these patients, and will identify biomarkers of drug response that may be used to guide more effective therapy for patients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application addresses a critical gap in the literature by providing critical foundational data to extend our knowledge of breast cancer (BC) risk among transgender (TG) individuals and begin to inform TG BC screening guidelines. This project will also extend the applicant’s knowledge, skills and experience supporting a successful career as a surgeon–scientist. Next steps include an R01 application to develop a multi-institutional longitudinal TG breast cancer screening program to definitively establish lifetime risk and incidence of BC development, provide evidence-based BC screening guidelines for TG persons, and address eliminating barriers to BC screening access and delivery for TG persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: THREE SENTENCE NARRATIVE We propose to analyze the timing and order of mutations in sarcomas, tumors that disproportionately affect children. Our premise, based on strong published and unpublished data, is that by understanding when and how a child’s sarcoma develops, we will ultimately be able to predict how it will change, how it will respond to therapy and whether it will recur. 1

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor remediation of abandoned commercial uranium (U) mines throughout the Southwestern United States has subjected surrounding communities to metal-based (U, V, As) environmental exposures. Recent data suggest that inhalation of fugitive metal-based dust may have systemic impacts, driven by extracellular vesicles. The proposed research intends to explore the relationship and mechanisms between PM-driven extracellular vesicles and vascular and neurovascular consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Narrative Although negatively biased attention has a central theoretical and empirical role in the maintenance of depression, few treatments successfully target and improve this deficit. The current proposal builds upon our prior work and aims to conduct a well-powered efficacy trial to determine the potential of gamified and traditional Attention Bias Modification for the treatment of depression in adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. This work develops new methods for the combinatorial synthesis of glycan microarrays. Because glycans are involved in numerous biological processes such as cellular trafficking, signaling, cancer metastasis, viral entry, and immune defense, etc., such a technological breakthrough will have immediate impact on human health by helping to understand the target epitopes of glycan binding partners, and accelerate efforts to uncover the structure and function of the glycome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will identify the neurobiobehavioral mechanisms underlying sensory and salience processing and stress reactivity in 7- to 10-year-old children with ASD. The findings will reveal how sensory aberrations in low-level (visual, auditory, tactile) processing disrupt both high-level multisensory integration and detection of salient sensory information, and how multisensory and salience dysfunction—moderated by stress reactivity—are associated with internalizing behaviors. The research findings may ultimately contribute to the development or refinement of therapies including current sensory-based interventions and practices to ameliorate sensory dysfunction and co-occurring internalizing symptomatology in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative / Public Health Relevance  Data and metrics for evaluating retention and engagement in clinical care among persons with HIV have yet to be optimized for distinct sub-populations in an era of changing data availability, new primary care models, and remote clinic visit modalities. Applying the proposed epidemiologic modeling methods to the largest HIV cohort in the US, the North American AIDS Cohort Collaboration on Research and Design, will elucidate appropriate retention and engagement metrics for different groups. This research will be novel and high-impact, generating evidence to inform programs and policies which will create benchmarks for, and ultimately improve, HIV care nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal targets secondary prevention of cervical cancer with the long-term goal of mitigating high-risk HPV persistence, risk of cervical cancer, and improving the health of women co-infected with HPV and HIV. The proposed comprehensive ASHA-Health HPV intervention builds on a highly successful and long-term US-Indo collaboration with a high potential for scale-up in India. Success of this intervention will lead to policy development and further cervical cancer prevention trials among co-infected Indian women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have found that infection with SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 diagnosis are associated with the development and progression of both Type 1 (T1D) and Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). The proposed study will engage 15 sites from the National Patient-Centered Clinical Research Network (PCORnet) and the T1D Exchange to recruit 1600 English- and Spanish-speaking pediatric and adult patients with recently diagnosed T1D or T2D who have had a known COVID-19 infection in the past 90 days or no recent diagnosis of COVID- 19 infection in the past year. The study will follow this population for 2 years and will utilize linked electronic health data from PCORnet sites to understand the impact of COVID-19 on diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Naïve T cell numbers are dramatically decreased with age, leading to impaired immune responses in the elderly. Naïve T cells rely on signals from the lymph node tissue environment to survive, yet it is unknown whether this support is reduced with age. This project will determine how age-related changes to the structural organization of the lymph nodes contributes to reduced naïve T cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune T cell responses specific to neoepitopes formed in peripheral tissues may explain how and why T cell responses break the usual tolerance mechanisms. This project investigates how disulfide modified antigens elicit autoimmune T cell responses and how redox regulation may impact disulfide modified antigen presentation. The study could provide novel therapeutic strategies to prevent or treat type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tendon ruptures and tendinopathies are painful and debilitating conditions affecting a large portion of the adult population. From a regenerative standpoint, there is a pressing clinical need to identify the cell and molecular mechanisms regulating tendon differentiation vs fibrotic scarring in order to improve repair outcomes. Since the local immune environment and T cells are implicated in both effective and poor tendon healing, the objective of the proposed studies is to fully define the T cell subpopulations underlying tendon healing and to test the role of IL33.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to improve early diagnosis of colorectal cancer polyps by development of a novel and soft tactile sensing device and complementary intelligent algorithms. The proposed transformative diagnosis framework (1) readily integrates with the existing colonoscopic systems and does not change the current clinical diagnosis workflow, (2) provides high-resolution 4D imaging (i.e., 3D texture mapping + stiffness classification), (3) dramatically decreases polyp diagnosis miss-rate, and (4) enhances in vivo polyps’ type and stage classification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes research focuses on predicting who will get the disease, preventing disease in those at risk, and reducing the chances of heart attacks, amputations, blindness, and kidney disease in people who survive with the disease. Unfortunately, many of the blood tests that are used to investigate or treat type 1 diabetes are not reproducible in other laboratories, or they give very different results compared with assays made by other companies. This project aims to make new blood tests that researchers and clinical laboratories can easily recreate at their own institutions, which will make research findings more reproducible and will help facilitate their translation into patient care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Identification of the mechanisms responsible for many structural birth defects is hindered by the complex genetics of these disorders, where genetic mutations interact with genetic and environmental factors. Proposed studies will elucidate how genes and environment interact to converge on progenitor cell development to cause structural birth defects. This understanding is vital for devising strategies to prevent birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is a major global health threat, especially for people living with HIV and BCG, the current TB vaccine, typically provides only poor protection. Here, we will use a macaque model of TB, both with and without an SIV infection, to explore vaccination with BCG, as well as the more attenuated BCG? 1419c, delivered to the respiratory mucosa rather than the standard intradermal route. Both TB vaccines will be assessed for safety, immunogenicity, and protective efficacy to guide the development of a safer, more efficacious, TB vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Infection with human rhinoviruses (HRVs) may render individuals less susceptible to infection or severe illness associated with heterologous respiratory viruses; however, most existing studies that evaluate these interactions utilize animal models or in vitro experiments. This proposal seeks to leverage our unique platform of intensive case-based SARS-CoV-2 household surveillance in order to test the central hypothesis that coinfection of HRV with SARS-CoV-2 may be associated with reduced transmission of SARS-CoV-2, reduced risk of symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection, and reduced clinical symptoms among symptomatic infected individuals. A detailed understanding of the impact of HRV coinfection with SARS-CoV-2 in real-world conditions may yield new insights into both the immunological consequences of HRV infections and also the individual and age-associated variability in SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility to infection and severe illness.

PHR: Project Narrative Port-wine birthmark (PWB) is a congenital progressive vascular malformation of the skin with an estimated prevalence of 3–5 children per 1,000 live births. This proposal aims to develop novel and clinically relevant cell and organoid models derived from patients’ induced pluripotent stem cells (IPSCs) and determine the causative pathways underlying the impaired cell-fate and lineage-specific differentiation in these models and PWB skin lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are membrane bound organelles which are critical for eukaryotic cellular function. This proposal describes how biochemistry and systematic functional genomics will be combined to look at how outer mitochondrial membrane a-helical proteins get made, an important class of proteins that mediate a range of processes such as mitochondrial-cytoplasmic communication, the innate immune response, and apoptosis. Knowledge about the biogenesis of these proteins will not only expand our understanding of basic cellular biology, but also aid in the development of treatments for diseases associated with outer mitochondrial membrane protein dysregulation such as Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project analyzes barrier to access to care for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias for individuals dually eligible for Medicare and Medicaid, whose higher burden and worse management of chronic disease and lower educational level put them at higher risk of dementia. Since many physicians are reluctant to accept Medicaid, because of the greater administrative complexity and lower payment rates, and since patients may lack the health literacy to navigate two distinct coverage systems, dually eligible individuals tend to face substantial obstacles to access. We will disentangle the effect of those different obstacles and investigate how they interact with state- (e.g., number of specialists per capita) and patient-level factors (e.g., distance to facilities, race/ethnicity) to provide guidance for policymakers in all 50 states and the District of Columbia on policy interventions to improve access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The HIV epidemic remains a global public health challenge despite the substantive progress made in disease con- trol measures, including the universal treat and test (UTT) strategy and behavioral interventions to reduce HIV risk behaviors. By designing, validating and disseminating new statistical methods to incorporate social context and heterogeneity investigation in the evaluation of HIV treatment and prevention interventions in order to inform the development of novel, more cost-effective community-based implementation strategies for delivering them, it is expected that this proposal will have a significant impact on public health by contributing to the attainment of global HIV control targets. In particular, the new methods will provide the scientific community with innovative analytical tools to identify more effective combinations of interventions at the individual-level and community-level for reducing HIV transmission and increasing diffusion of preventive behaviors, as well as to identify and inter- vene on more influential individuals who will amplify the dissemination of risk reduction information, preventive behaviors, retention in HIV care, and HIV treatment adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: A fundamentally new approach to the treatment and prevention of age-related diseases is to target the root cause of aging. Under this new paradigm, rejuvenation of aging human tissues and organs represents a promising and exciting direction. Previously we identified 4 transcription factors that can rejuvenate human fibroblast cells aged in vitro through continuous passaging. This project proposes to test the rejuvenating effect of these factors in human fibroblast cells aged inside human body, and in mouse liver. New technologies will be developed to systematically identify combinations of transcription factors for rejuvenation. The proposed research will set a unique stage for discovering combinations of small molecule drugs for rejuvenation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: People suffering from type 1 diabetes (T1D) could be cured with new stem cell-derived beta cells that restore the glucose homeostatic function lost when endogenous pancreatic beta cells are attacked by the immune system. Beta cells do not function in isolation, however, but rather in the context of a community of other cells and extracellular matrix arranged in a specific 3D structure called the islet. A detailed blueprint of islet structure is not available; therefore, the goal of this proposal is to identify the organizational principles of the islet, paving the way for future work to leverage these principles for engineering more functional islets that ultimately could be moved into clinical trials as a cellular replacement therapy for curing T1D.  1 1U01DK135019 PIs: Sneddon & Gartner 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regular exercise and lifestyle physical activity are critical for quality of life and longevity, and particularly important for a healthy heart. However, exercise anxiety is common and can result in avoidance of exercise, and reliance on false safety behaviors, which leave patients vulnerable to the misperception that it is only safe to exercise under a restrictive set of circumstances. We aim to fill a critical assessment gap by developing and evaluating a novel measure of exercise avoidance and false safety behaviors for use in both research and intervention efforts to help enhance exercise participation in cardiac rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Women who are first infected with HCMV early during pregnancy have ~12% chance that their child will be born with or later develop significant handicaps, primarily deafness but also varying degrees of cognitive and motor function deficits. This population comprises ~120,000 women annually in the US with comparable incidence in Europe and Japan. Reinfection or reactivation of latent infection also contributes to the risk of birth defects. Although harder to detect, and thus less suitable for a clinical trial, the potential benefit of TRL345 likely extends to the entire population of first trimester pregnancies. The economic impact of congenital HCMV, including the costs of medical care and educational expenses, is estimated to be >$3 billion annually (US). HCMV is also the leading viral cause of hospitalization for solid organ and bone marrow transplant patients, impacting close to 50,000 patients annually in the US at a cost of ~$5 billion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiretroviral therapy does not eliminate HIV reservoirs and HIV continues to persist in tissue compartments, including the brain. Immunotherapies to eliminate these persisting viral reservoirs are being evaluated but targeting HIV reservoirs in the central nervous system (CNS) presents unique challenges. Here, we will assess in two human clinical trials and in the nonhuman primate model of HIV whether an immunomodulatory molecule, the IL-15 super-agonist N-803, can be given safely without CNS toxicity and can boost the antiviral CD8 T cell response in the CNS, reducing HIV reservoir seeding and persistence in the brain. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Understanding how the brain processes sounds is of great importance for the well-being of individuals across society. As harmonics are fundamental elements of speech and music, we investigate how the brain processes these signals by combining advanced neurophysiological and computational methods. Our online stimulus optimization methods hold the potential to be eventually adapted into an automated adaptive diagnosis system for hearing deficits. Findings of the present study will not only advance our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying hearing and vocal communication with harmonic sounds but also contribute to the development of treatment of hearing loss and impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Cognitive resilience to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and brain aging is a phenomenon whereby an individual’s cognitive functioning is better than predicted based on chronological age, genetic risk, and/or advanced neuropathology. Understanding the protective factors that improve cognitive resilience requires comprehensive identification of the protein components of unique brain cell types – an analysis that cannot be performed longitudinally in human patients. In this project, we will combine human clinical and molecular data with proteomic data from neurons and immune cells from the hippocampus of mice that are resilient and susceptible to cognitive decline to identify novel proteins and complexes that could ultimately be therapeutically targeted to delay or prevent cognitive symptoms in AD patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia and obesity lie on seemingly opposite ends of the disordered eating spectrum, yet it is well established that these conditions share appetite circuitry that influence the behavioral decision to eat in excess or scarcity. Presently, the genetic mechanism that results in this stark phenotypic difference is not known. The goal of this F99/K00 proposal is to determine if alternative polyadenylation, a rapid activity-dependent RNA processing mechanism, functionally controls information flow from genome to phenome to meter the development of an obese phenotype, as this information has the potential to better inform treatments for disordered appetite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a progressive neuromuscular disorder caused by loss of dystrophin protein in skeletal muscle and heart. There is an unmet need for serum biomarkers that can be employed to de-risk drug development programs, and further provide objective biomarker outcomes on muscle disease and pathologies in DMD. The proposed research investigates whether drug-related reductions in two inflammatory serum biomarkers, MDC and CD23, predict later clinical motor outcomes in DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Perturbation of the Hedgehog (HH) pathway and activation of glioma-associated oncogene (GLI), a dedicated transcription factor in the HH pathway, is responsible for approximately 30% of medulloblastoma. The proposed project has the potential to improve public health by elucidating the novel role of O-GlcNAcylation in regulating GLI functions in the HH pathway, which will eventually lead to better diagnosis and treatment of medulloblastoma. The proposed work will utilize laboratory-based science to advance strategies for overcoming radiochemoresistance in medulloblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE: Cognitive aging across the lifespan has profound implications for the health, quality of life and productivity of society. The superimposed risk of Alzheimer's disease increases with more advanced age. The proposed research program constitutes a major reevaluation of the methods and goals of the study of cognitive aging that should provide major new, integrative, and perhaps simplifying, insights into the neural basis of the most important and central features of cognitive aging and into the preclinical brain changes leading up to AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease, a disorder characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive deficits and affecting tens of millions of people globally, is first pathologically evident among a subset of cells in specific brain regions including the hippocampal-entorhinal system critical for learning and memory. Aging is a major risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and age related changes occur throughout adulthood concurrent with disease progression, complicating our understanding of the molecular and cellular events underlying the etiology of Alzheimer’s disease as opposed to normal aging. We therefore propose to use cutting edge technologies to investigate the cell type specific molecular mechanisms and gene regulatory networks underlying Alzheimer’s disease and aging in the human and non-human primate brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project will identify blood-based epigenetic aging biomarkers predicting risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI), Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), and brain aging. These biomarkers can be used to identify older adults early in the ADRD disease course to potentially prevent irreversible cognitive and functional decline. The proposed research will support NIA’s public health mission by addressing the NIA 2020- 2025 Strategic Directions for Research goals of understanding how “molecular bases of changes associated with aging contribute to the development and course of age-related dementia” and identifying “biological and clinical markers for early detection of cognitive decline, MCI, and AD.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Sleep disruption affects millions of older Americans and is associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease (AD); moreover adults with AD have increased sleep disruption. Using an innovative cross-species, human and fly translational approach, we will identify novel gene targets underlying the bi-directional relationship between AD and sleep disruption. This will pave the way for new treatments to prevent the negative impact of sleep disruption on the risk of AD, and improve sleep disruption in patients with AD, resulting in a sustained impact on the health of millions of older Americans at risk of, or suffering from, Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia in the elderly, which accounts for 60-80% of cases. Currently, an estimated 5.7 million Americans of all ages have AD. Apolipoprotein E (APOE) plays a critical role in maintaining synaptic plasticity and neuronal function by controlling lipid homeostasis, with the APOE2 allele having a superior function. The APOE2 has been found to be more prevalent among centenarians and associated with decreased susceptibility to AD. Studies on the role of the APOE2 in relation to AD suggest that APOE2 is neuroprotective and is positively associated with cognitive functions in aging. Therefore, increasing APOE2 level in the brain is an effective therapeutic strategy for AD. Although gene therapy possesses immense potential of treating various neurodegenerative diseases including AD, its clinical application is limited mainly due to lack of safe and effective vectors that can efficiently deliver the therapeutic gene across the blood brain barrier. The long-term goal of the proposed research is to design a gene delivery carrier for efficient delivery of pDNA encoding APOE2 to brain for prevention and treatment of AD. The studies will be conducted in vitro and in vivo in Wild Type, APOE-knockout, amyloid AD APP/PS1 and tau model PS19 mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Risk for financial exploitation has both been associated with diminished cognitive abilities (e.g., reduced executive functioning), Alzheimer's Disease, depressive symptoms, and a range of demographic variables (e.g., socioeconomic status, sex, and ethnicity). Yet, it remains unclear whether age-related differences in neural processing of social and nonsocial rewards underlie these relationships. Understanding the role of altered reward-processing mechanisms will help establish a foundation for future work aimed at characterizing and mitigating risk for financial exploitation in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) causes progressive loss of memory, for which there is no cure. A growing understanding of memory impairment in AD suggests that alterations at the genetic and cellular levels contribute to circuit dysfunction. Knowledge gained from our proposed studies will advance the understanding of the key neural circuits that modulate vulnerable networks during early AD, and guide new therapeutic directions by selectively targeting these modulatory circuits for treating memory loss associated with AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease impacts a large number of individuals. One to the pathological features of this disease are neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) that occur in the cytoplasm of neurons and are made up of an unfolded protein called tau. NFT occur initially in a region of the brained termed the entorhinal cortex, then “spread” to other limbic and association areas over more than a decade; this spread corresponds to the clinical symptoms of the disease and correlates with the destruction of neurons. Evidence suggests that this misfolded protein is transferred from neuron to neuron, and how this occurs is an important and central question that remains unanswered. Our studies have identified receptor molecules on the surface of neurons that are capable to binding tau and mediating its internalization into neurons. This grant will investigate detailed mechanisms of how these receptors guide this misfolded protein to the cytoplasm of the cell to trigger formation of more neurofibrillary tangles and thereby propagate formation of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Disease-modifying therapy for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a massive and urgent unmet medical need. Cognitive failure stems most directly from neuronal synapse loss during mild cognitive impairment and mild AD. Innate immune mechanisms release complement proteins, which then tag specific neuronal synapses for removal. Here, we seek to define the molecular mechanisms at specific neuronal synapses which instruct the recruitment of complement proteins to trigger synapse loss. By understanding synaptic clearance mechanisms, we aim to develop the means to preserve synaptic number and function in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Abnormal circadian rhythms are associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but it is unclear whether and how the central circadian clock in the hypothalamus contributes to cognitive functions. We will address these questions using novel animal models and methods. The study will provide insights into the mechanism of AD-related dementia (ADRD) and lay groundwork for harnessing the circadian rhythm to treat ADRD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer's disease is highly heterogeneous presenting sex-differentiated characteristics. Understanding the impact of sex differences on the trajectories of brain aging and AD is critical for individualized prevention and treatment of AD. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Single-cell CRISPR screens are a new high-throughput experimental approach which can deepen our understanding of how genes and regulatory elements interact in biological networks. We propose to develop computational tools which can analyze the large and complex datasets generated by these screens to characterize the phenotypic effects of genetic perturbations at single cell resolution. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a devasting degenerative brain disease that is increasing in prevalence and there is no effective treatment. Although very rare forms of the disease are caused by inheriting abnormal genes, most cases have no definitive genetic cause, although many risk-associated genes have been identified. These studies will focus on the role of one risk-associated gene, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) and its function in processing abnormal proteins produced in the brain in patients with AD that lead to neuron death and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The human brain is supplied by a dense array of vessels where each neuron has its supplying capillary. Aging impairs functionally and structurally the cerebromicrovasculature and thus induces consequential neuronal dysfunction and cognitive impairment. Our recent studies using heterochronic blood exchange (HBE) in mice showed that young blood rescues the age-related decline in signaling via the NAD+/SIRT1 axis and reverses circulating IGF-1 deficiency, each of which can result in vascular mitochondrial rejuvenation, attenuation of endothelial oxidative stress, improved endothelial vasodilator function and restoration of endothelial angiogenic processes, improving brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Although most studies in Alzheimer disease (AD) so far have focused on amyloid β, interest in Tau is growing because of the discovery of the central role of Tau in neurodegeneration and the difficulties associated with the targeting of amyloid β to develop mechanism-based treatments for AD. The main goals of this project are to elucidate the structural basis and pathological mechanisms implicated in Gerstmann-Sträussler-Sheinker (GSS, F198S) disease and Prion protein cerebral amyloid angiopathy (PrP-CAA, Q160X), in which Tau deposits are composed by 3R+4R Tau, as in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This large, population-based study will reveal the relationship between HIV and the natural history of oral human papillomavirus (HPV) infection in an at-risk cohort of males living with HIV. This information will be critical for developing screening algorithms to identify males at high risk of developing HPV-related oropharyngeal cancer (HPV-OPC), who would benefit from preventive treatment or early-stage treatment when outcomes are most favorable. Ultimately, the knowledge gained from this study will translate into strategies to mitigate the risk of HPV-OPC among males living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias are among the leading contributors to morbidity, disability, and mortality worldwide. This project will apply novel machine learning techniques to large multi-cohort samples to determine whether multidimensional sleep health predicts cognitive outcomes (change in cognition, incident dementia; Aim 1) and change in depressive symptoms (Aim 2), and examine depressive symptoms as a pathway through which multidimensional sleep health predicts cognitive outcomes. Through our multi-cohort secondary data analysis approach, which offers enhanced generalizability and power and an efficient use of existing resources, our findings will directly inform the design of subsequent prospective studies aimed at developing integrated approaches to treating depression and cognitive decline in older adults, with implications for preventing Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The underlying causes and treatment of dementias observed with advanced age remain poorly understood and are a major unmet need for the aging population. This proposal explores a novel protein that prevents mild cognitive decline normally associated with natural aging, determining whether it prevents or delays severe neurodegenerative conditions observed with aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Paradigm-shifting research has revealed that urethral failure, long thought to be unimportant, plays a major role in incontinence. Studies of the role of advancing age and disease in causing urethral failure and incontinence are blocked by the use of obsolete, artifact-prone testing equipment and outdated conceptual models. By providing the next generation of urethral testing equipment and computer modeling that capitalizes on advances in sensor and imaging technology, we will provide the needed armamentarium to conduct studies of urethral failure mechanisms that can lead to novel therapeutic targets and treatable disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) underlies age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of irreversible vision loss in the developed world. Avenues to improve RPE function in the dry form of AMD are desperately needed, as the disease currently has no FDA-approved treatments. Here, we explore the role of a lipid storage organelle, termed a lipid droplet, in maintaining the RPE’s health and function, with implications for developing novel therapeutics for dry AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We previously demonstrated that pancreatic tumors depend on the amino acid cysteine in order to prevent cell death through a process called ferroptosis. Here we propose to improve the anti-cancer effects of cysteine depletion by targeting complementary aspects of tumor metabolism and immunity. These proposed studies will also further illuminate the mechanisms of cysteine depletion and ferroptosis in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic masticatory muscle pain disorders (MMPD) affect between 5-12% of the adult population and are the most common cause of chronic non-odontogenic orofacial pain. Combining standard dental care with brief telehealth psychological interventions offers hope for reducing negative pain outcomes and improving quality of life in this population, but few such interventions exist. The proposed submission will generate data to support a future full-scale Phase II efficacy trial of a brief telehealth psychological intervention for MMPD, potentially leading to an efficacious, widely implementable, and disseminatable treatment option for patients with chronic MMPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Dissecting and targeting a novel vulnerability in Rb1 and p53 doubly deficient prostate cancer Projective Narrative (Relevance) Rb1 and P53 Deficiency (RPD) significantly correlates with poor prognosis in prostate cancer patients, and it has been documented that RPD promotes prostate cancer progression using cells/xenografts/genetic mouse models. However, RPD mechanisms are far from well understood, which has hindered the development of effective treatments. Our proposed study will define GRK3 kinase as a novel vulnerability in RPD prostate cancer, dissect its mechanisms of action and examine the effectiveness of targeting it with first-in-class inhibitors to thwart RPD tumors, which will not only shed light on critical molecular events contributing to the aggressiveness of RPD tumors, but also facilitate the development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinicians who treat patients with OUD collect standardized clinical data such as urine toxicology and self- report of use of substances, as well as medication dosing and clinic treatment engagement. Nevertheless, it is currently not possible to predict, in real time, what the risk is for a patient to relapse in the next week or month. This project aims to apply well developed contemporary statistical and machine learning methodologies to build such a relapse risk score, which would be of benefit to both clinicians and researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 5 million patients are admitted to the intensive care unit every year in the United States; most of these patients experience profound sleep and circadian disruption. Promotion of circadian alignment (i.e., alignment of the body's clocks) would make it possible to strategically schedule behaviors such as sleep and eating at normal body clock times, which is predicted to improve sleep quality and metabolic function. This project will test the ability of a sleep chronobundle (i.e., sleep promotion and circadian treatment bundle) to normalize circadian alignment and subsequently test if this realignment also improves sleep and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This study of the impact of immigrant policy on the mental health and health care access of foreign- and US-born rural Latinos will produce new data and knowledge on the social determinants of Latino health across diverse rural communities. It will investigate variations in health care access and health status and the influence of county policy contexts, social climates, and Latinos’ own policy encounters on these outcomes. The study will inform policies and interventions aimed at promoting mental health and increasing access to health care and safety net services for Latinos in rural regions.
