IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cell entry of SARS-CoV-2 depends on binding of the viral spike (S) protein to the host cell receptor ACE2 and its priming by host protease TMPRSS2. The findings that skin biopsies were SARS-CoV-2 RNA positive; skin cells express both ACE2 and TMPRSS2 whose expression is increased in inflamed/wounded skin; and that there are skin manifestations of COVID-19, suggest that skin could be potentially an additional port of entry for SARS-CoV-2. We will test this hypothesis using pseudotyped Spike (S) protein-containing lentiviruses, 2D- and 3D-cultures made from African American, Hispanic and White non-Hispanic human epidermal keratinocytes pretreated with cytokine cocktails to induce ACE2 and TMPRSS2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Socioceconomically disadvantaged individuals typically have poor outcomes in behavioral weight loss interventions, but the reasons for this are unknown. This project will characterize the mechanisms through which adverse daily experiences and present bias -- a cognitive adaptation to harsh and unpredictable environments -- account for disparities in weight loss outcomes.

PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to combine mathematical modeling with quantitative experimental approaches to understand the feedback and feed forward loops that regulate intracellular signaling networks. The ultimate goal of this project is the development of predictive models of in vivo cellular processes that can be used in the rational design of therapeutic strategies for treating disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Our postdoctoral T32 program aims to provide the next generation of investigators with state-of-the art training in intellectual disability research. It is designed across traditional scientific disciplines to provide trainees with broad-based technical and conceptual approaches to apply to the study of pediatric brain disorders and related conditions. We also aim to engender sensitivity in our trainees for individuals with IDD and for their families. Our ultimate objective is to train individuals so they have the concepts, experiences, and skills required to initiate and sustain successful long-term independent careers dedicated to decreasing the burden of intellectual disability in our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth in the US. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will integrate real-time data on suicide risk among youth with national data on social determinants of health and COVID-19 burden to determine how suicide risk among youth have changed throughout the pandemic, how these changes vary by different sociodemographic groups, and how social determinants of health and COVID-19 impact suicide risk. This research is particularly needed in light of the pandemic’s impact on youth mental health and recent advisories from the US Surgeon General that highlight the need for a better understanding of the impact of the pandemic on youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is focused on how the metabolic state of different retinal ganglion cell subtypes, arising due to their energy needs, modulates their electrical excitability. By understanding the links between the cells' bioenergetic requirements, how they generate potentially harmful reactive oxygen species when making energy, and how they respond to these intrinsic metabolic signals by reducing excitability, we will identify key mechanisms that suppress metabolic crisis in the retina. This knowledge is a prerequisite for improving diagnostic assessment that may allow detection and intervention to prevent or restore vision loss due to retinal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of the small GTPase Ras and its negative regulator p120RasGAP have been linked to numerous vascular diseases including capillary malformation-arteriovenous malformation syndrome (CM-AVM) and vein of Galen malformations (VOGM). Despite the importance of strict regulation of cell signaling for normal control of cell growth and proliferation, these signaling proteins are still not well understood at the molecular level. This project will investigate inter-domain regulation of p120RasGAP and its effect on Ras activity, providing new insights into the mechanisms of these diseases.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this collaborative project, we will use rigorous development methods to expand the Observer-Reported Communication Ability (ORCA) measure to 13 neurodevelopmental disorder populations. Additionally, we will provide age-based normative data from a US sample of typically developing children, evaluate other commonly used communication measures, and explore endpoint models to provide a comprehensive set of outcomes for capturing communication ability. Our ultimate goal is to provide investigators with a comprehensive set of tools to evaluate changes in communication ability in these vulnerable populations, which in turn, will help to facilitate crucial pediatric clinical trials.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Expanding the Observer-Reported Communication Ability (ORCA) Measure: Measuring the communication ability of individuals with rare, neurodevelopmental disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Insulin resistance is when cells in your muscles, fat, and liver don’t respond well to insulin and can’t easily take up glucose from your blood, a condition known as prediabetes, affecting more than 84 million people ages 18 and older in the United States, about 1 out of every 3 adults. Researchers don’t fully understand what causes insulin resistance and prediabetes, but they think that excess weight and lack of physical activity are major factors. Here, we study three models of insulin resistance in an animal model to better understand the mechanisms involved in insulin resistance related to excess fat intake, excess sugar intake, and excess androgens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Catholic Health Initiatives’ Institute for Research and Innovation (CIRI) Oncology Research Alliance (CORA) is a community-based research network made up of community hospitals and cancer centers from ten states that works together to recruit and enroll patients, including those underrepresented in research, in cancer control, prevention, screening, and care delivery trails as well as quality-of-life studies. CORA also identifies, designs and implements cancer care delivery research that leads to improved models of care and translates to high quality, value- based services throughout the oncology continuum. Overall, CORA seeks to contribute to and improve cancer research and the delivery of cancer care in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about factors impacting suicidal ideation and behavior in people with serious mental illness, nor which treatments are most effective, despite markedly increased risk of suicide in this population. This NRSA proposal uses advanced data science methods to evaluate the dynamics among potentially modifiable treatment targets related to suicide. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several species of bacteria adapt to the host environment by changing their morphotype which often coincides with broad changes in physiology that promotes their survival. Mycobacteroides abscessus is an emerging pathogen that presents as either a smooth or rough morphotypes which have very different behaviors in the host. This proposal aims to define the genes contributing to the difference between the two morphotypes behavior in vitro and during infection using a library of gene mutants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A balanced supply of deoxynucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs), the building blocks for DNA, is vital for the synthesis or repair of both nuclear and mitochondrial genomes, thereby maintaining cellular fitness. However, little is known regarding whether and how dNTP metabolism affects innate immunity. This MIRA R35 project aims to establish the role of dNTP metabolism as a new layer of innate immune regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AND RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Colon cancer evolution from precursor lesions is described mainly by two pathways, the adenoma-carcinoma sequence and the less understood 'alternative serrated pathway'. This application investigates the mech- anisms of the serrated pathway of human colon carcinogenesis by applying computational approaches to genomics and single cell/spatial transcriptomic data of a large cohort of precursor serrated lesions. Under- standing the precursor potential to malignancy can considerably enhance prevention, diagnosis and the clinical predictability of the serrated lesions and polyps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the USA; however, clinical therapies aiming to grow blood vessels in the body are currently lacking. Recently, we developed innovative technologies for directly reprogramming somatic cells toward endothelial cells (rECs) using the ETV2 gene, bypassing a stem cell stage. In this proposal, we will develop a clinically compatible ETV2 vector and rECs engineered with a novel biomaterial, and determine the therapeutic effects of direct delivery of ETV2 gene and engineered rECs on ischemic animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative To improve our understanding of mechanisms of drug action in the enteric parasite Cryptosporidium parvum, we are proposing to expose Cryptosporidium parasites to chemical mutagens or to mutagenic radiation, and select mutagenized populations for resistance to drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: IMPACT CENTER NARRATIVE The goal of the IMPACT Center: Optimizing Evidence-Based Practice Implementation for Clinical Impact, is to increase high-fidelity delivery of evidence-based practices (EBPs) for youth receiving mental healthcare in low- resource community settings. IMPACT Center's approach is to optimize EBP implementation in community set- tings by partnering with stakeholders to develop practical implementation strategies, methods, and resources for the practice and scientific communities. We focus on three challenges to high-fidelity EBP delivery: (I) Identify and prioritize determinants of practice; (II) Match strategies to prioritized determinants; and (III) Optimize strate- gies. Our research will have a strong impact on public health by enhancing treatment quality in the service of improving clinical outcomes for youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this grant is to investigate the contributions of mitochondrial diversity as a regulator of cell- and circuit-specific functions. The work from this grant is expected to link the distinct mitochondrial bioenergetic signature of CA2 neurons to the unique molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying CA2 function in learning and memory. Completion of this project will advance our understanding of mitochondrial heterogeneity in a cell type important for social memory and will identify novel therapeutic candidates for disorders with social deficits, such as schizophrenia and autism.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Spontaneous preterm birth is a leading cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality, yet we lack the means to diagnose it in advance, treat, or prevent it, especially in women giving birth for the first time. We will analyze samples from one of the best-phenotyped cohorts of nulliparous pregnant women, the nuMoM2b study, providing the largest sample size of its kind along with detailed clinical data affording a nuanced view of prematurity. Our study will identify new biomarkers for early identification of preterm birth, and potential mechanisms underlying it, through a high-resolution investigation of the microbes and small molecules in the female reproductive tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will use high-resolution functional neuroimaging and human intracranial recordings to delineate the contributions of the dorsal and ventral subregions of the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) to episodic memory. This research will test the hypothesis that the dorsal PCC serves as a putative accumulator of mnemonic information in support of memory-based decisions, while the ventral PCC supports the retrieval of mnemonic details and associations from previous episodes. Abnormalities in the function and structure of the PCC are associated with neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease), and further understanding of the precise functional organization of the PCC will help to both better understand cognitive deficits that characterize disease progression and to inform more precise interventions aimed at mitigating these deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to design, control and engineer materials and biological systems drives the development of innovative knowledge, tools and processes for advanced biotechnology in the pharma, medical devices and diagnostics industries. To achieve this goal, we must train the next generation of innovators who can be productive members of interdisciplinary teams working to translate fundamental science into products and services for human health. The UMass Amherst Biotechnology Training Program in Applied Life Sciences will continue to provide students from a variety of life sciences and engineering/physical sciences backgrounds with novel training in biotechnology, inspiring them to consider industrial relevance and translational science, and preparing them to enter the workforce with an integrated perspective about the role of biotechnology in society.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ebolaviruses are among the deadliest pathogens known to man, with a mortality rate of 25–90% depending on the outbreak. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical circumstances that allow for chronic recordings from and stimulation of deep brain areas provide a rare opportunity to investigate neural mechanisms underlying freely moving behaviors in humans. The results from the proposed studies will bring in line major discoveries in rodent physiology with the human medial temporal lobe system underlying spatial navigation and memory. These translational studies will address questions about the relationship between deep brain stimulation, oscillatory activity, spatial navigation, and memory, and help lay the foundation for future treatments for illnesses marked by memory impairment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the development of an organism, proliferating cells must replicate both their genome and the histones that package it. This proposal aims to gain mechanistic insight into how expression, specifically transcriptional repression, of replication-dependent histone genes is connected to the cell cycle and regulated and to determine how aberrant expression of histones affects the development of an organism. The principles uncovered from these studies will increase our understanding of the regulation of histone biosynthesis and provide insight into the role of histone regulation on the development of organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use and intimate partner violence (IPV) are major public health concerns that often coincide during adolescence to young adulthood and can be exacerbated by simultaneous symptoms of depression or post- traumatic stress. The present proposal will examine (1) the bidirectional association between alcohol use and IPV perpetration and victimization, (2) symptoms of depression or post-traumatic stress as potential moderators in the relationship between alcohol use and IPV perpetration and victimization, and (3) whether these relationships change as a function of sex assigned at birth, race, and ethnicity. Eleven years of pre- existing longitudinal annual data of adolescents (age 15) to young adults (age 26) will be used to explore the study aims to inform culturally sensitive prevention and interventions aimed at reducing intimate partner violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because acute kidney disease (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) are widespread problems that are both associated with significant morbidity and increased mortality. Currently, supportive care is the only therapeutic option for these diseases. The experiments in this proposal will improve our understanding of the mechanisms of AKI and CKD, and they may lead to effective new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper brain development requires the cooperation of neurons and glial cells. One form of this cooperation is neuronal contact with astrocytes, which induces astrocyte morphological and transcriptional maturation. This proposal will test how epigenetic histone modifications act as a mechanism linking neuronal contact to astrocyte maturation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will help us to understand bidirectional relations between parental experiences of burden (i.e., difficulties perceived to be caused or exacerbated by a child's psychiatric symptoms) and their adolescents’ mental health service use following psychiatric hospitalization, with attention to the effect of socioeconomic status on this association. This study will employ a mixed methods design with a sample of 252 mothers of recently hospitalized adolescents. Findings may be used to improve the cultural responsiveness of care coordination and intervention post-hospitalization which may reduce health disparities, youth suicide risk, and the substantial burden associated with youth psychiatric hospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the United States, in part because of our lack of understanding of its etiology, epidemiology, and disparities based on race or ethnicity. Our research aims to characterize the landscape of ancestry effects on lung cancer evolution, and understand the mechanisms underlying the genomic disparities. Our findings will provide implications for lung cancer outcomes and enable the discovery of novel biomarkers to improve prognostics and precision medicine, particularly for the minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative A growing population of obese, older adult breast cancer survivors face unique brain health challenges post-treatment, including cognitive impairments and anxiety symptoms. There is unanimous consensus among guidelines for cancer survivors that increasing physical activity and limiting alcohol consumption are key modifiable health behaviors to target for interventions; however, both the effects of light-intensity physical activity, and the unique interactions of physical activity and alcohol consumption on brain health, are unknown. The proposed study seeks to investigate the effects of a 15 week light-intensity physical activity intervention among obese, older adult breast cancer survivors, in comparison to usual care, on cognitive function and anxiety symptoms, and observe associated changes in alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tens of millions of individuals living with HIV-1 are taking highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), a long- term and life-saving treatment comprising the use of multiple antivirals that prevent HIV-1 infection by targeting essential enzymes involved in the viral replication cycle. Our lab previously reported a potent non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), JT-4-173, that binds at the typical NNRTI-binding site but inhibits the virus through a previously undescribed process that is unique to this compound. Here, I aim to characterize the novel mechanism of action of JT-4-173, which can both further our understanding of HIV-1 reverse transcriptase biology and aid in the development of future generations of HAART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing incidence of patients on two or more prescription drugs creates increasing chances of nega- tive drug interactions, so improved methods for identifying and predicting deleterious, and possibly lethal drug combinations, particularly for interactions with opioids, are desperately needed. I will use a unique translational bioinformatics approach to predict adverse drug reactions for patients by leveraging: the proteins with which each drug interacts, each patient's prescription drug regimen, and patient speciﬁc demographic information. The out- come will be an effective software to predict adverse drug reactions caused by opioid related polypharmacy that will aid clinicians by optimizing prescribing practices for patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While psychological stress can precipitate many cardiovascular events, and targeting those susceptible to stress-induced events in clinical trials has reduced event risk, the absence of a non-invasive metric that captures cardiac decompensation in heart failure (HF) patients has until recently impeded the identification of psychological experiences as acute precipitants that contribute to HF decompensation and hospitalization. The recent introduction of the wireless hemodynamic monitor (e.g., CardioMEMS,), implanted in the pulmonary artery to directly measure pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) provides a unique opportunity to identify and risk stratify HF patients for whom stress may contribute to HF exacerbation. We propose to leverage this new technology to: (Aim 1a) determine the effect of acute laboratory stress on momentary PAP, (Aim 1b) determine the relationship of daily stress and negative emotion to daily PAP as captured by ecological momentary assessment, and, (Aim 2) determine the relationship of stress-induced PAP increase to HF exacerbation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While prior studies have reported worse symptoms in women following traumatic brain injury, a neurobiological basis for this sex difference has not been thoroughly examined, particularly in individuals who sustained a TBI during a traumatic event. The proposed study aims to characterize sex differences in white matter integrity and resting-state functional connectivity and how these connectivity metrics relate to symptoms and quality of life. Findings will inform our understanding of sex differences in brain connectivity, how connectivity relates to symptoms, and the influence of estradiol levels in trauma-exposed individuals with TBI, helping identify more precise intervention windows and novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: DOE: Project Narrative The Tony Mazzocchi Center (TMC) will conduct 1,430 workshops that will reach 28,900 DOE site workers, Tribal members and community residents with 355,200 hours of training over the proposed five-year grant from 2020-2025. To meet our training goals, TMC has direct access to 3,742 USW and CWA members employed at DOE sites; to other employees located at 12 DOE Nuclear Weapons Complex sites; and to community stakeholders including Native American Tribe members, local vocational schools, fire departments, and community organizations. We will conduct required HAZWOPER courses as well as a range of other classes, including radiation worker safety, industrial hygiene training, OSHA outreach training, accident investigation training, effective health and safety committee training, and disaster response training, including response to disasters related to climate change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study investigates the mechanism by which a unique group (“exceptional controllers”) are able to control HIV infection without HIV medications. We hypothesize that exceptional controllers have very low levels of virus in the lymphoid tissues, have levels of inflammation similar to people without HIV, and do not benefit from HIV medications. If these hypotheses are true, exceptional controllers might serve as a model for a treatment-free HIV “remission.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is a need for rapid advances in understanding the ways the sole causative agent of the sexually transmitted infection, gonorrhea, acts as a successful pathogen. This need is due to the rising rate of N. gonorrhoeae infection and an alarming rise in antibiotic resistance complicating treatment. This work will create genetic resources for the entire research field that will facilitate investigations into how this important human pathogen causes disease and facilitate the development of new treatments or vaccines.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Women and children were historically excluded from and continue to be under-represented in clinical research studies, leading to a paucity of knowledge relating to pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of therapeutic agents in these populations. The IU-OSU MPRINT DMKRCC will identify data relevant to understanding maternal and pediatric physiology, pharmacology, and clinical outcomes from literature, public resources, and MPRINT collaborators, integrate data into pharmacometric models to enhance knowledge and understanding of drug disposition and response, and support drug development and therapeutics in maternal and pediatric populations. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to enhance drug safety and efficacy in maternal and pediatric patients by understanding inter- and intra-individual sources of variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the U.S., and new treatment strategies are urgently needed. Abundant preclinical and epidemi- ologic data link lower levels of circulating vitamin D to increased risk of and mortality from colorectal cancer, but causal evidence from randomized clinical trials is needed before vitamin D supplementation can be incorporated into standard of care treatment. This proposal will provide causal evidence in support of the clinical efficacy of vitamin D supplementation in patients with colorectal cancer, as well as elucidate underlying mechanisms of action on the immune tumor microenvironment that may lead to novel combination treatment strategies with immunotherapy agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Center for Adolescent reward rhythms and sleep (CARRS) Narrative: Adolescence is a time of heightened reward sensitivity and greater impulsivity. On top of this, many teenagers experience chronic sleep deprivation and misalignment of their circadian rhythms due to biological shifts in their sleep/wake preferences paired with early school start times. Many studies find that this increases the risk for substance use (SU). However, we don’t know what impact circadian rhythm and sleep disruption either together or independently have on the neuronal circuitry that controls reward and cognition, or if there are interventions that might help to prevent these changes. Our center will perform human and animal studies with the goal of understanding the important role of sleep and circadian rhythms in the vulnerability for SU in adolescents. We will also provide training and community outreach to educate scientists and the public about the importance of sleep and rhythms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT – OVERALL Failures of the mucus clearance system can produce consequences for the US population in the context of susceptibilities to inhaled infectious agents and environmental toxins. In addition, failure of the mucus clearance system produces a spectrum of muco-obstructive lung diseases, including COPD, asthma, non-CF bronchiectasis, and the rare genetic diseases cystic fibrosis and pulmonary ciliary dyskinesia. There is a great need to elucidate the normal structure and function of mucins to understand their roles in lung health and to develop strategies for the treatment of chronic failures of mucus clearance, i.e., patients with muco-obstructive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The clearance of apoptotic cells, termed “efferocytosis”, is essential for the maintenance of tissue homeostasis. Although much is known about the mechanisms of apoptotic cell recognition and uptake, how efferocytes process the metabolic cargo they receive during apoptotic cell uptake and how they hijack the endocytic machinery for this process are underexplored. In this R35 MIRA proposal, we will determine the novel mechanisms by which efferocytes degrade apoptotic cells and remove excess cholesterol released from digested apoptotic cells to maintain cellular homeostasis.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza vaccination is strongly recommended for hospitalized children, many of whom are at high-risk for influenza infection and associated complications, yet approximately half fail to receive this needed vaccine before hospital discharge. This project will establish a stakeholder-informed, standardized inpatient influenza vaccination program and examine its effectiveness in increasing influenza vaccination rates of hospitalized children across diverse U.S. pediatric health systems. The program has important public health implications for influenza vaccine delivery to high-risk children, with indirect benefits to other vulnerable populations including the elderly, and could be expanded to other needed vaccines, patient populations, and healthcare settings.

PROJECT_TITLE: The INFLUENTIAL Trial- Inpatient FLU Vaccination Program Effectiveness: National Trial Implementing Best Practices And Learning Collaboratives

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Ethnic minorities have a severe data-disadvantage that is set to produce new health disparities as data-driven and algorithm-based biomedical research and clinical decisions become increasingly common. The proposed research addresses this challenge by discovering critical knowledge and creating open resources for a paradigm shift in multiethnic machine learning using cancer clinical omics data. This paradigm shift is expected to prevent or reduce health disparities arising from the data-disadvantage of ethnic minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Career development programs that focus on the retention and advancement of under-represented minority (URM) mid-career research faculty are needed to foster greater diversity in the ranks of senior investigators and institutional leaders, and ultimately of the larger biomedical workforce to address the healthcare needs of all people. We propose a career development program that unites the expertise and educational modalities of the Association of American Medical Colleges and the University of Pittsburgh's Institute for Clinical Research Education and partners with three minority serving institutions and Centers of Excellence to recruit mid-career faculty researchers on the cusp of promotion and consideration for leadership opportunities. Our yearlong program will matriculate 20 mid-career scholars per year with the aim of increasing their retention, promotion into senior ranks, attainment of leadership roles, and the longevity of their research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Medication-assisted treatments (MATs) are recommended during pregnancy and postpartum for opioid use disorder (OUD) yet relapse rates remain elevated and we have limited knowledge of the factors contributing to opioid use trajectories during this critical time. The proposed study will be the first to examine the predictive role of psychosocial and parenting stress on opioid-use trajectories during pregnancy and across the postpartum period. Findings will be critical to the development of more effective evidence-based intervention and prevention approaches for pregnant women and mothers with OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This application is focusing to enhance the state of art of molecular diagnosis of sepsis, one of the leading public health concerns. The proposed interdisciplinary work includes new methods to isolate and concentrate bacteria from patient sample, an isothermal and amplification-free assay to identify antimicrobial strains, and a highly efficient optofluidic sensing chip to detect fluorescently labeled targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and especially diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI) is a powerful tool for investigating the health of white matter issue in neurologic diseases. The diffusion-time dependence of the apparent diffusion coefficient in neural tissues has been recognized in several studies, yet is an underexplored aspect of DWI, particularly to uncover the microstructural features of white matter tissue. This proposal aims to reveal the microstructural features that underlie the diffusion-time dependent changes measured in neural tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Lineage plasticity is an increasingly common mechanism of resistance to targeted therapy seen in multiple solid tumors that results in universally poor patient outcomes. Using EGFR-mutant lung cancers as our model system, we will comprehensively molecularly characterize lineage plasticity using patient-derived samples and use patient-derived xenograft transformation models to genetically and pharmacologically assess putative drivers of transformation. Our goal is to inform development of novel therapeutic interventions to prevent or reverse histologic transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will significantly advance our understanding of how human gut bacteria affect the development and progression of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, in particular, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Specifically, this work will define new molecular pathways that causally connect the bacterial metabolism of bile acids (cholesterol-derived compounds that are produced by the host and metabolized by the resident microbiota) and the differentiation and function of T cells (immune cells that play critical roles in host immune homeostasis and disease). This research will lay the groundwork for the development of new therapies for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases that target the microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Protein synthesis is a highly regulated process with the ribosome being an important antibiotic target. The goal of this project is to understand at a molecular level how the P-site tRNA regulates translation initiation, ribosome recycling, and protein synthesis quality control. To achieve our goals, we combine state-of-the-art techniques of cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and X-ray crystallography with biochemical and kinetic approaches of large functional ribosome complexes; the findings may pave the way to structure-guided design of next-generation antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Boys are diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) at least four times more frequently than girls, but the mechanisms underlying this bias remain largely unknown. Serotonin regulates social and emotional behaviors and abnormal function in the serotonin system has been described in ASD. In this proposal, we will elucidate the mechanism of sex-dependent serotonin function that influences social behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a significant problem among underserved populations who receive care in community health centers. Several evidence-based psychotherapies for PTSD are not practical given the time and resources required for these approaches. This research will examine whether Written Exposure Therapy (WET), a brief and well-tolerated therapy approach, delivered within collaborative primary care is effective and can be implemented successfully within a collaborative care (CC) intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Digital health technologies such as remote patient monitoring (RPM) have potential to improve the care of Latinx patients with hypertension (HTN), but there are barriers to both effective and equitable use in clinical practice and a need for better approaches in this population. Growing evidence supports the addition of community health workers (CHWs) to primary care teams as effective means to address social and structural determinants of health and healthcare needs to improve HTN management among Latinx patients, and supporting their digital health competency and capacity may enable improved implementation and sustained use of RPM technology. This study seeks to enhance implementation and effectiveness of RPM among Latinx patients with uncontrolled HTN using CHWs supported by advanced RPM training and EHR support tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of our proposal is to define the clinical relevance of variants associated with Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) and early onset retinal degeneration (eoRD) by establishing a variant curation expert panel (VCEP) to develop disease-gene specified rules for curation, and to systematically classify variants, implementing the specified rules and ClinGen-approved protocols. The results will generate an FDA expert level approved resource of accurately classified variants in LCA/eoRD genes that will improve the consistency and accuracy of interpreting diagnostic genetic test results, leading to more precise diagnosis and improved medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is estimated to affect 13 million people and results in 2 million deaths each year around the world. Currently there are no effective pharmacologic treatments to prevent AKI, improve outcomes of AKI, or suppress the transition from AKI to chronic kidney disease (CKD) and this is predominantly because of lack of knowledge regarding what happens in the human kidney when AKI occurs. We now propose to study human AKI and CKD biopsy tissues to understand the injury signals and cellular responses and to work collaboratively with KPMP consortium members to better understand AKI, thus identifying therapeutic targets for improving outcomes in patients with AKI and CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative This proposal focuses on genetic and biochemical mechanisms misactivating the cell cycle in meningioma, the most common primary intracranial tumor. Our objectives are to define the efficacy and biomarkers of response to CDK6 inhibitors in meningioma, define the molecular mechanisms underlying CDK6 misactivation in meningiomas, and identify pathways mitigating resistance to CDK6 blockade in meningioma. By integrating human samples, an innovative organoid model of meningioma tumorigenesis, and understudied patient derived meningioma xenografts with CRISPR interference and pharmacology, this work will provide fundamental insights into meningioma biology and establish preclinical foundation to support new trials for meningioma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Photoreceptor cell death is the ultimate cause of vision loss in many retinal disorders, including inherited retinal degenerations, retinal detachment, and non-exudative age-related macular degeneration. Vision loss patients experience secondary to such retinal disorders results in life-long clinical care, loss of productivity for patients and caregivers, and reduced quality of life. This project will provide necessary career skills to investigate how retinal bioenergetic resources maintain photoreceptor metabolism, function, and viability in health and disease and whether these resources can be leveraged therapeutically to prevent vision loss in blinding eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to judge the locations of various objects from oneself during self-motion in the intermediate distance range (~2-25m) is crucial for successful performance of activities of daily living, such as walking and driving. However, little is known about the mechanisms of visual space perception involved in judging distance, the focus of this project, in the planning and/or execution of self-motion in the natural 3D environment. The theoretical knowledge to be gained from this project will contribute to the scientific literature and provide insights into how eye and neurological defects could impair visual space perception, wayfinding, and mobility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gastrointestinal tract and kidneys provide respectively about 200 and 350 square meters of body surfaces to the outside world - by far the largest surfaces in the body. The FAIR DOs program will educate the next generation of researchers in using the latest computational tools to study transport processes across these crucial surfaces. The use of FAIR methods will also ensure that students appreciate the importance of open science, data sharing, standardization and large-scale collaborative modeling efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a common life-shortening genetic disease that causes progressive lung failure due to recurrent infections and airway obstruction. These studies will use airway cells and cystic fibrosis animal models to investigate new therapeutic strategies to complement CF defects, including gene repair and the addition of a small molecule anion channel. Through these studies we hope to accelerate the development of new therapeutics for CF lung disease. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer risk behaviors (e.g., smoking, physical inactivity, obesity) are linked to poor treatment response, side effects, heightened recurrence risk, shortened lifespan, poor quality of life and increased treatment cost for many patients, but treatment of these behaviors is not routinely integrated into cancer care. Utilizing telehealth offers the opportunity to extend patient access to health promotion services that decrease risk behaviors among oncology patients. As developers of evidence-based, technology-assisted risk behavior treatments, we propose to refine and evaluate the first tailored, cancer-specific, telehealth treatment program for multiple risk behaviors to be fully integrated into quality care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is a leading cause of human skin infections and is associated with itchy skin lesions in patients with Atopic dermatitis and Impetigo. Here, we investigate the role of S. aureus and its secreted proteases in driving itch during infection, and the role of neurons in mediating skin immune responses. Our study could reveal novel mechanisms of itch and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is characterized by a distinct, highly heterogeneous molecular profile, aggressive nature, early relapses, the worst survival rates in all breast cancer subtypes and a lack of FDA- approved targeted therapies. Because TNBC cell growth is not dependent on estrogen and progesterone hormones, and epidermal growth factor 2 (HER2/Neu) signaling, the patients cannot benefit from anti-estrogen (i.e., tamoxifen) or anti-HER2 therapies, representing an unmet therapeutic challenge. We recently identified EF2-kinase (EF2K), an unusual member of alpha kinase family and does not have any homology with known kinases, as a prognostic marker for its dramatic association with patient survival and validated it as a potential molecular target in TNBC; thus here we are proposing to develop highly effective, safe and effective therapeutic strategies for targeting EF2K and evaluate their in vivo efficacy as monotherapy and in combination with the standard chemotherapy in clinically relevant preclinical models of TNBC with the long-term goal of translating into the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Over 80% of people with Parkinson's disease (PD) will develop dementia, causing lower quality of life, increased caregiver burden, and worse health outcomes. Although the pathological mechanisms of dementia in PD are poorly understood, Alzheimer's disease (AD) co-pathology is believed to play an important role. Identifying the impact of AD genetic risk factors in PD dementia (PDD) will broaden our understanding of PDD and open the door to developing therapeutic or preventative approaches targeting AD pathology to reduce the burden of dementia in PD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will enhance the understanding of the role of intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells function on sleep and circadian regulation in people with diabetes, especially those with retinopathy. It will provide the evidence of potential benefit of melatonin in improving sleep and circadian regulation in patients with type 2 diabetes and diabetic retinopathy, which could lead to improve glycemic control and thus reduce complications associated with this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PARP1 is a validated target for cancer therapy in DNA repair-compromised tumors, with four clinically approved drugs and many ongoing phase III clinical trials. We propose to study the structure, activity, inhibition, and downstream effects of PARP1 bound to chromatin DNA. Our quantitative, structural, and mechanistic approaches will aid in the development of the next generation of PARP inhibitors.

PHR: Environmental pollutants as well as plant, microbial and host-derived products can bind to aryl hydrocarbon receptors (AhR). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Suppressive immune cells in tumors are supported by high levels of the amino acid glutamine, and we have recently shown that small molecule glutamine metabolism inhibitors have potent anticancer effectiveness. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of TB, has long been known to release an enzyme that generates high levels of glutamine, and we recently found that the same glutamine metabolism inhibitors that are active in cancer models also act to reduce TB burden, reduce suppressive immune cells, and prolong survival in animal models. This application will further define the immunosuppressive roles of glutamine in the TB granuloma and also investigate a panel of new glutamine metabolism inhibitors as TB therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social gaze interactions serve a dominant function in contingent and dynamic social exchanges between individuals. However, the causal brain mechanisms underlying complex inter-individual gaze behaviors remain elusive. In this proposal, we will investigate functionally informed causal contributions of the orbitofrontal cortex, the basolateral amygdala, and the communication between the two brain areas, in real-life face-to-face social gaze interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in SYNGAP1 cause a neurodevelopmental disorder, which is associated with intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder, and motor impairments. This research will use mouse models to investigate how mutations in Syngap1 affect communication between brain cells responsible for the selection and learning of appropriate actions. Our findings will advance our understanding of the cellular and circuit basis of SYNGAP1 disorders and can be leveraged to improve therapeutic possibilities for patients with this and related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A vaccine that will be effective in preventing HIV infection and also control virus replication once the virus has taken hold, will require a dual barrier. The first one at the mucosal portal of entry for the virus to prevent or at least minimize the ability of the virus to create a beachhead and two at the systemic level where generalized immune responses are able to control virus that has succeeded in overcoming the first barrier. Our vaccine strategy targets renewable vaginal epidermal stem cells as a permanent source of antigen production which proliferate and elaborate the vaccine antigen along the phases of the reproductive cycle, providing repeated bouts of vaccine antigen presentation as the cells mature and cycle, leading to induction of humoral and cellular immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The “Prevention of Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms” (PLUS) Research Consortium is a transdisciplinary U.S. scientific network established to expand research beyond the detection and treatment of LUTS to the promotion of bladder health and prevention of LUTS in adolescents and women across the life course. Our overarching hypothesis is that healthy voiding and toileting behaviors contribute to improved bladder health and decreased LUTS for adolescent and adult women. Our transdisciplinary PLUS team at the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) proposes three interrelated pathways related to healthy voiding and toileting behaviors that may impact bladder health and prevention of LUTS: (1) conducting a longitudinal cohort study of women to assess bladder health and LUTS across the life course; (2) increase understanding of risk and protective factors to inform plausible intervention targets for healthy voiding and toileting behaviors; and (3) developing delivery models for future bladder health education programming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Normal brain functions arise from the activity of populations of neurons within cortical networks. When normal patterns of activity across neuronal populations go awry, many neurological disorders occur. The pro- posed research investigates the neural basis for visual segmentation, a fundamental perceptual function with well-known impairments in some patients. The study will advance our understanding of representing sensory information in neuronal populations in the cerebral cortex. The insights gained from the proposed research may contribute to a better understanding of neurological disorders such as dyslexia and visual agnosia that involve malfunction of visual segmentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE iPATH will leverage prior federal and private investments in health care quality research to systematically identify, rigorously test, and disseminate promising care delivery innovations in Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) across four U.S. regions. Research will (a) identify processes and organizational conditions at FQHCs that promote or impede the effectiveness of type 2 diabetes care; (b) adapt a promising patient- centered medical home practice transformation strategy; and (c) test an innovative implementation approach. iPATH will apply novel multi-method, iterative, practice-relevant research focused on patient-centered, team- based, technology-enabled care to promote customized practice transformation that will address equity challenges in diabetes care and improve care for NIH-designated U.S. health disparity populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Humans live in a society that has rigid schedules for work, school, and social activities often requiring them to be active when their biological circadian clock is indicating a need for sleep. Misalignment in the timing of the master circadian clock in the brain, the circadian clocks located throughout the body and the onset of sleep or activity can lead to significant adverse health problems. This proposal will examine the role of neurons and non-neuronal brain cells in regulating biological timing and identify possible targets for the therapeutic intervention of circadian-based disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Bashir, Rashid Project Narrative: Sepsis, a life-threatening syndrome that contributes to millions of deaths annually worldwide, represents a moral and economic burden to the healthcare system. We propose to develop a point-of-care microfluidic biochip for measuring cell- surface and plasma-proteins biomarkers that will be used for contributing with early diagnosis and risk stratification of sepsis. The proposed device could transform the current sepsis diagnosis criteria, which are extremely non-specific, into an accurate screening tool to reduce over-prescription of antibiotics, increase survival rates, decrease lengths of stay, and enable more efficient development of treatment options in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Phosphoinositides (PIPs) are minor components of the eukaryotic membrane but major regulators of cellular functions. One of the cellular processes regulated by PIPs is autophagy, a process essential for a broad range of cellular functions and tissue development, and dysregulated in many human diseases. The proposed studies based on our recent discoveries will uncover novel mechanisms of PIP regulation of autophagy and potentially reveal new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Many novel drug treatments are being investigated towards a durable HIV cure, including immunosuppressants targeting immune dysfunction and inflammation associated with HIV infection persistence, as well as broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) that clear virus and HIV-infected cells. This project will 1) explore how varying exposure to the immunosuppressant, sirolimus, administered with a recombinant varicella zoster virus vaccine, decreases HIV reservoirs and restores immune function, and how patient-specific, genetic, and disease factors may contribute to differences in drug effect, and 2) determine if systemic bNAb levels can predict time to viral rebound after antiretroviral treatment interruption. Overall, this research will help inform dosing in people with HIV and future pharmacological investigations in the HIV cure field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulation of amyloid plaques and the formation of neurofibrillary tangles are critical events in the pathogenesis of AD. Thus, treatments that reduce both are hypothesized to block and potentially reverse pathogenesis and disease progression. Avanti Biosciences is pioneering the development of potent negative allosteric modulators of DYRK1A, a kinase that phosphorylates tau and whose activity is linked to p-tau mediated synaptic and neuronal dysfunction and death in AD. Furthermore, DYRK1A phosphorylates the APP and enhances its affinity for Beta-Secretase 1 (BACE1) and the γ-secretase complex, increasing overall Aβ levels and plaque deposition2. Thus, DYRK1A inhibitors are potentially helpful in treating both hallmarks of AD, neurofibrillary tangles, and amyloid plaques. In collaboration with NYS Institute for Basic Research, Avanti Biosciences has identified a new series of fluoro catechin derivatives that potently and efficiently inhibit the activity of DYRK1A both in vitro and in vivo. The requested funding will allow the progress of our optimized lead compound, ABI-171, into a long-term AD disease animal model and IND enabling studies to determine the new drug’s efficacy and safety profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The accumulation of dental plaque into stable, long-range biofilms leads to chronic periodontitis due to dysbiosis of oral microbiome. This project investigates the consequences of the aging in non-human primate model of SIV infection and antiretroviral therapy on periodontitis related to oral microbiome alterations. Knowledge gained from the research proposed may help improve the regenerative capacity of the periodontal tissue in PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary Spastic Paraplegia (HSP) comprises a group of rare heritable neurological disorders characterized by progressive lower extremity weakness and spasticity resulting from the gradual degeneration of long axons projecting from corticospinal motor neurons (CSMN). While it is known that the most common form, termed SPG4-HSP, is caused by mutations of SPAST, the gene encoding the microtubule-severing protein spastin, the mechanistic basis for the disease remains unknown. Based on novel mechanistic hypotheses, the proposed work utilizes a wide variety of contemporary techniques (including the development and use of novel reporter mouse models) to evaluate mechanisms linking SPAST mutations to CSMN degeneration.

PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement Enteric viral infections, including those caused by rotaviruses (RV), remain a major health scourge resulting in severe distress to millions and hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Economic prosperity and research institution competitiveness demand diversity of the biomedical workforce and diversity in the breadth of scientific inquiry; however, there is a documented shortage of underrepresented minorities (URM) represented in science. Thus, this proposal will establish a new one-year Postbaccalaureate Research Education Proposal at UW-Madison (UW-PREP) that will fill a current gap that exists in the pipeline for increasing the number of URM individuals that are prepared to take on rigorous graduate training in the biomedical sciences. The UW-PREP uses evidence based Entering Research and Mentor Training curricula alongside a vast array of resources and dedicated faculty and staff to prepare extraordinary URM scholars towards impactful and productive careers in the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ LAY SUMMARY This proposal represents Mayo Clinic’s application to participate in the HeartShare Research Consortium, a program established by the National Institutes of Health. This team science initiative will be enabled by advances in data science and focus on determining the causes of heart failure (HF) with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The HeartShare initiative will ultimately lead to new ways to diagnose and treat HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Globally, access to lung transplantation for high risk patients varies significantly due to a lack of consensus regarding their eligibility. Our project will compare how different lung transplant centers manage these patients, which will help us to develop new standard guidelines for their care. Ultimately, this will allow more patients to receive a surgery that reduces their illnesses and saves their lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV are at increased risk for developing dementia despite treatment with antiretroviral therapy. Dementia risk scores based on measures routinely collected in primary care may assist clinicians in identification of individuals who could benefit from earlier targeted intervention or cognitive screening. The proposed K01 Career Development Award will support Dr. Jennifer Lam in the completion of a mentored research project and acquisition of skills necessary for future independent research on the prevention and management of dementia in people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung transplantation is a life-saving cure but is limited by graft failure. The creation of a national Lung Transplantation Consortium holds great promise for uniting physicians and scientists to improve patient outcomes. Our Center focuses on understanding why lung transplant recipients respond poorly to vaccinations so that better life-preserving vaccines can be designed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A plant virus nanotechnology-based immunotherapy will be developed against metastatic tumors. Specifically, good manufacturing practices (GMP)-compatible, scalable methods for molecular farming of the nanotechnology in plants will be developed; efficacy, pharmacology and toxicology will be evaluated in tumor mouse models and canine patients to set the foundation for translation into clinical trials and practice. Successful completion would enable GMP manufacture, IND-enabling pharmacology, and First-Time-In-Human trial of the plant virus cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Between 2020 and 2021, US policy changes will require increased visibility of information about calories, serving sizes and added sugars on the back or side of packaged foods. During the same time, Mexico will put “stop sign” warnings on the front of packaged foods that are high in calories, sodium, sugar, or fat, as well as on products with added caffeine or sweeteners. This study will analyze surveys of Mexicans and Americans, including Mexican Americans, to evaluate labeling policy effects on nutrition knowledge and healthy eating, including which policy is most effective for people with limited resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research will provide new understandings on the role of deficient lubrication in the development of osteoarthritis after joint injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Extremity trauma involving volumetric muscle loss (VML) presents a clinical challenge with significant fibrosis and fatty infiltration, impaired regeneration, and long-term functional disabilities. In this work, we will use pre-clinical models to define the roles of key cell types in the pathologic process of VML. We then utilize this foundational understanding to develop newly engineered immunomodulatory and regenerative treatment strategies with the long term goal of translating these into clinical treatments to improve functional outcomes after VML injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations among children have spiked dramatically worldwide, and children are an important source of community transmission; however, COVID-19 immunity studies have predominantly focused on adults due to ease of sample collection and exclude children whose immune systems are still developing. This proposal addresses the critical need to study the short- and long-term immune responses to the COVID-19 mRNA vaccine in adolescents, children, and mother-infant pairs and to identify correlates of protection against breakthrough infection. The results will inform policy makers and scientists on how to optimize COVID-19 vaccination strategies to effectively protect children and decrease community transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the importance of dietary composition and food choice to health, and despite persistent dietary advice to change eating habits, we know almost nothing about how the brain controls dietary macronutrient choice. This project will define the brain areas and neural phenotypes mediating FGF21-dependent changes in feeding behavior, thereby uncovering a novel set of neural circuits that regulate food choice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapies represent a powerful therapeutic paradigm because they are applicable to a wide variety of tumors and can produce durable clinical responses; however, only a fraction of patients experience clinical benefit from current immunotherapies, and there is a need to develop new therapies. Our studies will uncover novel mechanisms by which a certain protein affect immune responses to malignancies, particularly in the immune system's T cells, to successfully disable cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic adults experience adverse aging outcomes that manifest early and confer significant personal and public health costs, including higher rates of chronic health deterioration, cognitive decline, and mortality. The proposed research will leverage epigenetic markers that can detect deviations in cellular aging years before the onset of overt declines, thus helping to identify autistic persons most at risk of poor outcomes and the factors contributing to risk variations in this vulnerable population. Understanding how early clinical and environmental factors in autism coalesce to influence biological aging processes may ultimately inform preventive strategies to mitigate subsequent health and longevity disparities by minimizing risk exposures and promoting identified protective factors across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Effective classification of gene variants associated with inherited retinal diseases is critical for accurate molecular diagnosis and is required to match patients to appropriate treatments to address blindness. Here we will develop disease- and gene-specific rules to modify official ACMG-AMP guidelines for variant interpretation and use these specifications to curate genomic variants found in clinical samples. This work will utilize NHGRI Clinical Genomics Resource (ClinGen) FDA approved processes, procedures, and informatics infrastructure to address seven X-linked inherited retinal disease genes including CACNA1F, CHM, OFD1, NDP, RPGR, RP2, and RS1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The goal of this proposal is to create an efficient new set of tools and techniques for the generation of genetically modified marmosets suitable for use as models of brain physiology and function. These studies will provide tools for future gene editing experiments in marmosets, will establish an initial set of genetically modified tool lines for use in the field, and will provide initial proof-of-principle lines for marmoset models of genetic alterations potentially relevant to the neurobiology of human brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Only a subset of individuals that use drugs of abuse will develop an addiction, suggesting that the transition from drug use to dependence may be mediated by behavioral or biological factors that influence the likelihood of an individual to develop an addiction. Using computationally-derived decision-making phenotypes, this proposal seeks to identify and verify the signaling pathways that confer risk for drug use and to determine if these molecular disruptions are linked to genetic and/or environmental components of risk for drug-taking behaviors. These results will identify novel protein targets to aid in the development of more precise and direct prevention strategies for methamphetamine addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Interleukin-2 (IL-2, Proleukin®) is a T cell growth factor. IL-2 is licensed for the treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma and at low doses, 100-times lower than those used in cancer therapy, IL- 2 promotes the selective expansion of regulatory T cells (Tregs) in humans. Our preliminary data in a phase 1b/2a clinical trial indicates that low-dose IL2 appears safe in ulcerative colitis patients, expands Tregs in the blood, and is associated with a biological response. In this study, we aim to assess the safety of and immune effects of low-dose IL-2 to selectively expand Tregs in vivo in patients with moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease, with the aim that this expansion will be associated with a therapeutic response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Pain associated with trigeminal nerve injury takes a tremendous toll on those who suffer, their family and loved ones, and society because of the intensity and persistence of the pain and the absence of effective treatments. We have discovered two changes in the trigeminal nerve in response to injury that are not observed in somatic nerves in response to the same injury, and have data to suggest that these changes may not only contribute to the pain associated with trigeminal nerve injury but may serve a viable therapeutic targets as well. We have proposed to further explore the implications of these discoveries in experiments that will increase our understanding of the cause of neuropathic pain and that may suggest more effective treatment of pain associated with trigeminal nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/ Lay Summary: Skeletal deterioration and related fracture risk is exacerbated in the elderly cancer survivors receiving radiation treatment (RTx), reducing their quality of life. Our recent work shows that p21+ senescent cells and their secretome are key drivers of RTx-related skeletal deterioration. In this proposal we shall assess if acute removal of p21+ senescent cells can prevent chronic skeletal damage and initiate fracture healing.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Xenopus model is a very powerful in vivo system, but the lack of strong complementary in vitro tools prompts researchers to rely on mammalian cell lines, which can create hurdles due to species specificities. The establishment of Xenopus laevis stem cell lines would allow the Xenopus field to benefit from more robust complementary in vitro tools, expanding the application of this model system as well as eliminating current difficulties associated with working across multiple species experimentally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to elucidate the long-term consequences of COVID-19 in the brain using advanced, quantitative imaging technology. COVID-19 survivors are at higher risk of developing neuropsychiatric and neurologic sequelae after overcoming the infection. Defining the biological basis of these persistent symptoms will be critical for developing therapies specifically targeting the underlying pathologic mechanisms associated with the long-term consequences of COVID-19 and to provide appropriate care to these individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is an understudied breast cancer subtype associated with poor long-term outcomes and resistance to endocrine therapy and chemotherapy, but the underlying biology of ILC is poorly understood. We identified the protein MDC1 as a unique mediator of estrogen receptor function in ILC that is critical for estrogen-driven growth, gene regulation, and anti-estrogen resistance. Understanding the role of MDC1 in ILC will provide a foundation for the development of novel therapeutic approaches and predictive biomarkers for ILC patients, a patient population in critical need of novel, ILC-specific treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human XPD/Rad3-like helicases are critical enzymes for DNA repair and maintaining genomic stability. This project will use Escherichia coli as a model system to study the interaction between an E. coli XPD/Rad3-like helicase and single-stranded DNA binding protein to add to our knowledge of XPD/Rad3-like helicases. This foundational research will not only open doors to creating therapies for patients suffering from XPD/Rad3-like helicase genetic based diseases, but will also give insight into a novel DNA repair pathway that will have far reaching implications for the multitude of ailments caused by stalled DNA replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although there is increasing recognition that the cerebellum is involved in cognition as well as motor function, the manner in which the cerebellum contributes to cognition is uncertain. Using structural and functional neuroimaging, studies of patients with cerebellar damage/degeneration, and brain stimulation methods, the experiments in this proposal will test the hypothesis that the cerebellum generates a prediction of the sequence of events involved in motor or cognitive function in order to guide behavior. This information will improve our understanding of cerebellar involvement in cognitive function, as well as cognitive abnormalities in patients with cerebellar damage or dysfunction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R25 application proposes a new research training program in the NIDDK/KUH mission areas of adult and pediatric nephrology and adult and pediatric (benign) urology. Our Nephrology and Urology training program has successfully trained fellows for careers in academics in basic, translational, and clinical research, while focused on diversity recruitment and retention. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the COVID-19 pandemic, HIV services in sub-Saharan Africa have been adapted to lower-contact alternatives that reduce exposure to SARS-CoV-2, which maintained the effectiveness of some services but reduced the effectiveness of others. For services with reduced effectiveness, we will analyze program data to determine the extent to which effectiveness was reduced, and conduct observations and modeling to estimate the potential for SARS-CoV-2 transmission while accessing services in different ways. We will work with global, national, and local decision-makers to inform policies about when, and for whom, lower-contact services should be offered during the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although there have been tremendous advances in cancer therapy, cancer remains a feared, disabling, and lethal disease; its prevention through the use of medications that will halt or reverse early lesions has particular promise since the complexity of changes that allow fully developed cancer to evade treatment has not yet occurred. We will conduct clinical trials to test medications that appear promising for the purposes of cancer prevention; these trials will tell us whether a particular medication is worth testing in larger trials, how it works, and who will be most likely to benefit from it. We will, in particular, focus on common cancers (breast, colon); those that are both common and lethal (lung); and those that are lethal and often fail treatment (liver, pancreas).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Maternal mortality and morbidity are increasing in the U.S., prompting calls for greater action to address the rising rates and concerning racial disparities in maternal health. Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islanders (NHPIs) are profoundly underrepresented in maternal health research, despite emerging evidence of inequities. The proposed study will advance the development of data-driven and culturally-responsive interventions for NHPIs by 1) assessing critical maternal outcomes for NHPIs by maximizing the few population datasets that disaggregate NHPI and 2) characterizing NHPI experiences across several states and subgroups, and 3) identifying key factors related the processes and quality of maternity care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Progressive retinal disease with vision loss is a chronic complication of long chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (LCHADD) with no current treatment and no previously established animal or cell culture models in which to test novel therapies. We have developed 2 novel experimental models and now propose experiments to characterize an in vitro model of LCHADD induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE)-like cells from patient specific fibroblasts and a novel LCHADD knockin mutant mouse model that exhibits decreased vision. These experiments will further our understanding of LCHADD retinal disease and provide the basis for the development of future treatments for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation therapy for the clinical management of brain tumors and metastases is linked with severe cognitive decline and neuroinflammation in cancer survivors. We hypothesize that radiation-induced aberrant activation of the glial complement cascade play a causal role in development of cognitive impairments. This proposal will address glial complement activation mechanism and translationally feasible intervention to curtain this unmet medical need.
