IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Well-designed multicenter research is urgently needed in lung transplant to optimize donor management, improve recipient candidate selection, reduce postoperative complications, and ultimately extend long-term patient survival. The Lung Transplant Consortium (LTC) will fill these knowledge gaps through the conduct of clinical and mechanistic observational studies across up to eight Clinical Centers (CCs) and through a common protocol led by a single Data Coordinating Center (DCC). The Duke Clinical Research Institute partnered with the University of Pennsylvania as the LTC DCC will provide the consortium with outstanding scientific leadership, experienced administrative support, operational excellence, and biobanking infrastructure to ensure the development and conduct of rigorous, impactful, and efficient studies.

PHR: Project Narrative: The Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) welcomes the opportunity to partner with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) to advance our shared goal of enhancing the diversity of the biomedical research workforce. Through this funding opportunity, the AAMC will develop and deliver a multichannel educational program for cohorts of NIH-awarded K99/R00 scholars from groups underrepresented in research that provides a full suite of career development tools and supports as they transition from postdoctoral appointments into academic research faculty positions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor adherence to HIV prevention regimens is a primary factor in lack of efficacy, with multiple, complex barriers driving product uptake and continued use. We will develop a resorbable subdermal implant for sustained systemic delivery of a novel maturation inhibitor for up to 1 year. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will expand the development pipeline for long-acting HIV prevention products, increase understanding of the pharmacology of novel antiretroviral agents and degradable implantable delivery devices, and potentially improve device uptake, and adherence to HIV prevention regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While it is clear that bacterial pathogens often infect only a subset of available host species, we rarely know the genetic mechanisms that prevent them from making a host jump to colonize new hosts. To address this gap in our knowledge, the goals of this proposal are to determine host genetic factors and interactions with the host-associated microbial community that limit bacterial adaptation to new hosts. The results of this research will inform our understanding of the barriers that prevent a bacterium from colonizing a new host and will improve our ability to predict microbial host jumps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pharmacologic and behavioral interventions are effective in improving outcomes for cardiometabolic diseases (e.g., hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes), but there is an implementation gap in low- and middle-income countries that leads to substantial excess morbidity and mortality. In this proposal, I will use a stepwise approach in Guatemala to investigate the implementation of the World Health Organization Hearts model of integrated treatment of cardiometabolic diseases, through (1) identifying barriers and facilitators to expanding an ongoing hypertension intervention in Guatemala to also include diabetes and dyslipidemia treatment, as recommended in WHO Hearts; (2) co-designing a delivery model of integrated treatment of cardiometabolic diseases using human-centered design, and (3) evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of the delivery model using a mixed-methods evaluation of a cluster randomized pilot study. This project has high public health relevance as it will develop Dr. Flood’s generalizable implementation research expertise to address gaps in the implementation of evidence-based cardiometabolic disease care in resource-limited health systems in the U.S. and abroad.

PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. New and repurposed vaccines against TB offer immense promise to reduce TB-related morbidity and mortality, especially in low- and middle-income countries. This project will estimate the potential impact of introducing TB vaccines in four key countries and identify specific vaccination strategies that will maximize population benefit.

PHR: Project Narrative Poor oral health is epidemic among American youth from low income families. School-based educational programs can be a venue for addressing this problem, however they have not been rigorously evaluated and documented as effective. This grant will allow us to plan for, and test the efficacy of an elementary school-based oral health intervention using a cluster-randomized controlled trial design across children from ethnically-diverse, low-income families in Houston, Texas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Rhythmic behaviors and physiological processes are temporally organized by the central circadian pacemaker to occur at the optimal time of day. Disruption of this precise organization due to disease or lifestyle (shift work, artificial light at night) is associated with negative health outcomes including metabolic, cardiovascular, and mood disorders. Our research program aims to determine the interaction between the genes, neurons, and circuits that time rhythmic behaviors, which will provide a foundation for the investigation of the mechanisms of circadian dysfunction that both lead to, and are a symptom of, disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A more thorough quantitative evaluation of the transcriptional differences between cells in healthy and diseased states particularly is paramount to our understanding of disease etiology. This includes analyzing the transcriptional differences between diseased cells and appropriate normal counterparts both in terms of gene expression and alternative splicing, as well as potential mRNA subcellular localization differences and cellular spatial-contextual differences within tissues. This proposed work will develop computational tools to enable such analysis using large-scale single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatially resolved transcriptome imaging data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance  This proposal will use cerebral organoids derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) to model HIV interactions with drugs of abuse and combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). We will utilize convergent state-of-the-art electrophysiology, single-cell transcriptomics and a systems biology strategy to generate new mechanistic hypotheses on neuroHIV pathogenesis, HIV interaction with drugs of abuse and cART. Ultimately, this proposal will lead to novel therapeutic concepts to improve neuropsychological functioning in people with HIV and substance abuse comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The incidence of acute type B aortic dissection is proportional to the prevalence of uncontrolled hypertension. The results of the IMPROVE-AD trial (including 1100 participants in the US) will provide important clinical guidance on the most appropriate patient-centered ways to reduce mortality and major morbidity by testing two distinct therapeutic strategies. It will also inform decisions regarding racial and gender disparities in patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung diseases such as asthma, chronic bronchitis, cystic fibrosis, tuberculosis, emphysema, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and lung cancer cause substantial morbidity and mortality. This program will produce clinical and basic science investigators with broad experience in Pulmonary investigation. The training program will prepare these researchers for the challenges of academic medicine and biomedical research and will help fill the need for the next generation of scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic dysregulation is a common and challenging comorbidity in patients with asthma that increases morbidity, mortality and healthcare costs. We will study the effects of targeting the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1R) pathway on clinical measures of airway inflammation in adults with asthma, using GLP-1R agonist drugs which are already FDA approved for treatment of type 2 diabetes and obesity. Characterizing the effect of GLP-1R agonists on asthma clinical outcomes and mediators of airway inflammation could inform treatment benefits and patient selection, leading to personalized, glucocorticoid-sparing interventions that reduce risk and improve chronic disease management in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis use disorders are highly prevalent in the U.S., and frequently co-occur with alcohol and other substance use disorders. The proposed research seeks to identify and determine how key genomic variants and pathways interact with each other in a disease-relevant tissue specific context to affect an individual’s risk for drug abuse. The obtained knowledge will be incorporated into a larger disease model and lead to more precision in the understanding of the mechanism underlying risk for cannabis use disorders and thus provide a substrate for more effective prevention and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this ambitious team science grant, we propose to develop the first single cell very early onset inflammatory bowel diseases (VEOIBD) cellular atlas and associated VEOIBD networks. We hypothesize that developing this atlas will inform upon disease pathogenesis and enable targeted therapeutics for VEOIBD patients. Moreover, identification and characterization of novel VEOIBD causative genetic variants will inform upon novel IBD pathogenic networks extending beyond VEOIBD. Robust data and resource (organoid) sharing will facilitate translational research and the identification of therapeutic targets for common forms of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cancer Research Consortium of West Michigan (CRCWM) has over 40 years of community-based clinical trial experience and remains dedicated to assuring that every person in West Michigan, regardless of socioeconomic status, race, or geography, has the opportunity to participate in NCTN/NCORP clinical trials for cancer prevention/control, cancer care delivery, and treatment. These trials are the practice-changing research that improve cancer survival, decrease toxicity, and offer better ways to deliver care with decreased costs. Our partnerships with regional health systems allow us to offer over 130 open and accruing cancer research studies, maintain follow-up for 175 additional trials, offer education to targeted populations, and contribute to the knowledge base surrounding the needs of diverse and underserved populations such as children, adolescents and young adults, racial and ethnic minorities, and rural residents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cell plasticity, the ability of cells to change their phenotypes without genetic mutations, is crucial for the development and the progress of diseases such as cancer. Post-transcriptional mechanisms are essential for cell plasticity as they offer a route to regulate cell fate, specifically in response to rapid changes in response to environmental cues. This proposal investigates the mechanisms by which translational control and RNA modifications regulate cell plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep and circadian disruption are prominent features of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). Circadian, or daily, rhythms influence nearly every aspect of our physiology. This work will help researchers understand how molecular rhythms in the brain may influence the progression of AD, contribute to the sleep disruption experienced by AD patients, and influence the time at which AD targeted medications will be most effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pharmaceutical drugs have reduced mortality and morbidity across all areas of medicine; however, key challenges such as undesirable side effects, poor efficacy, and the need for frequent administration or complex administration routes limit their ability to have even more pronounced impact on patient welfare. The projects described within this proposal seek to overcome these challenges by developing injectable drug delivery platforms that can precisely control pharmacokinetics, reduce the frequency at which drug needs to be readministered, deliver biologics in their bioactive form, and enable multi-drug therapies that match dynamic patient needs. To achieve these goals, we will develop surface-eroding biomaterials that protect the encapsulated payload in combination with advanced fabrication methods that define microparticle geometry— and thus the release of drugs encapsulated in surface-eroding materials—to rationally design injectable particles that are compatible with a broad array of drug classes and exhibit predictable release kinetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Advances in genomics and proteomics have uncovered thousands of previously unannotated small proteins, many of which are encoded on genes implicated in cancer. This proposal seeks to characterize the mechanism of one such novel microprotein with roles in cutaneous wound healing and tumor progression. Successful completion of these studies will enhance our knowledge of how regulators of wound healing are hijacked by cancer, and may provide a new target for the development of cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Klebsiella pneumoniae is an opportunistic nosocomial pathogen that is the cause of severe respiratory, urinary tract and wound infections that can enter the bloodstream and progress to fatal septicemia. Due to the spread of antibiotic resistance, very few drugs remain that can treat these infections. The goal of this project is to optimize our 5-phage therapeutic cocktail and to complete the necessary FDA IND-enabling tests and paperwork in preparation for a future phase 1 clinical trial, which will reduce the impact of K. pneumoniae infections on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed program (Developing and Readying Underrepresented Minority Researchers) will provide 10 disadvantaged and underrepresented minority Texas A&M University System students each year the opportunity to participate in the Texas A&M College of Medicine's Summer Research Program (SRP). We have operated a very competitive and highly successful SRP for the past 12 years and our 10-week program offers various seminars on biomedical research as well as training in the responsible conduct of research while providing the 50 “DRUMRs” the opportunity to choose from a number of invested mentors. Increasing the number of and training the next generation of disadvantaged and underrepresented minority researchers in NIDDK-related biomedical research areas is critical to ensure future discoveries that will improve the health and well-being of millions of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Zika and other related flaviviruses are responsible for human and animal infections in which the mosquito Aedes aegypti is the main vector. Some mosquito salivary components facilitate viral spread in the host. We will develop a vaccine candidate based on the A. aegypti salivary protein AgBR1 to control Zika virus infection and other related flaviviruses in the mouse model and in other rodent models such as guinea pigs and hamsters, which better resemble the human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Continued progress in the life sciences depends on researchers having access to powerful visualization software tools that make it easy for them to discover and visually analyze novel patterns and trends in data. My research investigates methods for creating such software, focusing on building tools to visually analyze data from large- scale genomics assays used in research and clinical settings. My program trains students in advanced, state-of-the-art software development methods while creating open source genome visualization software that is freely available for everyone to use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Exosome-based research in the field of lung transplantation is a rapidly growing area and understanding their role in clinical outcomes, such as primary graft dysfunction (PGD) and acute cellular rejection (ACR), could lead to the identification of potential prognostic biomarkers for risk-stratification. Risk-stratification could be used clinically to better select recipients and match them with donors leading to improved patient outcomes or guide alterations in immunosuppressive management. Additionally, the knowledge gained from these studies would represent the first step towards precision donor/recipient endotyping allowing for the development of novel, targeted therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Aging and obesity are strong risk factors for breast cancer in women because as ovarian estrogen declines, women have less protection from the harmful effects of obesity, which causes inflammation and increases insulin levels. These harmful effects can be reversed by weight loss but this is often not sustainable. We have shown that a novel dietary intervention using time-restricted feeding of a western-style, high-fat diet prevents the effect of obesity to drive breast cancer in mice; the proposed studies will investigate the mechanisms underlying this beneficial effect.

PHR: Project Narrative Cūrza is developing the CZ-02 platform of antibiotics to treat antibacterial-resistant superbugs. CZ-02s exhibit activity via a novel mechanism of action with efficacy demonstrated in multiple animal models of infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project aims to develop a broadly applicable platform for targeting and modulating activity of neurons and other electrogenic cells anywhere within the body. This approach will be further applied to interrogate circuits connecting the enteric (gut) neurons to the midbrain pathways delivering insights into the role of gut-brain connections in modulating dopamine-dependent behaviors. Our technologies and findings would pave way for development of organ-centric therapies for neurological and mental conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our desire to replace or complement chemoradiotherapy with immunotherapy for children with solid or brain tumors is undermined by the fact that most of these tumors have very few genetic mutations and very few T cells in the tumor. The blood brain barrier prevents many immunotherapies from entering the brain. We propose protein engineering strategies to create next-generation bispecific T cell engagers that overcome these barriers and instruct patients’ own T cells to kill the cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Standard strategies for cancer treatment can have substantial systemic toxicity and while they might provide some short-term efficacy, they are rarely curative in all patients - thus, there is a critical need for new treatments with durable responses and better approaches to prevention. Cancer immunotherapy has made major breakthroughs in the last decade and is likely to have a greater impact in the future. Our Cancer Immunology Training Program (CITP) seeks to train the spectrum of basic to applied and predoctoral to postdoctoral clinical fellows and young scientists to carry out the next generation of cutting-edge research, within the ideally suited, dynamic environment of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine and the UPMC Hillman Cancer Center.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cancer Immunology Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Existing interventions for peripheral arterial vascular injury or peripheral arterial atherosclerosis, including autologous, synthetic, or primary cell-based tissue engineered vascular grafts (TEVGs), are insufficient to address a significant subset of patients requiring immediate intervention due lack of suitable vessel availability, potential for infection, a long patient wait-time (~23 days), or dysfunctional endothelium leading to thrombus formation. Human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) provide a unique, unlimited cell source to produce TEVGs of comparable quantity over a large scale, and can be modified genetically to produce hypoimmunogenic “universal” cells which would be suitable for safe transplant into any patient recipient. This project details our current and future efforts to extensively validate the hypoimmunogenic nature of endothelial cells (ECs) derived from genetically modified hiPSCs, and storage potential of acellular, endothelialized hiPSC-TEVGs so as to be readily available to patients in need, through both in vitro assays and in vivo implantation into a humanized rat model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung transplantation is a vital therapeutic option for select individuals with end-stage lung disease, however patient outcomes lag behind other solid organ transplants. The major early complication, primary graft dysfunction (PGD), is acute lung injury occurring in the first 3-days after transplant. This proposal seeks to establish a Lung Transplant Consortia Clinical Center between Pittsburgh, UCSF and Hopkins to investigate the impact of severe PGD on major clinical outcomes and airway inflammation in the first-year after transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Vertigo/disequilibrium, frequent medical complaints for adults, are related to balance problems and falls which negatively impact health and quality of life. There is no universally effective therapy to address these persistent abnormal self-motion perceptions which result in reduced participation in typical life activities. This project will develop novel approaches to rehabilitation, specifically addressing the need for a deeper understanding of self-motion perception and how self-motion perception can be adapted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) module important physiological processes, such as vision, taste, blood pressure regulation, immune response, mood control and so on and are the targets of more than 30% of all therapeutic drugs. I propose to visualize how a key regulatory protein, arrestin, interacts with GPCRs at near-atomic resolution using cryo-electron microscopy. Structural details of various GPCR−arrestin complexes will help dissect the mechanism of GPCR function and guide the design of drugs targeting this specific pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative Poor Black and Hispanic preterm infants often receive care in newborn intensive care units (NICUs) in safety net hospitals. These NICUs tend to have worse performance than those in better resourced hospitals. However, even among safety net NICUs, quality varies widely. We don’t know why some of these safety net NICUs perform well while others are more challenged. In this study, we will address this knowledge gap by bringing a large group of these NICUs together to work together on a common problem area and using this intervention to study what makes these NICUs perform differently from one another. We plan to leverage this joint effort for future collaboration among safety net NICUs.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The influence of positive natural selection in shaping the genomes of southern African populations is largely unknown. In this study, using the most appropriate and accurate statistical method, we will scan large-scale whole genome sequencing datasets (> 1000 individuals from ~5 populations) for signals of positive natural selection and characterize the functional importance of identified signals. Ultimately, we aim to detect novel positive selection signals that could have a potential impact on various human phenotypes in a largely understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: The quest for a drug that can halt bone loss and subsequent skeletal fragility in the aging population continues. We discovered that inhibition of a protein called IL-17ra in the cells that destroy bone (osteoclasts) in osteoporotic patients led to increased bone mass in small animals. Here we proposed to validate our discovery in aging versus traumatic bone injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although there have been advances in antiretroviral treatment (ART) for HIV, adolescents and young adults living with HIV (AHIV) continue to have disparate HIV outcomes particularly viral suppression (VS), when compared to other populations likely related to multi-layered challenges (social determinants, cognitive development), system, and biomedical challenges including the reliance on oral ART as the only choice for HIV treatment. Given that approximately 1/3 of AHIV despite being in care fail to attain or sustain VS with resultant individual and public health risk, there is a need to develop real-world implementable interventions that can improve their virologic outcomes. The Strategies to AchieVe Viral Suppression for Youth with HIV (SAVVY) Study aims to 1) optimize personal ART choice by using the HIV-ASSIST clinical program to inform CHOICE counseling regarding an AHIV's preferred approach, including the possibility of long-acting injectable ART (LAI- ART); 2) facilitate access to their preferred choice through deploying a focused team to navigate barriers to attaining LAI-ART; and 3) decipher and address the patient, provider, and systemic barriers to the uptake and routinization of LAI-ART among AHIV by applying an implementation science framework and assessing cost- effectiveness providing critical data to support comprehensive approaches to optimizing ART and VS for AHIV, a key population identified in the Ending the HIV Epidemic in the United States Initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), the deadliest form of stroke, causes high rates of death and long-term disability worldwide. This proposal investigates the biological functions of fibroblast-derived laminin in blood- brain barrier (BBB) repair and fibroblast biology after ICH. Successful completion of this proposal will: (1) elucidate the fundamental roles of fibroblast-derived laminin in BBB repair and fibroblast biology after ICH; and (2) identify the receptors that mediate these effects on endothelial cells and fibroblasts, which will provide new molecular targets with therapeutic potential and promote the development of innovative and effective treatments for ICH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narratives (3 sentences) Shared decision making (SDM) is a patient-centered process in which patients and providers work together to make decisions and select tests, treatments, and care plans based on evidence that balances risks with patient preferences and values. Here we will evaluate the implementation of Coach McLungsSM, a virtual evidence- based asthma SDM intervention integrated into the electronic medical record, into primary care practices across Atrium Health, a large healthcare system. After convening a Stakeholder Advisory Committee composed of researchers, patients, and stakeholders expert in implementation science and asthma advocacy, we will implement and evaluate the Coach McLungsSM SDM intervention into primary care practices where providers will be trained in SDM communication and use of Coach McLungsSM to evaluate asthma outcomes and ways to improve practice implementation.

PHR: Project Narrative There is a great need to reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing by dentists. PHR: The proposed research is highly relevant to public health, reflecting the fact that psychological stress is a major risk factor for hypertension and cardiovascular disease. This proposal investigates novel signaling mechanisms that induce both morphological and functional transformations of the neuronal circuitry in the hypothalamus, a brain region that plays a central role in orchestrating cardiovascular responses to stress. The long-term goal of our studies is to identify novel therapeutic targets for treating hypertension associated with psychological stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We discovered the important role of TFEB, the master transcription factor of autophagy and lysosome biogenesis, in host defense response to coronavirus infection. We developed small molecule E3 ligase subunit DCAF7 inhibitor to maintain TFEB protein levels, activate lysosome and enhance HCoV clearance both in cellular models and in K18-hACE2 SARS-CoV-2 mouse model. We propose that this novel strategy of activating lysosome to boost host defense can serve as an off-the-shelf therapy for the next coronavirus pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal examines a potential link between a cytoplasmic ribonucleoprotein granule, known as the Processing-body, and the microtubule network of eukaryotic cells. The experiments herein will test whether the process of tubulin autoregulation occurs within these granules and may therefore provide valuable insight into this form of regulation. This process has been studied for more than forty years but the machinery responsible for the mRNA degradation had not been identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of the proposed project is to design, develop, and optimize a new class of dual precision therapeutics that are the first to be pumped across the restrictive vascular endothelial cell barrier to achieve high concentrations exclusively inside lung tissue where they can comprehensively block TGF-β, a key signaling cytokine driving inflammation and fibrosis. This lung precision delivery system with active tissue penetration exhibits extraordinary promise at very safe, ultra-low doses and will be rigorously tested in rodent pneumonitis and fibrosis models. It is expected to boost therapeutic potency and efficacy in treating multiple lethal lung diseases that currently lack adequate therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

It will also advance our understanding of bladder cancer biology with re- spect to mechanisms of treatment resistance, ultimately leading to improvements in bladder cancer therapy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NCI’s Scientific Priori- ties that pertains to treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risk-reducing medications such as tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors can reduce breast cancer risk among survivors of childhood and adolescent cancer but are not currently standard care for these high-risk women. By using simulation modeling and longitudinal observational data, we will provide estimates of the clinical benefits and harms of risk-reducing medications among high-risk survivors to inform follow-up care guidelines and discussions. This work will reduce morbidity and improve care for survivors by broadening the focus of survivorship care to include primary prevention alongside screening and creating resources that can facilitate care discussions between survivors and care-providers about breast cancer prevention and early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diverse cancers can now be treated by modulating the immune system to recognize and destroy tumor cells; however, only subsets of patients respond to such immunotherapies and tumors often progress despite these efforts. I propose to apply a coupled set of cutting-edge, next-generation in vitro and in vivo methodologies to define the role of somatic mutations in response to cancer immunotherapies in human gastrointestinal cancers. My data will elucidate fundamental biological principles of the tumor-immune interaction, providing a mechanistic framework to inform immunotherapeutic strategies and targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the profound prevalence of asthma, we do not yet have a defined nutritional approach to support disease management. This research will elucidate a novel relationship between how diet effects asthma symptoms and lung function through altering the way our cells use energy. The short-term impact is new fundamental knowledge on the connection between diet, cellular energetics and asthma, while the long- term impact will open new lines of research aimed at using nutrition to improve the treatment and management of asthma, which may elevate patient care and quality of life for individuals with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social isolation is common among young adults with cancer, which can compromise their psychosocial health. We propose to optimize an evidence-based social connectedness intervention for young adults with cancer and conduct a randomized controlled trial to test its efficacy to improve psychosocial health in this population. This research leverages a highly scalable behavioral intervention to address the unmet psychosocial needs of young adults with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major impediment to developing effective therapeutics after spinal cord injury and other neurological disorders is that therapeutics that target one cell type may be contraindicated for another cell type, thereby masking any potential beneficial effects. In this proposal, we will address this issue by utilizing single-cell transcriptomics and proteomics data of the spinal cord injury site to bioinformatically identify compounds that are predicted to reverse the disease phenotype in a cell-type and cell-state-specific manner. These compounds will be targeted to specific cell types using nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems that minimize off-target effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American men are immensely affected by prostate cancer, often diagnosed at an earlier age and with advanced disease. Our work has established a link between metabolic rewiring and defects in the DNA damage response that drives biological disparities in African American prostate cancer patients. Findings from this study will identify metabolic underpinnings and provide a new avenue for biomarker development and targeted cancer therapeutics for African American men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to expand the NHGRI Genomic Data Science Analysis, Visualization, and Informatics Lab-space (AnVIL) platform for genomics and biomedical research. The research enabled by this platform will accelerate our understanding of the genetic components of human health and disease as well as accelerate progress towards implementing genomic knowledge in medical practice supported by the AnVIL Clinical Resource (ACR). This will be accomplished through improvements to the core AnVIL platform for scalability, usability, and interoperability, the addition of several new scientiﬁc services to make researchers more eﬃcient, and a multi-faceted approach to training and outreach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The genomes of most organisms, including humans, harbor a variety of so-called selfish genetic elements that enhance their own transmission by subverting normal reproduction and, in doing so, often contribute to genome evolution, genome instability, mutation, and host infertility. We will study the genetics, molecular mechanisms, and genomic consequences of a selfish meiotic drive element that distorts fair Mendelian transmission of sex chromosomes by killing non- carrier spermatids during spermatogenesis and biasing progeny sex ratios. We will determine how this meiotic drive system has given rise to a network of new genes and regulatory interactions, shaped the evolution of the sex chromosomes, and influenced speciation, the process by which one species split into two reproductively incompatible descendant species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding the pathophysiological changes to cerebral vessels in HIV-associated tuberculous meningitis so as to understand the mechanism underlying stroke development and long-term neurological disability. Once the mechanism leading to strokes in TBM is understood, there is the protentional for the development of targeted interventions to reduce the incidence of strokes in HIV-associated tuberculous meningitis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NINDS’ mission pertaining to the reduction of long-term neurological disability in neuroinfections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative For many patients with cancer, immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) have transformed the course of their diseases; however, only a small subset of patients with breast cancer have benefited from this therapy, in part because of high levels of immunosuppression imposed by myeloid cells in the patient’s tumor. This proposal will determine how treatment with entinostat, an epigenetic modulating drug and inhibitor of histone deacetylase, improves the response to ICIs in metastatic breast cancer via its effects on myeloid immunosuppression and on other suppressive immune cells, tested in mouse models and in samples from breast cancer patients in our clinical trial NCI-9844. The study will reveal new biomarkers and targets for therapy, assisted by a mathematical model that will decipher the complex and collective mechanisms of altered suppression, and predict tumor response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The pathological changes in excitation-contraction-bioenergetics coupling contribute to malignant ventricular arrhythmias, both in genetic arrhythmia syndromes and acquired cardiac disease. These studies aim to identify specific molecular targets to reduce the damaging influence of defective calcium signaling on mitochondrial function, and conversely improve mitochondria electron transport to restore aberrant calcium handling. Interruption of the vicious cycle of mitochondria dysfunction and defective intracellular calcium homeostasis is thought have a significant therapeutic potential, reducing arrhythmogenesis and improving contractile function of the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing spread of antibiotic resistance has led to an urgent need for new treatments to bacterial infections. While the treatment of bacterial infections with their viruses, bacteriophages, has enormous potential, it is held back by the high levels of specificity of phages for bacterial strains. Here, I will develop a phage therapy treatment that is able to overcome existing bacterial defense mechanisms, one of the key factors driving specificity and thus holding back this therapeutic option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  The proposed research will examine how Bone Morphogenic Protein Receptor1α regulates balance of TR and exTR cell subsets to prevent autoimmune diseases. We will investigate how BMP\BMPR1α signaling operates in vivo to regulate tissue tolerance and inflammation.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Adolescents and young adults with HIV (AYWH) aged 15-24 years are the fastest-growing population of people living with HIV worldwide. AYWH have worse outcomes along the HIV continuum of care than adults with HIV; HIV/AIDS is the second leading cause of mortality and the fourth leading cause of disability among AYWH worldwide. This study will develop an adolescent-tailored, mobile health (mHealth) intervention to improve retention in care and thus has the potential to improve AIDS-related mortality and morbidity among AYWH and decrease new onward transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogens in the Rickettsia genus cause an array of potentially fatal arthropod-borne vascular diseases in humans, but their infection mechanisms are poorly understood. The goal of this project is to investigate how two Rickettsia surface or secreted proteins of unknown function promote infection of host cells. Knowledge from this work will improve our understanding of Rickettsia pathogenesis and directly inform the development of diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines for these pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a kidney disease that results from an autoimmune response against the kidney glomeruli. Recently, HTRA1 has been identified as a new antigen in MN. Currently, little is known about the mechanisms by which HTRA1 may trigger autoimmune responses in this disease. This proposal will employ an integrated approach of proteomics and animal studies to characterize HTRA1 epitopes, which might be involved in MN development. The study should extend and expand insights regarding the disease mechanisms of HTRA1- associated MN, as well as establishing a foundation to develop novel peptide-based therapies for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The chimeric antigen receptor T cells (CAR-Ts) is a novel therapeutic strategy that uses the patient’s own T cells to kill the tumor cells. This approach has changed the treatment landscape of B-cell malignancies however a significant percentage of patients with these diseases unfortunately relapse after CARTs infusion with limited effective treatment options available to them. Here, we propose the first in human clinical trial with in-house manufactured CAR-Ts targeting three proteins at the same time in patients with B-cell tumors with the goal of improving over the results of single antigen CAR-Ts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survivors of childhood cancer require life-long healthcare to improve quality of life and health outcomes; yet, there are crucial gaps in our understanding of the modifiable factors that create and perpetuate disparities in healthcare among childhood cancer survivors in the Medicaid system. This study will use qualitative and survey research methods to systematically assess survivor experience of care in the Medicaid system and determine sources of disparities affecting care experience among adult survivors of childhood cancer. This study will inform future policies and interventions concerning the modifiable factors that can improve equity in healthcare for adult Medicaid beneficiaries with a history of childhood cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research evaluates immunogenicity of the dengue virus vaccine vaccine CYD-TDV in subjects with pre-existing dengue virus serotype 1 immunity. This knowledge is critical to understanding immune determinants of vaccine efficacy and is critical evaluation and improvement of this vaccine intended to control this globally important disease. The results of this project are highly and directly relevant to the NIH's mission fostering innovative research strategies to reduce the burden of illness and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Males and females differ with respect to complement-mediated innate immunity and susceptibility to obesity- induced pathophysiology in multiple tissues, including the brain. These experiments will determine whether sexually dimorphic regulation of complement underlies differential vulnerability to neuroinflammation in mice with dietary obesity. We will use state-of-the-art methodology, including machine learning-based reconstruction of glia in cleared brains, to generate a comprehensive topographical map of neuroimmune responses to chronic overnutrition and elucidate the role of complement in these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Epigenetic alteration is one hallmark for aging and age-related diseases, which are the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the general public health. Three-dimensional (3D) enhancer regulation is not understood in aging and its interplay with inflammation is unclear. The proposed research will unveil the cell type-specific mechanisms of 3D enhancer regulation in different contexts of aging and age-related disease and shed light on potential epigenetic therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: This competitive renewal application aims to define genetic mechanisms underlying IgA nephropathy and IgA vasculitis with nephritis, two related conditions that contribute to kidney failure worldwide. The proposal integrates multi-phenotype genome-wide association studies, epigenetic analysis of IgA+ cells, focused gene perturbation experiments in IgA+ cells, studies of human knockouts in the Pakistan Genomic Resource, and clinical studies in prospective cohorts. These studies aim to identify new targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osseointegrated dental implants have become a clinical standard for replacing missing teeth and are now an important routine component of dental practice. Due to its popularity, the presence of implant complications is rising, making it challenging to sustain implants in the long term. We propose to develop an innovative anti- bacterial adhesion and anti-inflammatory dental implant system that prevents implant failure while promoting long-term stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE The accumulation of dental plaque into stable, long-range biofilms at the gingival margin is implicated in reversible gingivitis, which may progress to chronic periodontitis. However, the specific cells and molecular interactions that govern dental plaque structure are not well known. The knowledge gained from the research proposed here will comprise a holistic understanding of oral community assembly processes and physical structure across spatial scales and may identify new paradigms for intervening in the progression of dental plaque-mediated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Given the prospect to develop effective AD therapies via current therapeutic strategies seems limited at this point, in this application we propose to develop a new class of AD drugs that target previously unrecognized pathways in AD drug development. We expect to identify a lead AD drug to stop or slow down the progression of AD in a manner independent of Aβ or tau aggregation that needs to be further investigated in clinical trials. Successful completion of our study will have an important positive impact because currently available drugs only offer temporary relief from the symptoms of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE Periodontal disease is affects an estimated 40% of US adults and remains a significant challenge to diagnose at early stages. The work proposed here will foster a better understanding of the structural features of plaque biofilms that are involved in the early initiation of periodontal disease and may foster the development of new strategies to monitor and treat and prevent these diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Giardia lamblia, a waterborne human parasite that inflicts 1.2 million people annually worldwide, is classified as a category B bioterrorism organism and also is included in Neglected Diseases Initiative by World Health Organization. The goal of this project is to develop PTLS-209, a potent MetAP2 inhibitor with very low oral bioavailability, as a safe and effective antigiardiasis drug, particularly resistant strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- OVERALL While Delaware has high quality healthcare compared to other states, Delaware still has significant inequities in health and healthcare for non-White Delawareans; further, Delaware lags behind other states in a number of areas, including drug deaths, obesity, high preventable hospitalization rates, multiple chronic conditions and cancer. As such, the overarching goal for the continuation of the ACCEL CTR Program is to create a unified Delaware Clinical and Translational Research Community (inclusive of investigators and community members) that breaks down existing barriers, capitalizes on the unique strengths of its partners to establish infrastructure and accelerates the creation of equitable solutions that improve the health of all Delawareans and all Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will assess the impact of a novel breastfeeding support intervention (“telelactation”), delivered via video calls on personal devices including mobile phones and tablets. The goal of this intervention is to increase access to International Board Certified Lactation Consultants to improve, and reduce disparities in, breastfeeding rates. By implementing a “siteless” randomized controlled trial that recruits participants through a popular pregnancy tracker mobile phone application, this study will efficiently recruit a national sample of 2400 diverse women to 1) provide evidence on the effectiveness of a widely available, yet understudied, service and 2) leverage technology to promote one of the most widely recommended health behaviors to improve children’s health and to reduce disparities in key maternal and child health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dorsal anterior cingulate cortex, nucleus accumbens, and amygdala are regions of the human brain that are reciprocally connected in several major neural circuit loops. These brain regions serve as key nodes within the brain’s reward circuitry, and also play critical regulatory roles in mediating anxiety and fear-related behaviors. In this application, we will generate spatial transcriptomic maps in these human brain regions. This data will be used to better understand the molecular correlates of substance use and comorbid neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research has public health significance because atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia and expected to double in prevalence in the next decade as the population ages. “Real-world evidence” from electronic health record data displayed in personalized decision-aid visualizations can enable patients and providers to choose together the optimal treatments for symptom reduction. Our proposal addresses NINR's key areas of “Symptom Science: Promoting Personalized Health Strategies” and “Promoting Innovation: Technology to Improve Health” by leveraging innovative technologies to deliver personalized interventions that reduce symptom burden and improve quality of life for individuals with chronic conditions. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This secondary data analysis leverages data from an Alzheimer’s Disease Initiative funded Phase III randomized clinical trial examining benefits of transcranial direct current stimulation paired with cognitive training to remediate age-related cognitive decline and alter trajectories toward Alzheimer’s disease. Using advanced neuroimaging-derived computational modeling and artificial intelligence-based machine learning methods, the study will determine the mechanisms underlying response vs. non-response to treatment in older adults and precision dosing parameters for optimizing treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging remains the most significant risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and has recently been linked to gastrointestinal health of older people. Our study will examine connections between intestinal and brain inflammation, in mouse models of aging and AD, to determine how these connections affect aging-related cognitive decline and AD pathology. The proposed studies will determine whether increased gut permeability due to loss of the intestine’s protective mucus barrier accelerates aging-related cognitive decline and AD, and whether a new probiotic therapy, LpD3-5, can reverse these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a multifactorial and complex neurodegenerative disorder that involves numerous genetic, epigenetic and environmental factors. In this proposal, we will study the function of a novel AD risk factor that we recently identified in order to understand how this gene functions together with other genetic factors that contribute to disease pathogenesis. This will lead to a deeper mechanistic understanding of AD and potentially to identification of novel targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The long-term objective of this proposal is to develop first-in-class, best-in-class noncoding RNA-based gene therapeutics with a novel mechanism of action, to improve standard of care for a broad range of blood and vascular diseases with unmet clinical need: management of thrombotic risk (blood clots), and management of bleeding disorders including bleeding caused by antithrombotic drugs. We have established for the first time a unique platform system of non-integrative, temporally controlled, tunable gene therapeutic reprogramming of blood platelets (the cells responsible for clot formation) and their parent cells megakaryocytes, which we have found is naturally selective for the megakaryocyte / platelet lineage without affecting other cell types, and which we have demonstrated yields strong antithrombotic and antibleeding therapeutic benefit. In this proposal, we will use mouse models of thrombosis and bleeding, including models of acquired and inherited bleeding disorders, to select novel RNA drug formulations with the strongest therapeutic benefits with limited risk of deleterious side effects, and we will determine efficiencies of different administration routes, which together will firmly set the stage to advance preclinical development of these novel antiplatelet drugs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Tet enzymes are epigenetic modifiers. They are highly expressed in embryonic stem cells and during development, particularly in the neural lineage. They promote DNA demethylation to regulate gene expression. Dysregulation or mutations of Tet enzymes have been linked to human craniofacial and neurodevelopmental disorders and many cancers. This proposal studies how various enzymatic activities of Tets regulate neural stem cell biology. Findings will broaden our knowledge of the epigenetic regulation of neural stem cells and nervous system development. This will have implications in identifying therapeutic targets for treatment of neurodevelopmental disorders as well as enhancing applications of neural stem cells for clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Narrative Due to a genetically induced imbalance in salt and water transport in cystic fibrosis (CF) lungs, mucus is dehydrated and the lungs fail to eradicate bacteria, leaving the airways prone to chronic infection and inflammation that ultimately destroy the lung. In this application, we propose to develop peptide-based therapies that can shift the lung’s immune balance to efficiently clear bacteria from the lung.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: It is the goal of my laboratory, the VA/CU Biomechatronics Development Laboratory and I to innovate devices, interfaces, algorithms, and systems in the field of limb prosthetics to positively impact the lives of persons and veterans with limb loss. The care of Veterans with upper limb amputation requires a highly individualized approach. Due to the severity of impairment caused by upper-limb amputation, upper-limb prosthetics research and development is of particular significance to US veterans with upper-limb loss. Each Veteran brings unique needs to the clinic including level of amputation, lifestyle, personal experience, and other medical indicators making quality-of-life a primary driver of care. In our field of prosthetic care delivery, prosthetists and occupational therapists collaborate with each veteran to provide personalized solutions with the commercially available prosthetic componentry and technologies. Often, the bottleneck is the lack readily sourced clinically sound and relevant prosthetic components with which to provide an optimal prosthetic solution.

PHR: Project Narrative: The Research Education Program on Microbes, Infections and Cancer (REPMIC) within the University of Puerto Rico Comprehensive Cancer Center will be the first research training program in Puerto Rico focused on recruiting underserved and minority college graduates to participate in a 9-month postbaccalaureate program designed to provide them with hands-on research experiences within the field of microbes, infections and cancer. Educational activities will be provided to help them apply and be successful in a Ph.D. program and/or in a health professions degree program. REPMIC will contribute to the next generation of cancer and infectious disease researchers and the diversification of the biomedical and public health research workforce.

PHR: Project Narrative For early diagnosis of potentially life-threatening bacteremia and combating antibacterial resistance, we propose to develop an integrated molecular and single-cell detection platform that can rapidly identify the causative bacteria and promptly test the susceptibilities of the identified bacteria against various antibacterial agents. Timely diagnosis of bacteremia with the proposed platform can transform acute-care clinicians’ ability to treat patients with appropriate drugs, thus improving treatment outcome and curtailing the emergence of antibacterial resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The number of cancer survivors with cardiovascular risks has increased substantially and CVD mortality has surpassed cancer mortality for many cancer sites. Cancer survivors often become disconnected from their primary care providers during cancer treatment and forego necessary chronic disease care. This study tests health system strategies to improve primary care connection during cancer treatment and has potential to impact implementation strategies used throughout U.S. health systems to reduce cardiovascular risks for cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health as we will define metabolic mechanisms involving in locus coeruleus (LC) neuron death. LC neuron dysfunction and degeneration are among the earliest neuropathological events in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD). A fuller understanding of mechanisms involved in LC vulnerability in brain health and disease will establish a foundation for the development of new therapeutics for a broad range of diseases including AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative -- Non-invasive, continuous blood pressure monitoring for prenatal maternal health The goal of this proposal is development of a non-invasive device that is comfortable, low-cost and easy to use in order to monitor the blood pressure and changes in the pulse waveform shape of pregnant women. Close surveillance of women at risk of developing complications from hypertensive disorders of pregnancy potentially enables timely diagnosis and treatment before they develop significant maternal and neonatal morbidities related to hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, such as pre-eclampsia. This project is based on technology invented in Prof. Zhenan Bao’s lab at Stanford University and a fully-functional prototype device, and includes prospective data collection, usability and validation studies with women at different stages of pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenetics is a discipline that will help us to understand how inherited gene activity, based on past environmental exposures, contributes to cancer. The purpose of this study is to identify and characterize epigenetic marks that contribute to the excess risk of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance in African Americans, which is a precursor to multiple myeloma. The knowledge gained from this study may help us to understand the disparate trends of these plasma cell proliferative disorders by race as well as to predict, classify and intervene more effectively in high-risk populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative There is evidence to support positive multisensory exposures in the NICU (such as skin-to-skin, holding, and language exposure), but these interventions are not applied in a consistent manner, reducing their benefit to high-risk infants. The critical next step is to address knowledge gaps about the effects of daily, evidence- based, positive, and multisensory interventions provided to very preterm infants throughout the duration of NICU hospitalization, on brain development during an important period of time. This is important to public health as it impacts millions of infants and families worldwide, the NICU environment is a modifiable factor, and there is high demand for interventions that can change the experience of NICU hospitalization, improve early parent-child relationships, and optimize developmental outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When men who have sex with men use alcohol excessively, they experience greater risk of HIV infection; they may also have reduced adherence to and less retention in pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) programs. A brief alcohol intervention, provided over about six weeks, may substantially reduce alcohol use among men who have sex with men. This trial will be conducted in Vietnam to assess the impact of the brief alcohol intervention on retention in a PrEP program and adherence to PrEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of death in the United States, with myocarditis contributing to 42% of all sudden deaths in young adults annually, yet the relationship between viral infection and fatal arrhythmias is unknown. Our research reveals that cardiac cellular junctional structures, essential for normal electrical activity in the heart, are targeted during infection to facilitate viral replication and spread. This research will identify mechanisms underlying viral sudden cardiac death and mechanisms of arrhythmogenic ion channel remodeling, and will reveal therapeutic targets applicable not just to myocarditis, but also to the broad array of heart diseases involving deadly disruption of cardiac intercellular communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Dysregulation of molecular machinery and molecular pathways that establish precise circuit connections and specific subtype identity of cerebral cortex projection neurons disrupts sensation, skilled movement, social behaviors, and high-level cognition, and plays central roles in neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases. Axonal growth cones are semi-autonomous, subcellular compartments at tips of extending axons that rapidly integrate extracellular signals to control axon growth, developmental guidance to targets, maturation into correct functional synapses, and maintenance of appropriate and healthy neural circuits. Vast distances (103- 105 cell body diameters) separate growth cones from their nucleus-containing somata, strongly suggesting that local, subtype-specific growth cone proteins underlie proper growth cone function, and motivating this project’s integration of novel subcellular isolation approaches with ultra-low-input proteomics via state-of-the-art mass spectrometry to identify key proteins regulating axonal navigation of subtype-specific projection neurons in mouse cerebral cortex during development, and in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most common brain malignancy in adults and is universally lethal, demonstrating a desperate need for more efficacious therapies. Poor survival outcomes are attributed to tumor recurrence, which is believed to arise from a chemo- and radioresistant, highly plastic population of glioblastoma stem cells. In this proposal we explore a completely novel function for EYA2 in centrosome biology and the molecular mechanism by which it regulates proliferation and mitotic spindle formation in GBM, presenting a novel potential therapeutic target for the disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Traumatic spinal cord injury is a devastating acquired disorder leading to permanent functional deficits, including loss of voluntary movement control due to damage and lack of repair of corticospinal neurons, the subtype of cortical projection neurons that normally connect the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord via segmentally-specific, exceptionally long circuitry that can extend up to a meter in humans– up to 100,000 times as long as the “cell body” size. The inability of corticospinal neurons to re-generate is in stark contrast with their ability to generate precise circuitry during development, during which axonal growth cones, subcompartments at the ends of these exceptionally long growing axons, respond to their environment relatively independently and are thus responsible for axonal guidance, and establishment and maintenance of functional synapses and functional circuitry. Using novel approaches to study cellular subcompartments of these vastly “polarized” neurons, I will investigate cell body- and growth cone-localized RNA and protein molecular machinery and thus local mechanisms responsible for executing developmental and treatment-enabled regenerative growth of corticospinal neurons, toward future development of targeted therapies for people with disability from spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) is one of the most common AIDS-associated malignancies. This cancer is known to be caused by Kaposi’s sarcoma herpes virus (KSHV). Despite years of the progress on our knowledge of how the virus causes this cancer, an outstanding paradox still remains unresolved. The viral gene, vGPCR, has been known to be necessary and sufficient for KS tumor development. However, vGPCR is produced in the lytic stage cells that destined to die to produce more virus particles. In this study, we aim to tackle the provocative question, how can vGPCR, a lytic viral gene expressed in cells destined to die, can cause cancer? To address this decades-long conundrum, we have development novel animal models and an engineered artificial skin platform. Our study will identify a totally new way of cancer initiation, advance our understanding of KS tumor development, and help to design novel anti-KS therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Folic acid (FA) supplementation is an effective modifier of neural tube defect (NTDs) prevalence, although a significant proportion of NTD cases are FA resistant. We hypothesize that some FA-resistant NTDs may be prevented by intervention with glycine. Discerning the mechanisms underlying the beneficial effects and relating them to known human NTD gene variants may enable us to expand effective intervention strategies to prevent previously unpreventable NTDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalized children who develop a venous thromboembolism (VTE), a blood clot in the deep veins or pulmonary vasculature, have an increased risk of morbidity from long term pain and venous insufficiency, as well as increased mortality. The current lack of established methods for assessing VTE risk or applying safe and effective VTE prevention strategies as a standard component of hospital admission for children has led to the continuously increasing incidence of hospital-acquired VTE. Completing the aims of this study will contribute to the NIH mission to apply scientific knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life and reduce illness and disability in children through establishing a validated pediatric VTE risk assessment model, identifying barriers to hospital staff implementing risk models and determining the incidence and characterization of bleeding in hospitalized children to create safe thromboprophylaxis methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Natural medicinal compounds (NMC) such as curcumin from turmeric, acemannan from aloe vera and essential nutrients such as Vitamin D3 can improve healing of bone disorders. The objective of this research is to test our central hypothesis, which is, NMC loaded doped CaP-based porous 3D printed scaffolds can significantly enhance osteogenic and angiogenic properties in vivo. Our long-range goal is to demonstrate clinically relevant patient matched, doped CaP or CaP– polymer scaffolds with NMCs that will substitute autologous bone. NMCs can also replace GFs and proteins for faster healing, and work on other materials such as titanium for applications in load-bearing or non load-bearing implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations that accumulate throughout the life cycle can result in cancer, infertility, and aging. This proposal will characterize how multicellular organisms control genome structure and development in order to reduce the impact of new mutations, focusing on plant transposons because it is possible to follow the spread of transposon-mediated mutations soon after they arise. The goal is to establish general principles that limit the persistence of mutations in diverse species, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is clear that microbial diversity is important to human health, the mechanisms that underpin why remain elusive. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The formation of the distal air sacs (alveolarization) requires the development of blood vessels by the process of angiogenesis. Disruption of angiogenesis and alveolarization in infants causes bronchopulmonary dysplasia, the most common complication of premature birth. Our studies will identify new pathways that direct angiogenesis in the developing lung, and explore new therapeutic strategies to promote lung growth by enhancing angiogenesis, an approach that may be applicable to diseases affecting both infants and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the fourth leading cause of death worldwide and current therapy only treats symptoms but cannot stop progression of this debilitating disease. We have found evidence that vascular dysfunction leads the development of the type of lung destruction that is found in COPD. In this proposal, we aim to uncover new therapies targeting the vascular impairments causing the disease state of COPD in the hopes of improving the lives of millions of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This application proposes a Kidney Precision Medicine Project Tissue Interrogation Site (TIS) for the mapping of a diverse set of acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) biopsies and subsequent construction of detailed multiomic molecular atlases. Atlases will be generated using an innovative and state-of-the-art multimodal imaging pipeline consisting of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization imaging mass spectrometry, autofluorescence, and stained microscopy. Spatial transcriptomics and proteomics will be used for cross-modal biological validation of the imaging data, and advanced data analysis strategies will reveal disease state/transition/class-specific biomarkers, provide insight into key molecular pathways that characterize heterogenous tissue regions, and explore potential disease subgroups; all across a diverse patient cohort with the objective of identifying specific biomarkers of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WiNCORP represents a collaborative effort among three healthcare systems that provide oncology care to a predominantly rural population in Wisconsin, the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, Northeastern Iowa, and Southeastern Minnesota. Member sites have developed multidisciplinary care teams and research staff to accrue numerous patients to NCI-sponsored trials and encourage collaboration through participation in regional research networks and affiliations with academic medical centers. WiNCORP will continue to provide patient access to NCI-sponsored clinical trials and influence oncology practice patterns in the region through the conduct and publication of cancer care delivery research (CCDR) projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop a new type of mathematical model, which could be used in any country in Sub-Saharan Africa to identify geographic disparities in the opportunity for people living with HIV (PLHIV) to access antiretroviral treatment (ART), and then to determine optimal strategies for reducing these disparities. We will demonstrate the utility of the model by analyzing a series of datasets from Malawi, a low-income country with one of the most severe HIV epidemics in the world. In doing so we will help advance UNAIDS’ 2021-2026 global strategy, which emphasizes the application of novel, data-driven approaches for achieving a more equitable access to HIV interventions.

PHR: Understanding the brain processes underlying alcohol use and misuse are essential for the development of effective treatments for alcohol use disorder or AUD. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) affects as many 57% of critically ill children, with mortality rates as high 67% among those infected. Infectious outcomes are affected by the host immune response and timely, effective antibiotic strategies; however the modification of antibiotic management strategies as a function of both MODS and host immune paralysis (IP) are key knowledge gaps in pediatric MODS. By leveraging the PARADIGM study infrastructure (R01HD095976), the objectives of this application are to characterize the variability of concentrations for the antibiotics most commonly used in pediatric MODS; to investigate the relationships between antibiotic target attainment and outcomes in pediatric MODS with and without IP; to develop model-based dosing approaches that rapidly achieve and maintain target antibiotic concentrations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a severe infection defined by a dysregulated immune response and organ dysfunction that causes significant morbidity and mortality worldwide, despite decades of research. Necroinflammatory cell death is an important mechanism in the initiation of the innate immune and organ dysfunction in sepsis. This project aims to evaluate novel necroinflammatory cell death biomarkers in early sepsis and track their change, with the ultimate goal of establishing necroinflammatory subphenotypes in sepsis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: People with multiple sclerosis (MS) commonly experience problems with cognitive function, but current assessment methods only provide a “snapshot” of cognition and fail to capture its true nature where it matters most, in daily life. The proposed research will examine the utility of novel mobile app-based cognitive tests to characterize changes in cognitive function, while simultaneously collecting data on important modifiable factors (e.g., physical activity, sleep, fatigue) that may impact cognitive function. Better understanding of daily variability in cognitive function, predictors of cognitive decline and the impact of cognitive dysfunction is crucial to developing treatments that can improve the functioning and health-related quality of life of people with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer incidence is expected to increase to 23.6 million by 2030 worldwide, and cancer is the leading cause of death for Asian Americans whose numbers are rapidly rising to reach 40 million by 2050. Despite instances of greater cancer-specific mortality compared to other Asians and likely limited access to high-quality care due many experiencing language barriers (~50%), very little is known about supportive care needs in Chinese-, Vietnamese-, and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers. This project will fill a critical gap in our understanding, and develop culturally relevant and scalable psychosocial resources aimed at improving the quality of life of Chinese-, Vietnamese-, and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers.
