IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal alcohol/ethanol and nicotine exposure (PEE/PNE) are common causal factors in the US and worldwide for fetal brain growth deficits, and their effects can be synergistic. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides a new method for understanding the impacts of maternal ethanol and nicotine consumption during pregnancy on the mammalian brain and microvasculature development. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burdens of human disability, in this case, due to exposure to toxins during gestation.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Disease driver genes have been identified in the past few decades, advancing both mechanistic understanding of disease and therapeutic development. However, the genetic background impacts considerably on the phenotype of a specific disease. These effects are due to genetic background and/or environmental influence on the disease driver, complicating diagnosis and proper treatment selection. Therefore, it is of utmost importance and relevance to investigate genetic background effects on disease development and progression. We now understand that genetic background effects are due to epistatic interactions that modulate disease driver function. However, common animal models are not suitable for studying this question because laboratory strains of these animals are mostly inbred and selected for laboratory use. Because they are closely related and at best represent different populations of just one species, they do not constitute high enough genetic diversity to allow identification of modulating epistasis. To circumvent this hurdle, we propose to implement various Xiphophorus fish species. These species present high inter-species phenotypical and genetic variation and harbor natural alleles that are disease associated. They offer the possibility of producing artificial inter-species hybrids, providing the unique possibility to investigate epistasis underlying diseases including cancer, metabolic disorders and aberrant disease related molecular traits. This suitability makes Xiphophorus the experimental model organism of choice to fill a knowledge gap in disease model research and to develop innovative research strategies. Xiphophorus is a genus of live-bearing freshwater fish that includes 26 species. The Xiphophorus Genetic Stock Center is a national resource center that hosts 61 pedigree lines that belong to 24 species. The goal of the XGSC is to maintain the unique features and preserve the strength of this model to be used in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We now generate so much genetic data that we no longer have the capacity to analyze it all. This has limited our ability to make new scientific discoveries and combat the ongoing pandemic. This research will develop efficient new methods for analyzing large numbers of genomes, so that we can learn about evolution and natural selection in unprecedented detail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Mammarenaviruses often cause severe diseases in humans but establish asymptomatic, lifelong infections in rodent reservoirs. We aim to identify the cellular processes that differentially regulate infectious versus defective particle production and the ecological impact of these defective viral particles on rodent reservoir fitness. This work has the potential to answer long-standing questions regarding for how zoonotic viruses, including those in the Bunyavirales order, are maintained in reservoir species in nature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because asthma is the most common chronic respiratory illness and the most common chronic childhood illness. Genetics contribute to asthma risk, although the how they affect specific cell types in asthma is not well understood, and this project will delineate genetic contributions to important subsets of asthma and determine their effects in cell types pertinent to asthma. This project is relevant to the NIH mission because it seeks knowledge about asthma with a goal of enhancing health, lengthening life and reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic factors play a major role in the etiology of breast cancer. However, little is known about the target genes for breast cancer genetic risk regions identified in recent years, and further a large fraction of heritability for this common malignancy remains unexplained. In this application, we propose a novel study to systematically search for genes associated with breast cancer risk and further evaluate whether these genes may influence racial differences in the risk of this cancer.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Alcoholism poses an enormous health and financial burden on our society. Currently, our understanding of the brain circuitries involved in alcoholism is far from complete. The successful completion of these proposed studies would result in important new information about neurons that may be involved in alcoholism, potentially creating new targets for therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The relevance of the New Mexico Minority-Underserved NCORP (MU-NCORP) lies in the deep rooted mission of our longstanding partnership of academic and community cancer providers and other community stakeholders managed through a unique statewide consortium infrastructure (UNM Comprehensive Cancer Center and the New Mexico Cancer Care Alliance) to deliver the highest quality in all aspects of cancer care (cancer screening, prevention control and cancer care delivery) to all New Mexicans with a strong focus on eradicating disparities in access, care delivery and outcomes. Our growth as an NCI Comprehensive Cancer Center with scientific programmatic focus on innovative approaches to cancer delivery and disparities research in our unique New Mexican populations in conjunction with our longstanding community partnerships through nearly 20 years of work as an MB-CCOP and now MU-NCOORP continues to support our progress in meaningful reduction in cancer burden and better understanding of barriers to care for our population. Continued team work with all academic, community oncology and tribal and other community stakeholders while serving as leaders within the NCI NCORP, CTEP and DCP with bidirectional research engagement will continue to strengthen our program and effectiveness in improving quality and length of life for New Mexicans and other minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is rare in the neonatal and pediatric population, but affected patients suffer from substantial morbidity and mortality. Currently available therapies target the imbalance of vasoconstrictive and vasodilatory endothelial signals present in most patients, but there are few modalities that address the underlying pathologic origins of disease. The research in this proposal will help lead to better understanding of disease biology as it relates to specific etiologies and stages of the disease, creating an opportunity for more focused therapies in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Survival studies show marked racial disparity effect in head and neck cancer between African Americans and Non-Latinx Whites (Whites). This project explores how key racial differences in genetic changes during the progression of HNSCC impact the expression of key immunomodulatory cytokines or ligands within the tumor microenvironment in order to escape an antitumor immune response. This molecular mapping will provide crucial insights that have significant implications for risk assessment, tumor surveillance and treatment interventions for oral cancer tumors in African American patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to elucidate the novel interaction between Nell-1, a unique osteogenic protein with proven potency for bone regeneration, and its receptor, Cntnap4, a presynaptic membrane protein that has functional association with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). We anticipate that the outcomes of the project will greatly improve our knowledge of Nell-1's function in both the skeletal and nervous system. This, in turn, may translate into the development of better treatment options for patients with craniofacial bone anomalies or neural conditions such as ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our study explores the impact of HIV and oral HPV infection on the immune response in oropharyngeal cancer. Specifically, we will examine how CD8+ T cells, essential for combating viruses and tumors, are influenced by HIV-HPV co-infection. The results aim to improve prevention, diagnosis, and treatment approaches for HPV- positive oropharyngeal cancer patients, especially those living with HIV, with broader implications for other HPV- related malignancies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New technologies are needed to address the limited availability of rehabilitation therapy as well as the suboptimal functional outcomes for people with hand impairments after stroke. This project will investigate a patient-centered approach to reinforce neuromuscular coordination and usage of the impaired limb through the use of surface- electromyography biofeedback and robot-assisted motor training. This study has the potential to combine rehabilitative and functional assistance within a mobile platform, and could close the gap between quantitative assessments of motor function and the user’s perception of performance in real-world tasks.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women in Georgia bear a disproportionate burden of the U.S. maternal health crisis with alarmingly high maternal morbidity and mortality rates. Very few studies have investigated the multifaceted ways that structural racism drives disparities in maternal morbidity and mortality for this population. The proposed mixed-methods and multi-level study aims to leverage population-level vital records and administrative data as well as physician and patient perspectives to document novel, potentially modifiable, structural associations elucidating the relationship between structural racial discrimination and severe maternal morbidity among Black women in GA that can inform future systems-level interventions.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: HE2AT Center Overall - Project Narrative The Heat and Health African Transdisciplinary Center (HE2AT Center) will generate new knowledge on the impacts of heat waves and extreme heat on clinical conditions and on people living in vulnerable urban settings, applying data sciences approaches to existing environmental and high-quality health outcomes data. Perhaps more importantly, the Center will develop and test innovative solutions for tracking heat-related conditions at a district level and for providing individualized early warnings of dangerous heat periods relevant to high-risk groups, industry and the general population. In all Center activities we will build capacity of the team and key organizations, engage with communities, government and other stakeholder, and work across the DS-I Africa Program.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nationally, sexual and reproductive health indicators lag behind those of other developed countries, with striking disparities in maternal health. Gender and sexual minorities confront disproportionate physical and mental health risks. Globally, the burden of disease and death associated with HIV, sexually transmitted infections, and maternal and infant mortality represents an urgent problem. This proposal requests continued funding for a rigorous doctoral program with an outstanding record of success in training young scholars in the methodological and analytical skills needed to conduct high-impact research on these critical public health issues.
PROJECT_TERMS: Grant;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: GSH Training Grant

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Significant advances have been made in reproductive, perinatal, and pediatric (RPP) epidemiologic research over the last several decades. However, important challenges remain to deepen our understanding of the critical periods of risk, identify determinants, elucidate mechanisms, investigate outcomes, and determine their impact on health and disease across the life course. The Training Program in Reproductive, Perinatal, and Pediatric (RPP) Life Course Epidemiology addresses this challenge by preparing the next generation of life course-oriented, cutting-edge, innovative, transdisciplinary researchers who will serve as independent investigators equipped to advance our understanding of significant RPP health research, apply cutting-edge evidence to inform clinical practice, translate science into policy action, and implement prevention strategies to improve the health of women and children across the reproductive life course.
PROJECT_TERMS: Childhood;Life course epidemiology;Perinatal;reproductive;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: The Training Program in Reproductive, Perinatal, and Pediatric Life Course Epidemiology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcoholic hepatitis is a disease of intense liver inflammation and injury caused by heavy alcohol use that can be deadly when severe. Cytokine IL17 may contribute to the development of alcoholic hepatitis by stimulating liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) to produce chemokines that drives the inflammatory response. In this study, we will explore the mechanisms of IL17-mediated LSEC activation in alcoholic hepatitis and experiment with novel ways of inhibiting IL17 production by targeting a gene regulatory element.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our work has pioneered efforts to evaluate the contribution of contact activation to the progression of vascular device-related blood clotting. Despite the use of currently available “blood thinning” drugs, which all have dose-limiting bleeding side effects, aberrant activation of the contact pathway of blood coagulation causes device failures, and contributes to significant vascular device-associated morbidity and mortality. The research will generate new knowledge supporting the development of novel anticoagulants that are significantly safer, lack dose-limiting toxicity, and cause less bleeding than current drugs while helping to identify medical conditions that could benefit from the therapeutic use of these contact activation inhibitors.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Many laboratory studies in both rodents and non-human primates consistently have shown large cognitive-enhancing effects of dopamine D1 agonists that are greater than current therapies for age-related cognitive decline such as cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine for Alzheimer’s disease. We propose to study how the mechanism of receptor functional selectivity/biased signaling may allow discovery of novel and superior drugs based on their pattern of differential activation of D1 dopamine receptor signaling pathways. The experiments are designed to lead to a highly promising compound that could translate into a novel therapeutic with profound cognitive benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias, a group of age-associated disorders characterized by progressive deterioration of brain function, affect millions of people in the US. This proposal investigates how loss of pericytic laminin leads to neurovascular dysfunction (blood brain barrier disruption, cerebral blood flow reduction, and brain influx/efflux function impairment) and neurodegeneration, and explores the underlying molecular mechanisms. Successful completion of this study will elucidate the fundamental roles of pericytic laminin in neurovascular function and neurodegeneration, and identify novel molecular targets with therapeutic potential in Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  APOE4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease, for which brain energy deficit is an event emerging in its prodromal phase. The proposed program of research addresses the role of APOE4 in regulating the energy producing system of the brain. Outcomes of this research will further the understanding of the complexities underlying APOE4-driven Alzheimer’s risks, and identify potential therapeutic targets and opportunities to prevent or delay the course of developing Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Treatments for Alzheimer's disease will likely be most eﬀective if applied before patients begin to develop symptoms of cognitive decline. But clinical trials in individuals who do not yet have any symptoms of disease can take a very long time and be very costly. This project uses common magnetic resonance imaging exams and artiﬁcial intelligence tools to detect subtle changes over time in parts of the brain where damage speciﬁcally due to Alzheimer's disease ﬁrst occurs, providing clinical trials with a faster way to determine if treatments are being eﬀective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Certain resistant forms of leukemia and lymphoma may be treated with a combination of chemotherapy and tumor-targeted immunotherapy made by modifying a patient’s own immune cells (CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy), but serious side effects including a spectrum of neurological toxicities known as ICANS and a serious inflammatory reaction known as CRS occur in a significant percentage of patients. White blood cells called monocytes secrete the signal molecules (cytokines) that initiate the inflammatory cascade leading to ICANS and CRS; therefore, giving a treatment to eliminate monocytes before CAR T-cell therapy (instead of chemotherapy) may decrease the risk of serious side effects. Actinium herein proposes a clinical trial, to be conducted at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, evaluating the use of a radioisotope-linked antibody targeting monocytes and other immune cells (CD45-targeted antibody drug conjugate, iodine 131 [131-I] apamistamab), in place of chemotherapy, to help make CAR T-cell treatment safer and more effective for patients with resistant blood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We will develop advanced machine learning approaches to combine single-cell multiomic and bulk 3D interactome data to model the impact of genetic variation on gene regulation, using rheumatoid arthritis (RA) as a disease model. Our gene regulatory models and experimental analyses will focus on two cell types that drive RA tissue pathology—T cells and synovial fibroblasts—and will serve as a case study for examining the genetics of polygenic human diseases that dysregulate multiple interacting cell types within affected tissues.

PHR: Project Narrative The Developmental Neurology Training Program supports postdoctoral fellows in the laboratories of neuroscientists at Boston Children's Hospital and related institutions in the Harvard Medical Area. The trainees are engaged in ground-breaking research into the molecular mechanisms underlying brain development, including studies of autism, epilepsy, Rett syndrome, spinomuscular atrophy, muscular dystrophy, and tuberosclerosis. With significant attention to the skills needed for rigorous studies, the trainees are prepared for careers in fundamental research that are informed by clinical needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise/week has well-documented benefits for lowering blood pressure (BP) and improving cardiovascular health. However, we have compelling preliminary data showing that only 5 min/day of inspiratory muscle strength training (IMST) over 6 weeks lowered resting systolic BP (SBP) by ~12 mmHg. While IMST could be applied to almost any population, here we seek to establish the efficacy of IMST as an intervention to reduce SBP in the context of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) -- an increasingly prevalent disorder among older adults accompanied by hypertension, obesity and exercise intolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed project addresses a major public health problem that arises in the care of patients with incurable malignancies: failure to deliver end-of-life (EOL) care consistent with patients' needs, values and preferences. The purpose of this trial comparing the effectiveness of (1) in-person, facilitated advance care planning versus (2) web-based advance care planning is to identify the best approach to improve treatment decisions near EOL and ensure patients' wishes are honored. Data from this study will inform clinicians, payers and health systems seeking to adopt and scale the most effective and efficient ACP strategy in real-world oncology settings, with the potential to improve care for the over 600,000 Americans who die annually from cancer and their families. 3

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 20-30% of surgical patients are at risk of developing clinically significant Persistent Post-Surgical Pain (PPSP). Our previous studies have revealed that greater pain amplification at baseline, either by psychosocial factors (e.g., anxiety, catastrophizing) or by psychophysical factors (e.g., temporal summation of pain) is quite variable among individuals, is measurable, and is associated with greater PPSP risk. One goal of the proposed studies is to utilize our scalable bedside measurement of a patient’s pain amplification phenotype to screen and identify high-risk patients before surgery, and then to test the ability of targeted interventions to prevent PPSP. Another goal is to gain insight into the mechanisms underlying the development of PPSP in humans, particularly the relationship of the pain amplification phenotype to pro- inflammatory and pro-resolving mediators. As a practicing Anesthesiologist and PhD- trained pain neuroscientist with experience in OR- and lab-based translational studies, I am well-situated to conduct these mechanistic and preventive clinical studies in diverse samples of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In spite of decades of research and expenditure of billions of dollars, cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of death worldwide and is increasing in incidence as a consequence of global Westernization with subsequent epidemics in obesity, metabolic disease, and diabetes, all of which greatly exacerbate CVD. A central premise of this Basic and Translational Cardiovascular Research Training Program (CVTP) is that these diseases are extremely complex, and that rigorous study of them requires trainees to have a strong foundation of knowledge in basic CV physiology, developmental biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, epigenetics, pathology, systems biology, biomedical engineering, and many other disciplines. The goal of this training program is to provide both pre- and post-doctoral trainees a highly integrated training experience to enable them to be facile in all of these disciplines thus uniquely enabling them to conduct pioneering studies of the pathogenesis of CVD, and to contribute to development of innovative and much more effective ways to treat or prevent them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain microvascular dysfunction leads to impairments of neurovascular coupling leading to cognitive dysfunction. Mitochondria are cellular energy sensors and impairments of cellular bioenergetics alter the neurovascular coupling. We believe that selective targeting of endothelial variant of neuronal nitric oxide synthase isoform, as we propose, could benefit the brain by protecting microvasculature from hypoglycemia-induced mitochondrial damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Intracranial hypertension (ICH) may lead to brain injury, developmental delay or even death in children, but its early identification to prevent potentially severe sequelae is challenging. Current invasive approaches to identify ICH are inaccurate and carry important risks, and its non-invasive evaluation is highly subjective and often inconclusive. In this proposal, we aim to use image analysis and machine learning methods together with a unique CT image dataset to identify and quantify for the first time cranial bone development abnormalities that have been qualitatively observed in patients with ICH and that could substantially improve current evaluation approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Strong autofluorescence signal from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) has high potential for noninvasive, spatially and molecularly precise early detection, and longitudinal follow-up for AMD clinical trials. Using human donor eyes, we will use high-resolution microscopy and imaging mass spectrometry to localize RPE organelles emitting autofluorescence signal in regions rich in cone or rod photoreceptors, as well as areas in high-risk AMD pathology. With analytic chemistry we will identify the responsible molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Electronic cigarettes have become very popular, especially among adolescent users, yet their long-term effects on brain and cognitive function in relationship to lung injury are essentially unknown. Electronic cigarettes are often used together with alcohol which can further aggravate brain and lung damage. Our preliminary data indicate harmful effects of exposure to electronic cigarettes and alcohol on lung tissue, brain microvessels and neuroinflammation. We propose to study injury mechanisms caused by the combination of electronic cigarettes and alcohol and develop therapeutic interventions to prevent them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The bacterial outer membrane serves as a barrier to protect the cell from a wide range of external stresses, but also restricts the uptake of nutrients and other molecules into the cell and thus is a critical bacterial organelle. Understanding outer membrane biogenesis and the mechanisms of transport across the cell envelope will provide fundamental new insights into bacterial cell biology, and has the potential to form the basis of future work that could open up new drug targets for next-generation antimicrobials. Here we will continue our study of a poorly understand family of transporters that are important for the trafficking of lipids and other hydrophobic molecules across the bacterial cell envelope, which will allow us to understand how the outer membrane is assembled and maintained, and how other hydrophobic cargos are moved in and out of the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project aims to understand the properties and function of a novel population of specialized cells within the thymus that are derived from cells that previously expressed Aire, a gene that is important in the prevention of autoimmunity. These post-Aire-expressing cells have unique features to that suggest they may further support maturation of T cells and induction of other important regulatory T cells. The proposed studies will define the important characteristics of these cells, how these cells develop, and how they may influence T cell development. The results of these studies will allow us to better understand how these cells may promote immune tolerance to self and prevent autoimmune diseases, such as Type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Acute gut barrier dysfunction occurs commonly in patients with critical surgical disorders, leading to the translocation of luminal toxic substances and bacteria to the bloodstream and, in some instances, resulting in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome and death. Effective therapies to preserve the gut barrier integrity are limited, because of poorly understood mechanisms underlying gut barrier dysfunction in various critical surgical conditions. Studies proposed this project will identify the roles and mechanisms of novel extracellular vesicle small noncoding vault RNAs (vtRNAs) in the control of gut barrier function under various critical surgical conditions and will create a fundamental basis for development of new therapies to protect the gut barrier in patients with critical surgical illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income individuals, especially those who are racial minorities, in the US have a disproportionately higher burden of cardiovascular disease, and also have lower rates of health insurance coverage. This study aims to understand whether health insurance coverage for low-income individuals is associated with improvements in access to inpatient and outpatient cardiovascular care, improvements in racial disparities in care access, as well as care after discharge from a cardiovascular hospitalization. The findings of this study will help understand the mechanisms by which recent expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act was associated with improved cardiovascular mortality, as well as inform future health policies seeking to improve cardiovascular outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This investigation will assess concurrent and long-term associations of pesticide exposures with systemic and liver inflammatory markers, and cognitive performance as part of a 12-year follow-up of the ESPINA study, a cohort of children living in agricultural communities in Ecuador. The proposed work will be the first investigation to assess, contrast and account for effects of both insecticides and fungicides (measured in urine) on children's health. Findings from this research will advance the current field of environmental health and inform future risk assessments and disease prevention programs in children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Rather than acute mortality, a significant proportion of severe trauma and sepsis patients develop chronic critical illness (CCI), primarily characterized by recurrent infections, a failure to physically rehabilitate and dismal long- term outcomes. The overarching goal of our laboratory’s research program is to define distinct immunologic endotypes after severe injury or sepsis, to determine their role in the chronic inflammation, immunosuppression and muscle wasting, and to delineate their interactions, such that therapeutic interventions may be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-lesional focal epilepsy (NLFE) is a common and difficult to treat condition that consists of recurrent seizures arising from a brain region with no apparent abnormality on standard clinical MRI. Recently, we identified brain-specific somatic variants in the gene SLC35A2 as a cause of NLFE. We propose to clarify clinical phenotypes associated with these mutations, further define the range of somatic genetic mutations in this and other genes, use advanced imaging to detect subtle abnormalities preoperatively, and determine the spatial patterns of histopathologic and electrophysiologic alterations in NLFE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is a common, age-associated condition in which a somatic mutation that is associated with blood cancers is detectable in the peripheral blood. We propose to examine the biology of individual mutations, to interrogate how CHIP progresses to malignancy, and to investigate how mutant blood cells might alter solid tumor development and response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Using an ultrasensitive RT-QuIC/PMCA assays, our recent study has indicated that skin samples of patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or Parkinson's disease, neurodegenerative diseases associated with the deposition of misfolded protein aggregates (PrPSc) or α-Synuclein, contains detectable PrPSc or α-Synuclein. The aim of the current proposal is to extend our preliminary finding to test a new hypothesis that skin tissues of Alzheimer's disease (AD), the most common neurodegenerative disease, contain the misfolded tau that can be a biomarker for diagnosing, characterizing and predicting outcome of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Social and behavioral determinants of MOUD utilization and opioid overdose In the US, over 192 people die each day due to opioid overdose (OOD), the leading cause of accidental death among adults. Veterans are especially vulnerable to OOD, experiencing rates double those of non-Veterans, due to their higher prevalence of opioid use disorder (OUD). Medication treatment for OUD (MOUD) is the gold standard treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD). However, in the Veterans Health Administration of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), access to MOUD care is lacking. Compounding poor access, many patients who receive MOUD discontinue within 1 year, an indicator of suboptimal treatment retention. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand social and behavioral determinants of health, biological variables, clinical settings and clinical factors that impact MOUD access and outcomes and to develop predictive models for MOUD outcomes.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an urgent global health threat and the prevalence is highest in the Western Pacific Region. The proposed study will identify risk factors for AMR, measure treatment outcomes of pharyngeal infections, and investigate the genomic epidemiology of AMR in N. gonorrhoeae among men who have sex with men in an HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) program in Vietnam. By contributing new knowledge about AMR in N. gonorrhoeae and providing crucial information from a population at high risk for AMR, this proposal will help guide public health efforts aimed at mitigating the spread of drug-resistant gonorrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Newly emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases represent continuing threats to human health, both nationally and globally. To improve our ability to diagnose, treat and prevent these potentially pandemic pathogens, we must understand their biology and pathogenic mechanisms in order to develop the tools we need. The mission of the NEIDL is to conduct this basic and translational research in a safe and secure environment, and through our research and collaborations accelerate the research and development of diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines for known and still to be identified emerging microbial threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This program will provide research training for individuals who will make important contributions to our understanding of how inflammation and fibrosis contribute to rheumatic diseases such as scleroderma and systemic lupus erythematosus. We have expanded the program to include research in additional rheumatic diseases and into different fields of research including the microbiome, cellular therapies and regenerative approaches to rheumatic diseases. Our trainee pool has expanded significantly over the last 15 years, both in number and quality, allowing us to further expand the opportunities in research training for enhancing rigor and research ethics and integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) often co-occurs with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and vascular dysfunction is one of the earliest markers of AD pathogenesis. Mounting evidence suggests delayed vascular reactivity may be an early sign of SVD and AD, but commonly only the magnitude of reactivity is assessed. Advances in magnetic resonance imaging methods have enabled non-invasive quantification of reactivity timing and may offer important insights into SVD and AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clostridioides difficile infection remains a significant public health problem that has persisted because of failures to develop an efficacious vaccine. Toxins secreted by C. difficile during infection drive disease pathology, subvert the host immune response, and leave patients vulnerable to recurrent infection. In the Oklahoma C. difficile U19 program, a consortium of investigators will undertake three distinct but complementary projects to advance a second generation vaccine candidate and to understand the mechanisms by which C. difficile toxins subvert the host immune response and contribute to vaccine failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The lipid and cholesterol-rich Western diet causes increased blood low-density lipoprotein (LDL) which are pathologically linked to many human diseases, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. This study proposes that native LDL plays a critical role in inducing inflammation by activating inflammatory signaling pathways which will be tested using in vitro biochemical assays and animal models of intestinal inflammation. Findings of this study will lead to developing novel therapies for LDL-linked inflammatory and metabolic disorders by targeting molecules involved in LDL-mediated activation of inflammatory signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Minimally invasive neural modulation at sub-millimeter spatial resolution remains a critical yet unmet biomedical need. We propose to build a minimally invasive neuromodulation device by taking advantage of a microwave split ring resonator design and validate its potential in suppression of seizures in a mouse model of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will determine 1) whether and how blood Tc9 cells induce tumor cell pyroptosis in tumor clearance via IL-9- and granzyme B-induced NFB-NLRP3-caspase-1-gasdermin activation; and 2) whether Tc9 cell persistence and function are mediated by Tc9 cell-secreted IL-9 and tumor-produced IL-1 and IL- 18 in vivo. We hypothesize that tumor-specific Tc9 subset may be superb effector T cells for cancer immunotherapy due to their capacity to induce both pyroptosis and apoptosis in tumor cells and utilize Tc9 cell-secreted IL-9 and tumor-produced IL-1 and IL-18 for their fitness, longevity, and function in vivo. Completing this project will reveal the importance and mechanism in induction of tumor pyroptosis by tumor-specific Tc9 cells and elucidate the mechanisms underlying the longevity and function of Tc9 cells in tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The major goals of this project are to develop a quantitative framework that enables objective delineation of Mendelian conditions, apply the framework to systematically delineate conditions across all genes known to underlie a Mendelian condition, and predict the number of conditions due to each gene. This framework will provide a fuller, unbiased characterization of the genotypic/phenotypic spectrum for all Mendelian conditions, enable more precise diagnoses and counseling of individuals with difficult to diagnose phenotypes, and accelerate the detection of new Mendelian conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop the foundations of an end-to-end platform for sequencing native, full-length proteins using unfoldase-coupled nanopore array technology. In principle, this platform could be used to directly determine the primary sequence, including certain post-translational modifications, of individual protein molecules found in human cells. This will provide unprecedented insight into proteoform diversity and its role in biological phenotypes and disease states such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The lack of effective treatment against metastatic cancer is primarily due to the complexity of the disease and incomplete understanding of the key mechanisms. We address this challenge through an unconventional approach that takes advantage of a specific feature of cancer cells distinguishing them from normal cells. We use this unique feature to develop anti-cancer drugs for discovery of agents selective against cancer cells over normal cells. We have developed a clinical candidate (metarrestin) that shows selective inhibition of cancer metastasis in animals. Metarrestin has begun a phase I pancreatic cancer clinical trial at NCI. We will investigate how this compound inhibits cancer behavior and will develop next generation, more specific and potent anti- cancer drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic stenosis is a common disease of the elderly that is caused by narrowing of the heart valve through which the heart pumps blood to the body, and can result in cardiac failure and death. All attempts at medical therapy to slow disease progression have failed, resulting in surgery being the only treatment for aortic stenosis. We will apply advanced imaging in animal models and humans to investigate a potentially treatable cause of aortic stenosis that involves blood platelets attaching to the aortic valve leaflets, thereby triggering adverse valve thickening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Despite the critical nature of cocaine addiction, current preclinical models devoted to investigating the enduring neural substrates of cocaine addiction have yielded little insight into developing novel treatment targets. In this application, we focus on distinct, time-dependent interventions during abstinence from cocaine self-administration in male and female rats to normalize cocaine-induced dysfunction in the prefrontal cortex thereby decreasing persistent cocaine-seeking. These studies will impact the field of drug abuse research by advancing our understanding of the key neurobiological substrates that mediate relapse to drug-seeking with the potential of leading to possible novel therapeutic targets for men and women suffering from substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Immunotherapy related adverse events (irAE), especially the irAE associated with combination of anti- CTLA4 and anti-PD1/PD-L1, are serious clinical problems that affect the cancer treatment efficacy and compliance, as well as patients' quality of life. Our hypothesis is reduction of cell surface and soluble CTLA4 by anti-CTLA-4 antibodies may contribute to irAE. Our work will not only establish a fundamental mechanism of irAE but also a treatment for adverse effect associated with anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA-4 combination therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both HIV and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) establish life-long infections that, despite the development of antiretroviral therapy and antibiotics, cause millions of deaths every year, emphasizing the need to develop a cure. This proposal aims to define the methods by which HIV and Mtb evade immune-mediated clearance by characterizing their common target cell, the macrophage, and how this cell acts to shield these pathogens from immune responses. Insight into these mechanisms will help identify macrophage-specific pathways that can be exploited to make these infected cells more susceptible to immune-mediated clearance, potentiating the development of cure-based strategies for HIV and Mtb infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Scanning plays a crucial role in defining and maintaining the integrity of the proteome, but it remains one of the least-well understood components of regulated protein synthesis. By directly observing scanning dynamics on single messenger RNAs, we will establish a quantitative molecular mechanistic framework that deepens our understanding of scanning and aids efforts to understand and reverse how it is dysregulated in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work will use quantitative and systems biology approaches for analyzing the regulation and function of the Extracellular Signal-Regulated Kinase (ERK) signaling pathway that plays a key role in human and animal development and disease. We focus on the transcriptional interpretation of ERK signals by Capicua (Cic) and other regulators, and will develop an integrated mathematical model for the control of gastrulation, a critical developmental event. Alterations of the ERK signaling pathway in humans are involved in a range of disorders, including Rasopathies, cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and the autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Nanomedicines are playing an increasing role in delivery of cancer therapeutics, however, variability in treatment response significantly limits their effectiveness and clinical translation. To address this shortcoming a nanoparticle-based molecular imaging agent will be developed as a companion diagnostic to visualize the delivery of a new therapeutic nanomedicine for prostate cancer. This agent may be used in the future in men with prostate cancer to select those patients that may benefit from the new nanomedicine.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differentiating between causes of shock in the 1.3 million Americans annually who develop shock annually is extremely challenging and requires many clinical experts to provide their perspective. Yet, there is no way for these clinicians to actively share their assessments, build a shared understanding of the cause of shock, and reach a consensus on treatment. The proposed resarch will understand why interprofessional clinicians disagree on the cause of shock, and then design and test a systematic process for interprofessional clinicians to share information, assessments and build a shared understanding of the cause of shock.
PI_NAMEs: BERRY, ANDREW BARNDEN LEWIS;STEY, ANNE M (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Shock Patients: Interprofessional Communication to Enhance Diagnosis (SPICED)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Prolonged opioid use after surgery is one of the most common but least understood surgical complications. Little is known about why some people take relatively few opioids, while others go on to consume opioids long after the expected postoperative pain course. This project will examine potential patient factors, including pain sensitivity and transcriptomic influences, on the variation in postoperative pain and opioid use after total knee replacement, a surgery demonstrating great variation in opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) affects nearly 11% of the population worldwide, significantly impacts patients’ quality of life and imposes a huge economic burden due to loss of productivity and high healthcare costs. Gut bacteria play an important role in IBS, but the mechanism remains unclear; thus, we do not have effective probiotics to treat IBS. This proposal will uncover how specific bacterial products affect gastrointestinal motility and allow development of more effective probiotic therapies for IBS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is to investigate the stage-dependent AMH actions in regulating follicular development and ovarian function, and to evaluate stage-specific AMH modulation in facilitating follicle growth and maturation to improve fertility outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer is a leading cause of cancer-related death in American men, with lethality due primarily to castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). This study will establish a paradigm-shifting model wherein FOXA1 collaborates with ARID1A, a chromatin modifier, to suppress inflammatory cytokine expression. Further, it will demonstrate the critical role of FOXA1 as a tumor-intrinsic regulator of the PCa immune landscape and pave the way for new therapeutic approaches that sensitize FOXA1-low or mutant CRPC to immunotherapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the leading cause of lower respiratory tract infection in children and is a cause of respiratory disease in the elderly and the immunocompromised. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently a lack of mechanistic understanding of why humoral immunity against malaria is not efficiently induced. This project will define mechanisms that trigger immune dysregulation during malaria and study the long-term consequences of these events. Determining the pathways that regulate the development and humoral immunity will be broadly important to the fields of infectious disease immunology and vaccinology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a common complication of diabetes, characterized by decreased vascular supply, ischemia and impaired metabolism in the skeletal muscle. Limited treatment options often lead to limb amputation in alarmingly large number of patients. We plan to investigate the function of a gene named ERR as a potential therapeutic target for PAD via it's stimulatory effects on skeletal muscle metabolism and blood supply.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black family caregivers of older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and/ or related dementias (ADRD) have an increased of risk of mortality as compared to White non-Latino caregivers. Minority caregivers may be able to improve their health outcomes by engaging in specifically designed community-based support programs aimed at increasing caregiver ability and confidence in providing care, perceived rewards of caregiving, and use of adaptive coping strategies. This work addresses a clinical void in culturally responsive interventions developed for Black caregivers of persons with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Humans with Type 1 diabetes (T1D) are susceptible to diabetic bone disease and are more likely to suffer a fragility fracture than humans without T1D. Despite this now well-recognized increased risk of osteoporosis and fracture in persons with T1D, it is still not well understood how insulin, or its homolog, insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), directly affects skeletal well-being in this condition. The studies described in this project will define the relative contributions of insulin and IGF-1 to the molecular, cellular and tissue-level events involved in the development of diabetic bone disease, as well as explore the therapeutic potential of insulin and IGF-1 in preventing and treating diabetic bone disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In regions where malaria transmission is high, chronic asymptomatic malaria infections are common and are major contributors to continued transmission of malaria. A recent field trial showed that asymptomatic screening, testing, and treatment (STT) interventions could reduce transmission from humans to mosquitoes. In this study, I will use agent-based modeling to evaluate the potential impact and cost- effectiveness of STT on long-term malaria control and elimination across a diverse set of epidemiological settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer is more common than many other cancers, but its causes are less well understood, partially because research in large, population-based studies has typically been unable to differentiate the molecular subtypes that make up prostate cancer. This proposal seeks to understand in which men some of the most important molecular subtypes of prostate cancer occur; to assess risk factors for specific molecular subtypes to elucidate which subtypes could be prevented and how; and to create new functionality for a widely-used data sharing and exploration platform to make molecular epidemiology data publicly available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this K01 Career Development Award is to foster Dr. Andrea Titus’s transition to independence as a social epidemiologist with expertise in examining environmental drivers of cardiovascular disease disparities. The proposed study will draw on multi-level statistical and machine learning approaches to investigate associations between fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and disparities across a range of cardiovascular disease outcomes, leveraging electronic health record data from a national cohort of U.S. veterans. Findings from this work will contribute to the evidence base regarding the pathogenesis of air pollution-attributable cardiovascular outcomes and will shed light on potential population subgroups that may benefit most from targeted interventions to reduce and mitigate air pollution exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Klebsiella pneumoniae is a bacterium that frequently causes pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection and is increasingly causing severe illness and death in hospitalized patients. Resistance to available antibiotics is rising drastically, and new ways to combat this organism are desperately needed. This proposal focuses on understanding the innate and adaptive immune responses to two O-antigen subtypes, O2v1 and O2v2, of Klebsiella pneumoniae to enhance design of vaccines against this pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is associated with increased risk for severe co-morbidities including myeloid malignancy, cardiovascular disease (CVD) and all-cause mortality, which are a significant health concern for which therapeutic approaches have not yet been identified. We hypothesize that targeting the unique inflammatory and metabolic features of HSPC harboring CH-associated mutations can suppress their preferential expansion in the bone marrow (BM), thereby reducing their production of tissue-damaging immune cells that contribute to CVD and other CH-related morbidities. The overall goals of our project are 1) to characterize the role of aberrant glycolytic metabolism as the mechanism selecting for CH HSPC under inflammatory conditions; and 2) establish whether blockade of the NLRP3 inflammasome blocks the inflammatory trigger that drives glycolytic activity and CH HSPC expansion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shared decision making prior to lung cancer screening is recommended since lung cancer screening has both benefits and risks. However, shared decision making rarely happens in primary care settings due to difficulty in identifying lung cancer screening eligible patients, lack of patient awareness, lack of provider knowledge, and limited visit time. This pilot study will compare a multi-strategy technology-assisted implementation program to usual care on lung cancer screening uptake, and will provide a foundation for a future large-scale pragmatic trial to improve the uptake of and longitudinal adherence to annual lung cancer screening by supporting shared decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disordered eating behaviors (DEBs) in type 2 diabetes (T2DM) is an under-recognized clinical issue that has shown to worsen diabetes self-management and increase the risk for health concerns, such as higher triglycerides and poor short-term metabolic control. By partnering with behavioral health providers in real clinical settings and utilizing implementation science methods to evaluate the implementation of a novel intervention to treat DEBs in T2DM, this project has the potential to fill a tremendous unmet need for people with T2DM and accelerate the translation of evidence-based interventions in chronic disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In addition to safe and effective vaccines, direct-acting antivirals with complementary mechanisms of action, patterns of resistance and improved toxicity profiles are desperately needed for the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS) to adequately deter the use of smallpox as a bioweapon and to prepare for zoonotic orthopoxviruses with pandemic potential. Following the eradication of smallpox and the subsequent end of the global vaccine campaign, most of the world’s population lost immunological protection to variola virus and to infection by all other orthopoxviruses. As a result, there has been a significant increase in the number of orthopoxvirus spill over events from animal reservoirs into humans. To better prepare for both natural and deliberate threats from orthopoxviruses, we propose high throughput screening of a diversified 200,000 small- molecule library to identify novel antiviral inhibitor classes for the treatment of smallpox disease and other orthopoxviruses with pandemic potential.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Program narrative Africa bears direct morbidity and mortality from poverty-related and neglected tropical diseases including schistosomiasis, which remains endemic in Uganda with an estimated 50% of the population at risk of infection and the associated complications of portal hypertension and fatal upper gastro- intestinal bleeding. Since the description of schistosomiasis in Uganda in the 1950s, efforts to control schistosomiasis remain limited due to incomplete understanding of the pathogen, disease manifestations and transmission mechanisms, and inadequate preventive measures and interventions. Capacity for advanced research training is clearly needed provide schistosomiasis-focused scientists with sufficient capacity to analyze, model and predict relevant clinical case management systems, biological interventions, and disease control efforts in Uganda. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High risk for premature mortality is one of the most pressing issues faced by the growing population of autistic older adults but the absence of accurate autism-specific mortality risk prediction tools results in inability to systematically identify those at the highest risk for targeted intervention. This proposal will have a high public health impact by providing critical information about detecting mortality risk among autistic older adults that can ultimately be used to improve life-expectancy among autistic people. This proposal is well-aligned with the NIA’s Strategic Plan, as we seek to “understand disparities related to aging and [inform] strategies to improve the health status of older adults” on the autism spectrum, and NOT-AG-21-020 in that we will analyze existing Medicare claims data to examine “subgroups of older adults with special needs” and “health outcomes in complex multimorbid older adults.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To realize the full promise of patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) to advance precision therapies for cancer, standardized PDX procedures and coordinated sharing of PDX specimens are needed to validate results across research groups and determine which results may be robust for cancer patients. To address these needs, our PDX Data Commons and Coordination Center unifies the activities of NIH-supported PDX Development and Trial Centers and the National Cancer Institute's Patient-Derived Models Repository. Our Data Commons and Coordination Center uses innovative administrative, cloud computing and bioinformatic approaches to enable PDX method standardization, model sharing, data sharing, and massive-scale data analysis to accelerate translation of PDX studies into cancer clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with Turner syndrome (TS) have a much higher risk of developing diabetes compared to the general population; however, the reasons for this are unknown. Because women with TS have alterations in their X chromosomes, much of the proposed work will focus on the role of the X chromosome in diabetes development. Knowledge gained from this project will help us better understand the cause(s) of diabetes in TS; because the role of the X chromosome in diabetes is understudied in the general population, this knowledge may be useful for our overall understanding of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryptosporidium is a common and life-threatening pathogen in children across the globe. There is no vaccine and drug development is notoriously difficult for this intracellular parasite, thus treatments are extremely limited. Effective therapies for children and immunocompromised patients is an urgent need with the potential to save future lives. We have identified PKC, a human protein kinase, as a key factor in disease susceptibility in infants. This study will explore if PKC is necessary for parasites to invade human cells and if it can be blocked with drugs as a new potential treatment. This approach overturns the paradigm of parasite-targeted drugs and has the potential to be broadly effective, with less potential for resistance. This proposal has the potential to significantly improve human health by developing a host-targeted therapy for cryptosporidiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to define the mechanisms that control the abundance of a class of essential non-coding RNAs that fine-tune the ribosome for efficient and accurate production of all cellular proteins. Dysregulation of these non-coding RNAs and thus, functional ribosomes, is associated with defects in gene expression that result in human disease. Determining the molecular mechanisms of these essential processes in gene expression is relevant for public health to provide potential novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Axon guidance is the process by which neurons find their targets in order to build the neural circuits that allow animals to respond to information they sense in their environment. Axon guidance involves a specialized structure at the end of the neuron called the growth cone, which probes the complex three-dimensional environment of the embryo and makes directional decisions in response to the cues it detects. The goal of this proposal is to discover how one particular molecular signaling pathway called the Planar Cell Polarity pathway is used by the growth cones of neurons in the spinal cord to find their appropriate targets in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently, the best way in which to screen men for prostate cancer (PCa) is unknown, resulting in a large burden of invasive, expensive, and unnecessary PCa diagnostic investigations and therapies. Our proposed R01 will address this problem by optimizing screening and identifying “who”, “when”, and “how often” men should be screened for PCa to prevent the high morbidity and mortality of this cancer, while also reducing the physical, mental, and economic harms of screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop the first neurogenetic tools in ants, and map how the chemosensory system represents social and environmental stimuli in the brain. By comparing neural activity between ants that show different behavioral responses to the same stimulus, it will reveal how perception can be modulated and lead to alternative behavioral outcomes. These insights will have implications for the development of new clinical approaches for treating disorders with abnormal sensory sensitivity to social and environmental stimuli, such as autism and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite unprecedented clinical success in the treatment of advanced cancers, immune checkpoint inhibitors are associated with immune-related adverse events. Understanding the mechanisms of immune-related adverse events is critical to identify valid biomarkers to predict and assess these events and to establish the optimal treatment strategy targeting autoimmunity while preserving antitumor immunity, both of which are triggered by immune checkpoint inhibitors. This work seeks to determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying arthritis associated with immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy by utilizing patient samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Lung transplant is an increasingly common lifesaving surgery for patients with fatal lung diseases, but its success is limited by a median post-transplant survival of merely 5.5 years which is only half the survival of other organ transplant types. Troublingly, median survival also varies up to 39% depending on geographic region of the United States, and despite the profound impact of social and environmental factors on lung function, this has not been rigorously investigated in lung transplant recipients. To address this gap, we apply a geospatial framework to measure, map, and model how the cumulative social and environmental determinants of health intersect to impact post-transplant survival, and, in doing so, create unprecedented comprehensive information translatable towards reducing geographic disparities and improving survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is common and deadly in children, and clinical trials have been hampered by patient heterogeneity. Clustering together patients with shared pathophysiologic or biomarker profiles are one strategy to identify subgroups with shared underlying biology to better target interventions. The proposed studies will assess whether the results of an ongoing trial of different fluids used for resuscitation are broadly applicable to all septic children, or whether their effects are more pronounced in some subgroups, as well as investigate the mechanisms underlying the relationship between fluid choice and kidney function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The cerebellum’s role in motor learning is dependent on the computations performed by neurons that compose its circuits. Yet the heterogeneity and functional organization of the neuron types in cerebellar cortex are not fully known, preventing elucidation of how the cerebellum implements adaptive behavior. Therefore, the goal of this study is to characterize the diversity of inhibitory molecular-layer-interneuron subtypes and determine how their neural connections allows for them to play a determinant role in error-driven motor learning, insight that is required to understand how the cerebellum operates in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The error-related negativity (ERN) is a biomarker of error processing that can predict future onset and worse outcomes of anxiety disorders in young children and is therefore a potential target to offset the development of anxiety disorders; however, a number of factors make the ERN difficult to measure, including relying on people to spontaneously click the wrong button on a small fraction of hundreds of trials. The balance N1 is a comparable biomarker that can be robustly and reliably measured in response to a single perturbation to upright standing balance and is associated in amplitude with the ERN in younger and older adult populations and may therefore provide a more robust measurement of the same underlying neural system. The proposed project will validate the balance N1 against the ERN in young children with and without anxiety disorders, and test whether an intervention to reduce the ERN transfers to a similar reduction of the balance N1, which may provide insight into prior work demonstrating that balance training can alleviate anxiety in children, and well- documented benefits of psychotherapy to balance disorders, which may ultimately facilitate the development of multidisciplinary interventions for anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The proposed study is highly relevant to public health, as data from the planned US population survey would allow more accurate estimation of negative impacts of alcohol, tobacco and drugs like marijuana, opioids and methamphetamine on people other than users themselves. The study will identify relevant risk factors of individuals, their social environments, and their neighborhoods and communities, which will be useful for planning targeted interventions and prevention programs to protect people at risk of harm. Results also will provide evidence to inform debates on effective policy strategies to reduce alcohol- and drug-related harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most current studies focus on pharmacological intervention (PI) for Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (AD/ADRD); however, increasing evidence from multimodal studies elucidates possible synergistic effects of PI and non-pharmacological intervention (NPI) for AD/ADRD. To respond to the PAR-20-156, the objective of this application is to develop translational informatics approaches to aggregate, standardize and discover the synergistic effects of PI and NPI candidates on AD/ADRD using multi-modal data resources (i.e., literature, EHR, clinical trials) followed by animal model validation. The successful completion of this project will deliver a comprehensive NPI knowledge graph, novel informatics approaches, ranked list of drug and NPI candidates, and validated synergistic intervention using multi-modal data sources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Between 22-40% of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) young adults are polytobacco users, meaning they concurrently use multiple nicotine and tobacco products, and low tobacco risk perceptions may be an influencing factor. The proposed study uses crowdsourced (Aim 1), in-laboratory (Aim 2), and Phase I randomized controlled trial (Aim 3) studies to determine effective message framing and targeting to communicate polytobacco use risk to LGBT young adult polytobacco users, and if exposure to anti-polytobacco communications delivered via text messaging reduces tobacco use in this population. Findings will provide public health officials, the National Cancer Institute, and the Food and Drug Administration critical information about optimal anti-polytobacco message framing and digital dissemination strategies that may be leveraged in national health communications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cholestatic liver diseases are heterogeneous, a subset of patients with cholestasis have decreased expression of β-catenin that may cause or exacerbate disease progression. In this proposal, we will use transcriptomics analysis to validate two mouse models that phenotypically resemble primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (PFIC), and determine the subset of PSC and PFIC cases they represent. We will also use these mouse models to assess the contribution of β-catenin to maintenance of cell polarity and cholangiocyte pathobiology in the context of cholestatic liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Our goal is to investigate the factors that influence sex differences in Alzheimer's disease. There is clear evidence that females are more at risk to develop AD than males and that this is exacerbated by the presence of the APOE ε4 allele. We hypothesize that sex chromosome dose and ε4 alleles impact neuroinflammation and we will determine the role of sex-chromosome linked genes that interact with ε4 in this sex-specific susceptibility to disease, which may help adjust treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to reduce the persistent racial disparities in breast cancer outcomes in the U.S and the advances in precision medicine have left African Americans behind. The primary objective of this study is to build a risk assessment tool for women of African descent from genetic alterations in genes that contribute to increased breast cancer risk, and combine this tool with environmental and lifestyle risk factors of breast cancer. We also wish to find the causal risk factors for breast cancer that share across populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: GABAergic interneurons (INs) are critical for the normal function of the brain and have been implicated in human disease. This research project is focused on VIP interneurons, which are the largest IN population in the superficial layers of the cerebral cortex, and have emerged as the main source of cortical disinhibition, a mechanism important in the regulation of perception and high order cognitive function. VIP INs have been shown to comprise a diverse population with structurally and functionally distinct subtypes and this project will use novel reagents and experimental approaches to examine the connectivity and function of distinct VIP IN subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are studying the basic biology underlying the formation of fat droplets in cells. This process is critical to meet the demands in cells for metabolic energy, but when uncontrolled leads to obesity, type 2 diabetes, fatty liver disease, and other metabolic diseases of fat excess. By understanding how these processes occur and are regulated, our work will advance our understanding of these conditions and may lead to new therapies to treat them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Congenital heart defects (CHDs) are a major global health burden, responsible for over 250,000 deaths annually and lasting complications for the estimated 12 million people living with CHDs. Without the ability to substantially alter the prevalence of CHDs, new medical technologies are needed to improve survival and quality of life. The goal of this proposal is to develop a stimuli-responsive material that can be integrated with existing medical devices, such as pulmonary artery bands, to permit adjustability acutely (e.g. due to physiological changes) and chronically (e.g. to accommodate growth) thereby improving patient outcomes and reducing costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The mechanisms underpinning heterogeneous metabolic response between individual cells remain poorly understood, though such mechanisms have ramifications across nearly all of medicine, e.g., disease detection, response to stress, treatment, and more. Most technologies lack the sensitivity, broad chemical coverage, quantitative capability, and/or the sampling throughput needed to enable the mechanisms of heterogeneous metabolic response of cells to be explored, but recently the development of single cell printing-liquid vortex capture-mass spectrometry (SCP-LVC-MS) has overcome many of these limitations. The goal of this research is to address key technical challenges regarding validation of the quantitative accuracy of SCP-LVC-MS, representativeness of SCP-LVC-MS measured cellular chemical profiles, and ability to relate SCP-LVC-MS measurements to established single-cell technologies so that it can become an effective research tool in the biomedical community and enable associations between metabolites and therapeutics to be investigated on an individual cellular basis for the first time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Similar to the addition of a negatively-charged phosphate to proteins during phosphorylation, sialylation adds a negatively-charged sialic acid to a glycoprotein to regulate conformation, clustering and cell surface retention. While this post-translational modification is known to regulate some protumorigenic cellular signaling and behaviors, roles in metabolism or brain tumors have not been determined. We seek to understand how sialylation and a specific sialyltransferase control brain tumor initiating cell maintenance and metabolism, which we expect will provide important insights that may be more broadly applicable to cancer biology and neurodevelopment.
