IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: READD-ADSP Alzheimer Disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disease in the US, occurring in more than 35% of individuals above the of age 85. While there are currently no effective pharmacological treatments for preventing or delaying the onset of AD, genomic studies are a proven approach for identifying new therapeutic targets. The goal of the ʺRecruitment and Retention for Alzheimerʹs Disease Diversity Cohorts in the ADSPʺ (READD-ADSP) is to build a resource that greatly expands the representation of currently underrepresented African ancestry and Hispanic/Latinx (HL) individuals in AD genetic studies, which will expand our understanding of the genetic etiology of AD and broaden the biological scope for developing potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Therapies for circadian rhythm disruption, which is common both in the general and clinical populations with irregular sleep-wake schedules rely on a single biomarker – the melatonin rhythm – to guide the timing of interventions such as bright light exposure even though circadian rhythms are ubiquitous across physiological systems. We have found that a combined intervention of light exposure and meals shifts the timing of the circadian rhythms in circulating cholesterol and triglycerides in humans, and we propose a randomized controlled trial in healthy young adults to determine the individual roles of light exposure and time restricted eating as the primary time cues for resetting the circadian rhythms of these lipids and melatonin, thereby construct phase response curves that define the relationship between the timing of these two interventions and the change in the timing of circadian rhythms in circulating lipids and melatonin. The knowledge gained will provide novel insight on the fundamental properties of the human circadian system and have potentially broad public health and clinical implications including recommendations for developing healthy light exposure and eating schedules and guiding current and future treatment strategies to address circadian disruption in multiple circadian systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE/Public Health Relevance Statement Individuals with Down syndrome experience chronic inflammation because of hyper-sensitivity to molecules called interferons, which activate immune responses to infections. In this study, we seek to apply diverse and complementary approaches to study two human enzymes that have recently been shown to drive these interferon responses. We anticipate that the mechanistic insights gained will establish the clinical potential of these druggable enzymes as antagonists of inflammatory interferons, which may yield new therapeutic strategies for DS and its co-morbidities, such as auto-immune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Huntington’s disease is a devastating and fatal neurodegenerative disorder for which there is no cure or effective treatment. The combination of emotional, cognitive and motor symptoms, leading to long-term care needs results in an extremely high healthcare cost, estimated at 25 billion dollars a year. This study is aimed at understanding how the disease process is modified, with the potential of discovering novel targets for therapeutic intervention prior to disease onset.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal uses an early social isolation (ESI) mouse model to investigate pathway-specific (PFC-VTA or PFC-NAc) synaptic transmission and molecular mechanisms involved in ESI-potentiated vulnerability for heroin relapse, measured by cue-induced drug seeking after abstinence from heroin self-administration. These studies may contribute to the development of more efficient pharmacotherapies for relapse prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/LAY SUMMARY We have discovered a new role for a protein called ATR in promoting aggressive triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) behavior and the ability of TNBC to survive by hiding from the immune system. Our goal in this proposal is two-fold: 1) investigate how ATR promotes aggressive TNBC behavior in response to external forces that are commonly applied to cancer cell walls as tumors progress and 2) examine whether targeting ATR and this new ATR pathway can reverse TNBC aggressive features and promote the immune system’s ability to fight TNBC. As there are over 32,000 cases of TNBC diagnosed in the United States each year and nearly all patients with metastatic progression succumb to the disease, our results could have a profound impact on health and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a global epidemic with a high disease burden, although clinicians caring for septic patients are unable to distinguish between septic patients who will rapidly recover and those who will develop a prolonged disease course marked by significant morbidity and mortality. This is partly due to our incomplete understanding of the complex underlying immune responses in sepsis as well as our inability to translate research findings into information that is useful to clinicians. This research will contribute to the development of novel techniques that will help clinicians to get individualized results about their patients’ immune responses, to guide their decisions about whether immune-adjuvant therapy may be appropriate for each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer cells, stem cells, and activated immune cells use a specialized form of sugar metabolism known as aerobic glycolysis to support cell division and tissue growth. I have discovered that fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) also use aerobic glycolysis to support rapid growth. My lab is using this model genetic system to understand how growing animal cells regulate aerobic glycolysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Sanford Community Cancer Program (SCCP) covers rural communities of the upper Midwest and Central Plains representing a large underserved population for cancer treatment, care delivery and clinical trials. The NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) partnership will help deliver clinical care and offer clinical trials across the rural area served by the SCCP. This will be accomplished through the following aims: maintain and enhance robust accrual to NCI Division of Cancer Prevention (DCP) supported clinical trials through seven components; address disparities in clinical trial accrual in underserved and underrepresented populations to increase participation; cultivate innovative access points to address barriers to clinical trial accrual through outreach and telemedicine; expand current personnel and infrastructure, and contribute to Cancer Care Delivery Research trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic pathogenic mold that can cause invasive aspergillosis, a fatal lung infection of immunocompromised patients. Preliminary data indicate that IL-1 signaling is required for murine survival and leukocyte killing of A. fumigatus. This three-year research training plan seeks to uncover the immune and lung structural cells involved in IL-1-dependent crosstalk during A. fumigatus infection to support development of targeted therapeutics promoting sterilizing immunity in patients with invasive aspergillosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE Implementation of evidence-based behavioral interventions that enhance treatment success among people receiving medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) is needed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections caused by the highly lethal marine pathogen Vibrio. vulnificus are the most burdensome foodborne illness. The proposed study investigates pathogenesis mechanisms of Multifunctional-Autoprocessing Repeats- in-Toxin (MARTX) toxin, a primary bacterial toxin produced by V. vulnificus. By investigating host receptor(s) and receptor binding domains on MARTX, the proposed work will provide important basic science knowledge on toxin functions and inform generation of novel therapeutics to combat lethal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated mitochondrial function is associated with many age-related diseases. Resolving the contributing mechanisms underlying age-dependent declines of mitochondrial health is a pressing goal of basic and translational aging research. This research aims to delineate novel organelle communication mechanisms involved in maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis during aging. This study will contribute to the discovery of interventions targeting mitochondria for the treatment of age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Loss of intestinal barrier function is a hallmark of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), a condition afflicting 6.8 million people worldwide in 2017 with substantially increasing prevalence, particularly in the USA. Microbiota-derived purines were recently identified to support intestinal barrier function and wound healing during disease and represent a potential therapeutic avenue for IBD treatment. This work will employ a mutant bacterium enriched in purine production to not only delineate the role of microbial-derived purines in intestinal metabolism, barrier function, and wound healing, but also assess the therapeutic efficacy of such a genetically modified organism as a next generation probiotic in disease intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genome maintenance is essential to life and disruption of genome integrity often leads to diseases. In this proposal, we will carry out genetics, molecular, and genomic studies in a functional model to study programmed DNA elimination, an exception to the genome constancy rule. These studies will reveal the functions and mechanisms of DNA elimination that will provide insights into genome maintenance and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Alkaloid natural products have had an immense impact on the field of therapeutic medicine, and hold promise for the discovery of new neuropharmacological treatments. The development of new synthetic strategies to build these important molecules allows for the construction of new matter capable of improving upon the available treatments for crippling ailments such as addiction, depression, post-traumatic stress disorder and Parkinson's. Laboratory synthetic access to these important alkaloid natural products holds immense promise for the development of efficacious and novel neuropharmacological small molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: While our understanding of the patterns of human genomic variation has greatly improved in the past decades, genetic studies failed to capture the full picture of genetic variation harbored in human populations across the globe. Research in my newly established lab aims to bridge one of the largest gaps in representation in genomics, by leading two large-scale genome sequencing studies of geographically diverse populations in Oceania, with the goal of reconstructing our evolutionary past and disentangling the genetic basis of phenotypic variation and disease susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We want to study how ADGRB1/BAI1, a cell surface receptor, can exert tumor suppressor functions in brain tumor development. Our goal is to decipher how the extracellular N-terminus of ADGRB1 can suppress mesenchymal transition in glioma, including through prevention of the maturation of growth factor  TGFβ1. The knowledge derived from these studies may lead to the development of novel therapeutics for brain and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The colon is distinct from the small intestine in morphology, cell type composition, function, and disease susceptibility, yet basic understanding of colon biology lags significantly behind that of small intestine, hindering a deeper understanding of colonic diseases and therapeutic development. We identified a chromatin factor that functions as a crucial regulator of colonic stem cell identity and differentiation. We propose in-depth studies of this factor to gain insight on colonic fate regulation and to evaluate a novel therapeutic approach to promote colonic nutrient absorption to treat digestive failure in the Short Bowel Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preeclampsia, a condition characterized by high blood pressure in pregnancy, constitutes a major cause of maternal and perinatal morbidity and mortality; severe hypertension (blood pressure ≥160/110 mmHg) is a common trigger for antihypertensive treatment and preterm delivery. We propose a clinical trial that will test whether lowering the blood pressure of women with preeclampsia at <36 weeks’ gestation to <140/90 mmHg will prolong pregnancy and, therefore, improve maternal and fetal/neonatal outcomes. Data generated in this study, along with knowledge and skills acquired by the candidate in the complementary career development plan, will facilitate an independent research career focused on hypertension and cardiovascular disease in pregnancy and the postpartum period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent mental health studies, both cross-sectional and longitudinal, have led to an expanded depth of neuroimaging, clinical assessments and physiological data, which provide an unprecedented opportunity for crosscutting investigations that may offer new insights to mechanisms and trajectory of mental disorders. However, much-needed statistical methods for exploring discoveries are lacking. In this project, we seek to develop rigorous and computationally efficient statistical methods for neural circuitry analysis, predictive modeling and longitudinal modeling of multi-dimensional data to facilitate diagnosis, deepen mechanistic understanding and improve treatment of mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative: The study aims to establish an integrated healthcare database and a novel analytical framework for causal analyses comparing continuation vs. different discontinuation strategies of antipsychotic medications (APMs) used to manage delirium due to hospitalization in persons living with dementia (PLWDs). The proposal will produce data reflecting routine-care delivery to optimize delirium pharmacotherapy management in PLWDs and a generalizable framework that facilitates evidence generation guiding deprescribing of potentially inappropriate medications in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High-throughput single cell genomics and transcriptomics technologies have allowed researchers to study our cells with unprecedented resolution and scale. With the knowledge obtained on individual aspects of cells and the development of technologies that can jointly profile multi-modality data, we are entering an era of “putting the pieces together”. In this proposal, we propose concepts and methods to integrate multi-omics data to understand cell temporal dynamics and regulatory mechanisms, and we also propose a new concept of “problem integration”, where related computational formulations can be connected into one unified framework to provide a consistent and more general picture of a certain aspect of cells.

PROJECT_TITLE: Studying temporal dynamics and regulatory mechanisms of single cells with a unified framework and multi-omics data

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health as this research will contribute to fundamental knowledge about risk factors for developing tinnitus and the metabolic pathways and genetic influences that underlie its persistence. The long-term goal of this research is to identify treatment targets and preventative strategies to reduce the considerable public health burden due to tinnitus-related disability, lost productivity, and mental health suffering, and thereby improve quality of life. This research exemplifies the NIH mission to reduce illness and disability and will advance the mandate of the NIDCD to improve the lives of those with auditory disorders.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to conduct a hybrid effectiveness-implementation study, harnessing the strengths of both quantitative and qualitative studies, to examine the effectiveness of a nurse-delivered brief transdiagnostic treatment for anxiety disorders and PTSD in South African primary care clinics. The proposed study will also examine the barriers and facilitators to the implementation of this treatment in primary care clinics in South Africa. The findings from our study have implications for increasing access and the scale-up of evidence-based treatments for anxiety disorders and PTSD in South Africa and other low and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Transition metals are essential nutrients for all organisms including bacterial pathogens that cause devastating human disease. To prevent infection, the human innate immune system orchestrates a metal-withholding response that attempts to starve invading bacterial pathogens by reducing the availability of essential metal nutrients. Understanding how metal-sequestering proteins such as calprotectin contribute to metal withholding and the host-microbe interaction may inspire new non-traditional antibacterial approaches to prevent and treat microbial infection in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Intrinsically disordered proteins, which lack of a well-defined folded structure alone, play important roles in a variety of intracellular activities. Characterizing the mechanism how these disordered proteins interact with others is therefore critical for understanding the relevant biological process. The research aims at developing a comprehensive set of computational tools to investigate sequence and conformational properties giving rise to biomolecular assemblies containing disordered proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, approximately 350,000 people suffer out-of-hospital cardiac arrest per year; the best chance of survival is when defibrillation occurs within 3 minutes. This proposal seeks estimate bystander AED performance in high-risk geographic areas to determine the treatment effect of a drone AED network. Our research has the potential to significantly improve treatment and survival for OHCA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients have a poor five-year survival (<30%), likely due to the persistence of a very resistant leukemic cell population called leukemia stem cells (LSCs). We identified a small RNA molecule called miR-126 as a potential target in LSCs and have invented and produced a miR-126 inhibitor called miRisten to eliminate the otherwise treatment-resistant AML LSCs. We are planning to test this new compound by conducting mechanistic, pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic and toxicology studies followed by a phase 1 clinical trial in AML patients with resistant disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to train investigators in the related fields of kidney, urology and hematology. In this U2C/TL1 proposal we bring together expertise in research and education from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the Columbia University Irving Medical Center, the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and the Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University, to establish the “New York Consortium for Interdisciplinary Training in Kidney, Urological and Hematological Research”. This consortium will train a new generation of investigators, who will recognize the value of interdisciplinary collaboration in kidney, urology, and hematology research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall The human brain contains roughly equal numbers of neuronal and non-neuronal cells. A major unresolved issue in understanding brain function is how the non-neuronal cells integrate neuronal molecular signals, modulate neural circuit structure and function at multiple temporal and spatial scales, and mediate changes in information processing, perception, and behavior. This project will employ a broad range of experimental and theoretical approaches to identify core principles of the bi-directional communication between neuronal and non-neuronal cells in various brain regions and how disrupting this regular communication transforms perception and action in health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The availability of general synthetic methods that build the carbon framework of organic molecules determines the types of compounds that are available for biological studies and therapeutics for the treatment of human diseases. My research program invents new chemical methods that allow for rapid access to novel small molecules with direct relevance to human health. To accomplish this, we develop new technologies in transition metal catalysis that enable new reactivity and selectivity for C–C and C–X bond forming transformations that prepare functional, highly three-dimensional small molecules.

PROJECT_TITLE: Discovering catalytic strategies for transition metal-catalyzed reactions to construct topologically complex organic scaffolds

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic musculoskeletal pain (MSKP) is a significant problem in many women with hormone receptor-positive early stage breast cancer receiving treatment designed to prevent cancer recurrence by blocking estrogen production via systemic inhibition of the aromatase enzyme. Unfortunately, very little is known about the mechanisms that underly the development of MSKP, which in turn limits the development of effective treatments and prevention strategies. This project will examine both the RNA transcriptome and the DNA methylome to identify genes and biological pathways that are involved in the development of MSKP within the context of declining estrogen levels providing evidence to inform mechanistically driven therapeutic interventions to mitigate the negative consequences of cancer and its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE With the population of U.S. adults ages 65 and older growing at a rate 3 times that of those under 65, primary care providers must be prepared to care for the 80% of older adults who have complex care needs due to multiple chronic conditions (MCC). Our Northwestern Older Americans Independence Center will infuse geriatrics principles into primary care and align services with patients' priorities, enhance treatment decision making and promote self-management to optimize function, independence and quality of life among older adults with MCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Severe infection (sepsis) leads to high mortality and long-term impairments such as physical disability, which diminishes quality of life and overburdens health-care systems. Clinical trials have been ineffective to prevent disability after sepsis, likely because of the lack of understanding of the pathology and variability of sepsis- induced physical disability. To improve future treatments that prevent physical disability, we first must not only better characterize the effect of age, sex, and race/ethnicity on variability in disability outcomes, but also explore the role of the gut microbiome, which uniquely controls the host immune response, depends on biological variability, and affects skeletal muscle in sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a self-shield kilovoltage x-ray cabinet system with the capabilities of delivering both FLASH and conventional dose-rate irradiations for pre-clinical laboratory research. The novel system, unlike other technologies, make FLASH irradiation broadly available to the research community, which is critical to advance the research and translation of FLASH radiotherapy. FLASH has transformative potential to enhance significantly the efficacy of radiotherapy in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Regulated recruitment and migration of acute inflammatory cells termed neutrophils (PMN) into the intestine and across the specialized epithelium that lines it is critical for host defense, yet dysregulation of this process is associated with disease. The goal of this proposal is to examine pathways can drive of pro- and anti-inflammatory states through regulation of PMN transmigration. Results from these experiments will reveal new insights into innate regulation of mucosal inflammation and homeostasis and extensions of this work could lead to targets for experimental therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Coronaviruses assembly within cells lining the gut, lung and kidneys uses the apical membrane recycling system and requires a specific interaction between host cell Myosin Vb and the coronavirus M glycoprotein. We now seek to evaluate the basis of the interaction of M protein with Myosin Vb in the recycling system of epithelial cells, and how interruption of this association may decrease efficient virus assembly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a deadly disease, in part, because the cancer cells are able to recruit non-cancerous cells called “fibroblasts” that in turn can help the cancer cells grow and evade therapies. The purpose of this study is to better understand how these non-cancerous fibroblast cells change during the development of pancreatic cancer, how different types of noncancerous cells contribute to tumor growth, and how we can develop new drugs to prevent these cells from aiding the cancer cells. This work will identify new ways to block the cancer- promoting, fibroblast cells, which could lead to new treatments for patients affected by pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this study is to better understand the underlying neurophysiology associated with motion processing deficits in cerebral (cortical) visual impairment (CVI). CVI is the leading cause of congenital visual impairment in the developed world yet, little is known as to how visual perceptual deficits in these individuals relate to early maldevelopment of central visual pathways and structures. We will carry out psychophysical behavioral testing combined with multimodal neuroimaging to characterize brain-behavioral relationships associated with motion processing deficits; which is an important marker of developmental vulnerability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-tuberculosis lung disease (PTLD), which develops in up to half of people with pulmonary tuberculosis, is an increasingly recognized cause of lung disease with up to 4.3 million new cases worldwide every year. However, the underlying biologic mechanisms that lead to PTLD are still poorly understood. This proposal aims to understand the underlying clinical host factors and host immunological factors that lead to PTLD, measuring lung function over two-years after pulmonary tuberculosis and using state-of-the art techniques including RNA sequencing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRAVIVE  The proteasome is the central protease in our cells, and as such it controls the levels, and therefore the functionality, of hundreds of proteins. We know from model organism studies that the activity of the proteasome promotes longevity as well as ameliorates some mechanisms of neurodegeneration. In this study, we will develop an understanding of key mechanisms that control the activity of the proteasome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will uncover the mechanisms through which COVID-19 has and will have short-term and long-term impacts on children’s reading skills. We use a risk-resilience model as the framework for this project, which recognizes children have varying levels of risk factors that make them more or less likely to be affected by COVID-19 related disruptions to their sources of resiliency. This project will help us understand how the COVID-19 pandemic is affecting children, as well as add to our general knowledge about how trauma affects children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Results from this project can provide foundational understanding describing the safety of e-cigarette use during pregnancy. These studies offer a valuable resource to the public health community defining the impact of e-cigarettes on early pregnancy success and fetal health. Furthermore, deepened understanding of factors affecting early pregnancy can benefit the treatment of women suffering from infertility, early pregnancy loss, or hypertensive pregnancy disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: This proposal seeks to establish an Al-driven "cyborg tissue" platform that integrates flexible electronic  sensors and actuators with developing human-induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-derived cardiac  tissues for monitoring and controlling tissue maturation. The closed-loop system will collect multimodal  electrical, mechanical, and genetic data from cells, analyze the data using statistical models, and  generate control policies through reinforcement learning to promote tissue maturation via distributed electrical actuations. By improving our understanding of how genetic, molecular, electrical, and mechanical  processes regulate hiPSC-derived cardiac organoid maturation, this resulting bioelectronics system will have  wide-ranging applications in regenerative medicine and pharmacology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary goal of the current application is to determine how genetic factors influence the development of brain structure and function in infancy and early childhood. Several major disorders emerge during this period, including autism and ADHD, and altered brain development at this early stage may increase risk for later-onset disorders such as schizophrenia. This project will provide new insights into the developmental origins of psychi- atric disease and inspire an exciting new line of research focused on preventing psychiatric conditions through very early intervention in at-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although sexual and gender minorities (SGM) experience among the largest mental health disparities of any population, evidence-based mental health practice specifically targeting this population's distinct stressors and stress responses has been unavailable until recently. Now that LGBTQ-affirmative CBT has shown effectiveness across several trials and generated high demand, implementation science is needed to determine optimal nationwide implementation strategies. This study will identify optimal means through which to implement this treatment innovation in the US's large network of LGBTQ community centers, thereby producing generalizable guidance for EBP implementation across low-resource settings nationwide in which mental health disparities populations are likely to seek treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent suicide and suicidality have increased in recent years, which parallels the advent and rapid growth of social media use in adolescents’ daily lives. The proposed study will be the first in a broader program of research that leverages smartphone technology to examine how social media use impacts risk for the development and worsening of suicidal ideation and behavior among adolescents. This research program aims to identify modifiable risk factors, including social media use and sleep disruption, for adolescent suicide risk, and ultimately, contribute to the development of interventions that are personalized, scalable, and delivered in real time to prevent suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of our company is to improve the lives of individuals with upper limb loss (ULL). In this project, we hope to empower the user by enabling improved control over their prosthesis. Specifically, this project is focused on a system to allow the user to start training for how to contract their residual muscles in order to generate signals which are sensed and interpreted by their prosthesis in order to drive the motors which control it. This is particularly important since currently there is not a system which is available to individuals before their prosthesis is fabricated, and this is the very time period in which training is the most valuable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to a narrow band of green light (nbGL) is capable of reducing headache intensity, photophobia and anxiety caused by a migraine attack. The proposed studies will provide insight to how nbGL affects the hyperexcitable cortex in (a) ictal and (b) interictal migraineurs; the non- hyperexcitable cortex in (c) healthy controls; and in a widely studied animal model of migraine. If successful, it will provide a mechanistic basis for a novel therapeutic approach that is not invasive, risk-free, and affordable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aim of this research is to reveal the fundamental mechanisms that underlie comprehension of spoken language. An understanding of how speech is coded in the brain has significant implications for the development of new diagnostic and rehabilitative strategies for language disorders (e.g. aphasia, dyslexia, autism, et alia). Abnormal perception of phonemes is a central component to language disability in all of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative processes translating major to to identify genetic and epigenetic variation provide powerful insight into the molecular that cause addiction and other diseases of the central nervous system (CNS). However, genetic- and epigenetic-level insights into therapies that treat substance abuse remains a challenge. Here, we will exploit the chemistry of pharmacophores found in psychoactive drugs study the impact of genetic variants and epigenetic modifications in addiction. Tools Measuring changes in protein activity in mouse models of vaping addiction will identify targets for anti-addiction drugs to treat this growing epidemic.

PHR: Project Narrative      There is a critical need for better understanding of molecular events underlying gliomagenesis, a process leading to  most  aggressive  primary  brain  tumors.  miR- 10b  emerged  as  a  common  regulator  involved  in  neoplastic  transformation  of  glial  cells,  glioma  growth,  and  survival.  This  project  will  investigate  epigenetic  mechanisms  of  miR- 10b activation in the brain and thereby advance our understanding of brain tumors and may open the door for  new therapeutic approaches.

PHR: Cancer treatments are complex, potentially toxic, and expensive to deliver. This new training program for pre and postdoctoral trainees focuses on preparing scientists from diverse disciplines to become independent investigators to conduct cancer care delivery research that will ultimately improve the care experience for patients with cancer. With the support of their mentors, formal coursework, selected emphasis activities, and professional socialization, trainees will acquire skills in descriptive discovery research, intervention development and testing, and implementation science to address gaps in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed center, ASPIRES, addresses a public health problem of highest importance, youth suicide. The health care system has been identified as an optimal location for suicide prevention, but lack of prevention strategies universally integrated into routine health care is an obstacle to reducing the rate of youth suicide. ASPIRES will facilitate integrated research studies of high impact, applying innovative sustainable practice- based research methods with strong potential to address national suicide prevention priorities and help to achieve the aspirational goal of rapidly reducing youth suicide in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Our results point to mature neutrophils recruited to the tumor microenvironment suppressing the expansion and activation of T cells required for anti-tumor immunity. This suppressor activity was dependent on a number of neutrophil functions, including complement signaling, a therapeutically targetable pathway. The impact of our proposal is to gain safety and preliminary efficacy data on APL-2-based regimens in recurrent epithelial ovarian cancer with malignant effusions and a detailed understanding of how these regimens modulate the immune landscape in the tumor microenvironment.

The Methods Core (MC) is essential to that process in promoting the advancement and application of rigorous and innovative methods to test and evaluate the impact and implementation of these evidence-based interventions. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The DS-CHANGE training program builds upon long-standing collaborations between Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST), the University of Washington (UW), Seattle Children’s Hospital, and the non-profit Smile Train. We propose to (i), develop a cadre of trained Ghanaian scientists who can use data science approaches to tackle prominent child health problems, (ii) build faculty and institutional capacity for data science at KNUST, and (iii) develop competencies to ensure Ghanaian biomedical data science teams work effectively and synergistically. Trainees will develop skills and acquire experience with real world data science problems that address 3 of the top 10 ten causes of child death and disability in Ghana: malaria, injury and congenital malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many researchers use DNA sequencing to study disease and biology, and analyzing this data requires sophisticated software capable of piecing together puzzles made of billions of fragments of DNA. The main strategy used to assemble the puzzle — aligning sequencing reads to a genome — suffers from “reference bias” which causes it to give incorrect answers downstream. Here we propose a suite of new methods, visualizations, software tools, and genome representations that help researchers to analyze sequencing data while avoiding the perils of reference bias. ii

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative With this proposal we seek to prevent an imminent public health concern, suicidal behavior (SB), among exceedingly vulnerable 6- to 9-year-old children whose parents have a history of suicide attempt (PH+). Through both genetic and familial mechanisms, these children are at especially high risk of NSSI and SB including suicide attempts, however, no prevention programs exist for young children in PH+ families. We will use an established prevention program to address family-and child-level mediators of SB and NSSI and evaluate parental and clinician acceptability, feasibility, and effectiveness on reducing suicide risk factors in highly vulnerable youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The suicide rate in U.S. adolescents has increased 75% during the past decade, but scientifically supported interventions do not exist to prevent adolescent suicide during high-risk healthcare transition periods. To address this gap, we will develop and test a safe firearm storage suicide prevention intervention (Safer Still) that has considerable capacity for future widespread use. Successful completion of this study will contribute to the NIH’s mission to support evaluation of innovative interventions to prevent firearm injury and mortality, which will have direct community benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma is the most common and lethal brain cancer, and one key mechanism by which it develops resistance to chemotherapy involves defects in a DNA repair pathway called mismatch repair (MMR). There are currently no treatments proven to be effective against these especially aggressive MMR-deficient glioblastomas. The work of this proposal investigates two new therapeutic strategies against these cancers: 1) combining inhibitors of different calcium channels, and 2) repurposing the chemotherapy drug irinotecan and the anti- cholesterol statin drugs as novel inhibitors of the TGF-β signaling pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide rates for U.S. adolescents are at the highest levels in over a decade, while access to psychiatric hospitalization to treat youth at acute risk is decreasing, despite the increasing demand for this higher level of care. To address the need for additional treatment options, we will examine a brief, evidence-based alternative to inpatient psychiatric care (Intensive Crisis Intervention, ICI) that has the potential for widespread community use. This research is consistent with NIMH’s priorities for high-impact practice-based research with near-term potential to address NIMH suicide prevention priorities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying the role of the microbiome-gut-brain axis in the pathogenesis of child-onset anxiety at the mechanistic level of microbe-epithelial interactions and enteroneuroactivity. Once these interactions are fully described, there is the potential for a significant advancement in the mental and overall health of children with anxiety and neurodevelopmental disabilities by deepening our understanding of the necessity of microbes in early life neurobehavioral development. Thus, the project is relevant to NICHD’s mission because it pertains to enhancing the lives of children and understanding child development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The purpose of this research proposal is to study the role of chromatin dynamics in genome regulation and cell fate decisions. The proposed research is relevant to public health because many of the proteins studied are mutated in human cancers, including pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors and pediatric glioblastomas. Understanding the normal physiology of these proteins will lead to greater insights and therapeutic opportunities in disease states.

PHR: Through the high quality gene expression data it has generated, ImmGen has become an important resource in Immunology research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Meiosis is the process that generates eggs and sperm necessary for sexual reproduction. For reasons not completely understood, meiosis in females is highly error prone, leading to infertility, miscarriage, and birth defects. The long-term goal of this grant is to understand how meiosis occurs in eggs to shed light on why this process frequently goes awry in females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Based on our novel preliminary data we have identified pharmacologic inhibitors that can inhibit polarization of macrophages towards the proangiogenic M2-type population, which has been associated with progression of CNV. We hypothesize that selective pharmacologic inhibition of M2-type macrophage polarization can block CNV. Here, we will systematically test identified kinase and non-kinase inhibitors of M2-type macrophage polarization for their selectivity in blocking M2-type macrophage polarization and consequently CNV, with the aim to establish novel drugs for the treatment of neovascular AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The United States opioid epidemic started in 1999 and continues to grow, and in 2019, opioid induced respiratory depression – a severe slowing and shallowing of breathing – caused ~130 deaths per day. Our goal is to first identify the key neurons that opioids target to stop breathing and then to determine exactly what opioids do to them. This work will provide a platform for future studies to design and discover novel ways to prevent death from opioid overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed a non-infectious, self-replicative SARS-CoV-2 replicon system that is a safe and effective tool for antiviral screening and amenable to genetic engineering for studying drug resistance. We have identified a small molecule inhibitor of SARS-CoV-2 antiviral activity, and early medicinal chemistry efforts have optimized this lead. This project aims to further identify and characterize compounds toward the development of novel inhibitors against SARS-CoV-2 with potent, nanomolar antiviral activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Living cells contain organelles which have specific functions related to their characteristic shapes and sizes. Our proposed research program will elucidate the design principles required for these organelles to maintain their size while sharing a common pool of their building blocks. A quantitative understanding of molecular mechanisms affecting organelle growth will accelerate the development of new therapies to combat many diseases like Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) and neurodegenerative disorders like Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The repair of DNA breaks by homologous recombination is essential for meiosis, the cellular process that produces sperm and eggs. This proposal addresses a critical gap in our understanding of the molecular processes responsible for ensuring crossing over between homologous chromosomes. Defects in meiotic recombination are associated with infertility, pregnancy loss, congenital disease and ovarian insufficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying genetic effects on complex traits is a critical step in the quest to establish causal mechanisms. Our research program focuses on identifying and quantifying the genetic basis of developmental differences in the human brain during adolescence, using unbiased approaches for identifying associated genes, determining genetic relationships, and profiling the impact of genetic predisposition for diseases in longitudinal Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) data. Our proposal utilizes innovative approaches to achieve the analytic goals and reduce the risks of spurious associations from admixed and related participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson’s disease (PD) and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) are irreversible neurodegenerative diseases with limited disease-modifying therapeutics. During the course of these diseases, cerebrovascular changes have been documented by brain imaging, histological, and transgenic mouse studies, however early changes in cerebrovascular gene expression during sporadic human disease with cell type-specificity and whole genome- resolution are not known; thus, the causal role of cerebrovascular dysfunction on disease progression is not established and represents an underexplored therapeutic target. The goals of this project are to characterize early cerebrovascular dysfunction using unbiased transcriptomic profiling of post-mortem brain tissue from PD and ALS patients, and establish whether iPSC-derived models of the cerebrovasculature mimic disease phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance The Upstate Carolina Consortium will engage community physicians to participate in NCI supported, cancer care delivery research, treatment, prevention and cancer control trials. Upstate Carolina Consortium serves a large rural, minority, and underserved population and is committed to increasing NCI clinical trial access and participation among this population that will reduce cancer disparities and the burden of cancer. The Consortium’s goal is to support practice-changing cancer prevention, treatment and cancer control research that will improve patient outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: High-risk corneal transplantation, performed in inflamed host graft beds, is characterized by swift and often irreversible immune rejection. While tens of thousands of these are performed annually on a global basis, there has been no significant change in these poor outcomes for decades. This grant proposes to study the function of regulatory T cells in the development of immunity to high-risk corneal transplants and develop novel strategies to promote tolerance and long-term survival of these grafts without use of toxic immunosuppressive medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, exposure to sociopolitical violence represents a serious threat to child and family development and wellbeing, yet research on care for these populations has yielded few rigorous, RCT evaluations of programs, overall small treatment effects, and a dearth of family-based approaches to care (Cummings et al., 2017; Jordans et al., 2016). The proposed research is relevant to public health in low-& middle-income countries because it provides a rigorous test of an innovative, evidence-based and cost-effective intervention that is readily scalable to support better family functioning, tests mechanisms of effect and pathways of intervention for program impact, and evaluates organizational factors contributing to program effects, all in the context of an RCT designed clinical trial. This proposal is in response to RFA-MH-21-160, and is specifically relevant to NIMH’s mission because it contributes to the understanding of mental health problems in youth and contributes to prevention and intervention by utilizing a family-systems approach to improving the family environment, which is a crucial developmental context with implications for mental health and processes underlying adjustment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to pilot test a group-based physical activity intervention for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention that harnesses components of social support, sense of belonging, and social connectedness to reduce social isolation and loneliness among reintegrating veterans following military service. The proposed training and research program will outfit the candidate with expertise necessary for conducting community- engaged research and mixed methods study design to conduct behavioral randomized control trials, both critical for the addressing the growing public health epidemic of social isolation and loneliness. Findings from the proposed studies may have significant implications on how to reduce social isolation and loneliness, and related CVD biomarkers (i.e., blood pressure) at a magnitude to drive long-term health benefits among vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of this MIRA research renewal proposal is to discern the cellular mechanisms that govern nucleic acid-induced immune activation. We investigate the functions of cellular RNA binding proteins and how their regulation of host or pathogenic transcripts impact the innate immune response or modulate viral replication. We also seek to understand the mechanisms by which the central DNA sensor-triggered pathway elicits its activity in activating an immunologic transcriptional response; overactivation of this pathway causes autoimmune disorders, whereas under-activation can lead to reduced immune fitness and tumor immunosurveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the mechanisms by which pupil-linked arousal modulates information processing in the brain. Dysregulation of the pupil-linked arousal system has been implicated in major clinical disorders, including schizophrenia, Parkinson’s disease, and depression, evidenced by abnormal pupil dynamics reported in individuals with the disorders. Therefore, the results of the proposed project will contribute to the knowledge base, potentially leading to more effective diagnosis and improved treatment of the disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal describes a novel technological approach towards portable electroanalysis that merges modular chemically-precise sensing materials with seamless device integration on porous and flexible substrates. The molecular design relies on conductive porous scaffolds that serve as ultra-sensitive hosts and transducers for physiologically-relevant guests within electronic devices. Conceptual and technological advances emerging from this work will enhance the development of modular bioanalytical systems with potential impact in monitoring quality control of engineered tissue and wearable electronics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate immune systems provide critical defenses against microbial infections and are composed of both ancient and newly evolved proteins. To understand where our immune pathways came from and how they integrate new components, we study antibacterial responses in eukaryotes found across the Tree of Life. These diverse immune systems promise to yield new antimicrobials and to reveal how innate immune defenses can change over evolutionary time.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Many infectious diseases that harm humans originate from wildlife. This research will collect viral genome and gastrointestinal parasite data from red colobus monkeys, other nonhuman primates, and humans at Kibale National Park (Uganda) and develop new statistical analysis methods to quantify what conditions allow viruses to spread within and between the species that share the ecosystem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Using data driven and computational approaches we will reveal fundamental mechanisms underlying viral infection, focusing on model systems that give insight into early, dynamic infection processes in diverse tissues, organisms, pathogens, and disease backgrounds. Gene networks and synergistic gene interactions causally related to infection will be inferred using our novel computational tools, thus uncovering signatures of protection and providing an invaluable resource for the community. The proposal promises to build approaches applicable across biological systems and processes, change our mechanistic understanding of viral infection, and, in the future, support therapeutic design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a common condition associated with high morbidity and very limited effective treatment options. Our HeartShare Clinical Center Team will leverage experience and expertise in cardiac imaging, exercise-based evaluation, omics-based research, bioinformatics, and geriatrics to comprehensively characterize HFpEF subtypes and advance our understanding of new treatment priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing anti-migraine agents produce unpleasant side effects, worsen headache with repeated use, and innovation in the development of new anti-migraine treatments with novel mechanisms of action has been minimal. To solve this problem, we developed new dual inhibitors of soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH) and fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH) to increase the levels of anti-inflammatory and analgesic metabolites in headache- relevant regions of the body, and, in this proposal, we will conduct rigorous structure-activity relationship studies, biological evaluation, chemical optimization, and behavioral testing of our dual inhibitors. Through in vitro and in vivo studies, our studies will reveal the utility of inhibiting two pain-related enzymes and provide the first steps towards the discovery and validation of novel sEH/FAAH-based anti-migraine treatments for human.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This investigation aims to enhance understanding of the association between childhood economic conditions and both risk and protective factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in adulthood. Results of this study will inform prevention and intervention efforts aimed at reducing CVD risk, by delineating childhood exposures that increase and buffer adult cardiometabolic health risk. Moreover, by testing novel contextual pathways at the family, school, and neighborhood levels this investigation will help to identify contexts that can be targeted by programs and policies to reduce socioeconomic disparities in adult health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This is a broadly based predoctoral training program in Neuroscience with the objective of providing individualized, high quality training to predoctoral students interested in pursuing scientific careers in the biological and biomedical sciences. The program includes a focused emphasis on training in quantitative thinking and experimental design and analysis and would support students in their first two years of graduate studies, before they start their dissertation research. We request 8 predoctoral training slots for students in their first two years of our program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is common and impairing, our lack of knowledge about the mechanisms underlying co-occurring depression in people with ASD hinders clinical care and effective treatments. This K23 seeks to address this gap, defining brain mechanisms associated with depressive symptoms in adolescents with ASD compared to controls, leveraging multimodal imaging methods (resting- state functional magnetic resonance imaging, diffusion spectrum imaging, and myelin imaging). This work is significant because it will create the foundation for future studies defining how the brain mechanisms of co- occurring depressive disorders in individuals with ASD change across development, and, ultimately, to develop novel brain-targeted treatments for depression in people with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than two-thirds of older adults are living with symptomatic cardiovascular disease. Many live with undiagnosed geriatric syndromes including phenotypic frailty and lack of physical resilience. This research proposal will enhance our understanding of the influence of geriatric syndromes on health outcomes, disability, and health-related quality of life among older adults with acute myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Specific neuron subtypes in the primate neocortex are implicated in neurodegenerative disorders. These neurons express unique complements of ion channels and neuromodulator receptors in primates. In this fundamental research project, we test the consequences of the cell type-specific expression of these genes on neuronal input-output properties in key brain regions in both human and non-human primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fungal diseases are a major threat to human health, and cryptococcosis, caused by Cryptococcus, kills nearly 200,000 people each year. This program will take a multidisciplinary approach to define the effects of a small peptide molecule produced by Cryptococcus and its target enzyme on the outcomes of this lethal fungal infection with the intent of developing insights on the infection process and to develop novel treatments to fight the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The M4I: Maryland Infection, Immunization, Intervention, and Impact Training Program provides structured training and robust mentorship to inspire and prepare the next generation of infectious disease researchers. We will enroll a diverse group of medical students to establish a cohort of trainees who will participate in formal research training and develop a hypothesis-driven research project with the support of their faculty mentors, methodological experts, and their peers. They will continue to work together as a longitudinal research track cohort for their medical school career, with opportunities to receive additional funding for research electives or an MD/Master’s dual degree program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to build a more comprehensive understanding of the genetic architecture of Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias, taking into account the complexities of age-related changes and diverse phenotypes. By leveraging large-scale biobanks, electronic medical records, and innovative machine learning techniques, we hope to uncover crucial insights that could lead to better understanding of disease progression, improved prevention strategies and novel therapeutic targets, representing a signiﬁcant advancement in dementia research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Congenital cardiac anomalies represent the most common birth defect, affecting nearly 1% of all live births and despite significant advances in their surgical and medical management, these conditions remain a leading cause of death and disability in the newborn period. One significant source of morbidity and mortality arises from complications associated with the use of currently available prosthetic vascular grafts, cardiovascular patches, and replacement heart valves that are frequently required to perform reconstructive procedures. Tissue engineering offers a potential strategy for creating improved biomaterials for use in congenital heart surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) is an extremely important public health problem with increasing incidence, especially in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-infected individuals. However, the role that HIV immunosuppression plays in the development of HPV-OPSCCs is poorly understood, and currently, there is no animal model for HPV-induced oral infections and malignancies in the context of HIV-induced immunosuppression. The studies we propose will characterize and establish a needed rhesus macaque model of persistent oral HPV and HIV co-infection using Macaca mulatta papillomavirus type 1 (MmPV1) and simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) that will be foundational for future research into the mechanisms of oral MmPV1 infections, persistence, precancer, and OPSCC induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary care clinicians are rarely part of the multi-disciplinary survivorship care delivered by oncology teams, despite National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines and National Academy of Medicine reports recommending that cancer survivors stay connected with their primary care clinicians. Leveraging our team’s program of research in primary care and cancer survivorship care delivery, we will conduct a pragmatic trial testing implementation and effectiveness of a survivorship care delivery intervention among eight Community Health Center sites across Texas. Guided by theory-based conceptual models to maximize the likelihood of successful implementation and sustainment within each local context, our evaluation will generate rich and actionable lessons to scale this generalist primary care-based care delivery model to improve cancer survivorship care equitably.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Evidence is mounting that neuronal hyperexcitability during the progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), can initiate decades prior to canonical memory loss and associated neuropathology. This proposal will model the dynamic relationship between hyperexcitation/hyperarousal and protein build up of tau and amyloid to understand how selective brain areas, like the locus coeruleus, are impacted early in disease. It will also demonstrate how this can lead to hippocampal dysfunction causing cognitive loss and will attempt to reverse pathological phenotypes by treating proteostasis deficits and ameliorating early stage neuronal hyperexcitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Rural cancer survivors experience a higher risk of negative health outcomes and require coordinated care to address the many effects of cancer and its treatment. Primary care providers recognize the importance of providing high-quality, evidence-based survivorship care and are well-positioned to meet survivor needs, however, these needs are often unmet due to limitations in knowledge, lack of resources, and administrative demands. Practical strategies are needed to assist PCPs to improve cancer survivorship care and this proposal will test implementation strategies to optimize the adoption of evidence-based practices for cancer survivorship care in rural primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: New biomaterials are revolutionizing how therapies are delivered to the body, yet these technologies have not been widely used for improving vessel growth and muscle function in patients who have suffered a heart attack. This project addresses this gap and many challenges in the heart by advancing customized vessel growth and muscle therapies using biomaterials with the goals of improving the blood supply in the heart, adding new heart muscle cells, and improving electrical and mechanical function of the heart. Experiments to help us understand how changes in heart function happen in response to these new biomaterial therapies will increase our understanding of the critical design features of the therapies to advance translation to the clinic for improving patient health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Underdiagnosis and undertreatment is a major problem in childhood asthma management, especially in preschool-aged children. Current prognostic approaches using risk-score based tools have poor-to-modest accuracy, are impractical, and have limited evidence of efficacy in clinical settings and hence are not widely used in practice. This award will support the candidate’s training in how to apply novel biostatistical and machine learning methodologies to pre-existing electronic health records prognostic data to develop a childhood asthma passive digital marker that can provide a timely, accurate, user-centered, and scalable approach for childhood asthma prognosis at point of care to address existing barriers associated with the use of risk-score based tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tears are common, affecting over 20% of the general population, with a high incidence of retear after repair, ranging between 30% to 94%. Arthroscopic 3D bioprinting is a potential high impact medical treatment, where a tendon can be “spot welded” to the bone during repair to enhance healing and reduce the incidence of retear. The objective of this proposal is to develop an arthroscopic 3D bioprinter.

PHR: The Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity (MoTrPAC) project will define the molecular changes that occur during exercise and following exercise training. The identification of which molecules change with exercise and training may allow us to find ways to enhance or mimic the broad beneficial effects of exercise on a person’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Prolonged or intensive physical activity has a profound effect on the lipid profiles of a variety of organs and bodily fluids. Lipidomics technologies enable these lipid changes to be accurately mapped to yield a more complete scientific understanding of how exercise affect lipids as fuels, signaling messengers and structural molecules. We will continue to serve as the MoTrPAC Chemical Analysis Site devoted to both targeted and untargeted lipidomic studies using mass spectrometry technologies, and the associated data science and bioinformatic efforts to integrate the multiomic datasets being created by the Consortium.

PHR: Project Narrative While physical activity prevents or improves many diseases, the chemical changes that occur in the body and lead to better health are not well known. As a part of a consortium of physical activity research programs working together, we will use advanced technologies to comprehensively study the changes in genes and gene products caused by physical activity. This study can potentially lead to advances in preventing and treating many diseases using physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection remain at increased risk of head and neck cancers due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, despite adequate management of their HIV with antiretroviral therapy (ART). This project explores the hypothesis that ART increases susceptibility to oral HPV infection by damaging the integrity of the oral mucosal tissue. Understanding if ART plays a role in enhancing risk of oral HPV infection is crucial to develop new intervention strategies to prevent HPV-mediated head and neck cancers in people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training. with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: INSTITUTO DE EFECTIVIDAD CLINICA Y SANIT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE LMICs’ research institutions are limited in institutional competitiveness and productivity due to scarcity of resources to set well-functioning research administration operations. Strengthening administrative infrastructure to support grant application preparation, submission, and management in the South American region is a challenge to equitable research that needs to be addressed. Good research management provides assistance to researchers in finding funding, guides them through the complexity of funders requirements and procedures, generates tools, and ensures compliance with research good practices. The introduction of good business practices for managing awards; and assisting the administrative staff in developing and implementing standard operating procedures, will result in more efficient and transparent funded-projects management, as well as increased compliance with NIH grant policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell disorder that accounts for ~10% of all hematologic malignancies. Proteasome inhibitors (PIs) in combination with other agents represent a major strategy for MM treatment, however rapidly developing resistance to PIs renders MM a largely incurable disease. In a current proposal we will characterize novel mechanisms revealing metabolic vulnerabilities of MM cells and novel agents that can exploit such vulnerabilities for MM treatment.

PHR: Narrative The ESTEEMED program at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T) will significantly increase the production of high achieving graduates who pursue advanced degrees in the biomedical sciences and diversify the STEM workforce. The program will use a persistence framework that combines an academic support system, early research experiences and mentoring, collaborative learning, and intrusive advising to cultivate the science identity of underrepresented minority students. The implementation of the goals, objectives and aims of the NC A&T ESTEEMED program will produce a stream of minority Ph.D. bioengineers and biomedical scientists who will address biomedical issues through the development of new and innovative technologies and cutting-edge research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative (3-sentence limit) This proposal aims to develop new technologies for rapid (1 min/dose; over 10 doses per hour) production of exogenous contrast agents for molecular imaging of cellular metabolism in vivo. Our overall goal is to develop clinical-scale production technology for preparation of non-radioactive hyperpolarized [1-13C]pyruvate (already in evaluation in nearly 30 clinical trials) that probes aberrant energy metabolism in a manner similar to FDG PET but with the added benefits of 1-minute scan time and no ionizing radiation. We will also validate the new contrast agent production technology in feasibility studies with cellular models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine phosphatases are emerging as an important class of enzymes in cancer signaling, and many members of this enzyme family could be fruitful drug targets for precision medicines and immunotherapies. While genetic evidence supports a role for many tyrosine phosphatases in cancer etiology and therapeutic response, it has been technically challenging to obtain detailed knowledge of the specific cellular functions of these proteins. In this project, we will develop a robust protein engineering strategy to identify direct substrates of individual tyrosine phosphatases in live cells, thereby allowing us to pinpoint specific biochemical functions across this important enzyme family.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need for powerful and effective statistical tools to determine the most important risk factors of mental illness, especially as the list of potential risk factors grows. The proposed research will develop guidelines and freely-available online applications to allow researchers to use novel Bayesian variable selection methods to overcome current challenges to reliably predict mental illness. These methods are then applied to understand important predictors of Obsessive Compulsive Disorder symptoms in a large sample of adults across the lifespan. The findings of this research can inform efforts to identify and intervene to help at risk individuals to ultimately reduce the burden of mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE Mood disorders, including depression, and loss of motivation are extremely common and debilitating in people with HIV, despite effective antiretroviral therapy. These disorders are likely to be related to changes in systemic and/or brain iron metabolism. This study will use new and state-of-the-art brain imaging techniques to measure brain iron in people with and without HIV infection and determine its contributions to depressive and other mood- related symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Catalytic Processes for Stereoselective Radical Cyclization Reactions  In modern pharmaceutical industry, where the market share of single enantiomer chiral drugs continues to rise, there are growing demands for developing practical and economical methods for the enantioselective synthesis of biologically and pharmaceutically important carbocyclic and heterocyclic compounds in an enantioenriched or enantiopure form. Compared to a racemic mixture, the use of an enantiomerically pure compound improves the desired bioactivity and while reducing toxicity because enantiomeric isomers often exhibit different biological activities. For drug discovery and development, it is desirable to prepare both enantiomers of a new chiral drug candidate for testing their separate activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Almost a million patients undergo open heart surgery annually in the US, and implantation of temporary epicardial pacing leads is the standard of care for patients undergoing cardiac surgery to provide on-demand pacing the heart should arrhythmias such as bradycardias occur. The current temporary epicardial pacing suffers from two severe limitations: 1) The traumatic implantation and removal of the pacing lead, and 2) inflammatory response induced lead-tissue fibrosis and resultant early device failure. Here we propose to develop a new epicardial pacing device in a form of an electrically conductive bioadhesive (e-bioadhesive) patch that prevents cardiac trauma and fibrous capsule, which could greatly improve safety in the perioperative period for vulnerable patients.
