IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are a major class of transmembrane receptors responsible for recognition of a large class of diverse ligands and are major targets of therapeutic drugs. Here we propose a comprehensive analysis of mechanisms for GPCR-dependent regulation of downstream signaling processes. We expect to reveal novel signaling mechanisms with broad implications for GPCR signaling in general, and new paradigms for adrenergic regulation of cardiac function and failure, that have the potential to drive development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products chemistry and organic synthesis are two enabling disciplines that fuel the engine of small- molecule drug discovery. These fields impact existing pharmaceutical agents, compounds currently in the clinical pipeline heading toward approved therapeutics, and basic research to develop the improved drugs of tomorrow. In our research program (i) we provide new knowledge about the structures of natural products as well as an understanding of how they are created by their producing organisms and (ii) we develop new paradigms that researchers can use for the synthesis of novel compounds having potential as new, clinically relevant drug candidates. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study seeks to examine the combined effect of lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd), mercury (Hg), perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS), and perfluorinated alkylated substances (PFOA) on stress, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and CVD mortality. The primary analysis will include: (1) assessing the effects of Pb, Cd, Hg, PFOA, and PFOS exposures on individual and neighborhood stress and (2) determining the effects of Pb, Cd, Hg, PFOA, and PFOS exposures on CVD risk and mortality. This study will help close the gap in knowledge of the effects of multiple environmental pollutants on stress and cardiovascular health and will further our understanding of the role that the social environment and the physical environment pose for potentially serious health risks to individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project builds on a growing body of evidence that supports an association between periodontitis and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD). By assessing clinical and microbial features of periodontitis in a longitudinal manner, along with key elements of the inflammatory response, within an established, rigorously developed diverse community-based aging study in Northern Manhattan, we have the unique opportunity to investigate a potentially causal association between periodontitis and incident ADRD, assessed through a comprehensive battery of neuropsychological tests, as well as through established neuroimaging and fluid biomarkers of AD. Given that a substantial proportion of AD cases occurs in the absence of established risk factors other than aging, and that periodontitis is largely preventable and treatable, identification of a novel, modifiable risk factor for AD would be extremely valuable from a public health standpoint and would influence the design of early intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chest pain is one of this nation’s most serious and ubiquitous public health problems, yet the 12-lead ECG is only diagnostic for a small subset of patients with underlying acute myocardial infarction. We have developed and validated novel, machine learning-based, ECG interpretation algorithms that could identify patients with acute myocardial infarction, and now we aim to expand and build these intelligent models at the bedside for prospective validation and real-time clinical deployment. Deploying this system at the bedside has the potential to impact care of more than 2 million patients evaluated annually for chest pain in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mobile genetic elements provide an accessory genome for microbial populations that can help microbes survive assaults such as antibiotic treatment and viral infection. The machinery encoded by such elements to promote their own transfer and maintenance provides a rich source of novel enzymes that are interesting as examples of how fundamental DNA-related manipulations can occur, and that are a potential source of new biotechnology tools. Our work focuses on the mechanistic and structural understanding of mobile element-encoded machinery, which has lagged far behind bioinformatics in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use and related disorders are a global public health issue. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), alcohol consumption ranks as a leading risk factor for disease burden and in 2016, alcohol use resulted in 7.2% of all premature deaths, with young people being disproportionately affected. Specialized training is required to tackle this immense problem, particularly as it relates to clinical research. This proposal focuses on providing this training to pre- and postdoctoral fellows working with faculty at San Diego State University and the University of California San Diego.

PROJECT_TITLE: Alcohol Research in the Science/Practitioner Model

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Taxane based chemotherapy with docetaxel is an important treatment option for patient with metastatic prostate carcinoma. However, only about half of patients respond and resistance to therapy occurs in all patients. The goals of this proposal are to better understand the in vivo effects of taxanes, to identify biomarkers for improved patient selection, and to develop novel treatments that could extend the utility of docetaxel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tissue mechanics directly regulate numerous cell behaviors involved in development, wound healing, and disease progression. This proposal will develop biomaterials that mimic the dynamic properties of natural tissues to improve our understanding of how cells sense and integrate mechanical signals from their environment. This work should have broad implications for the development of biomaterial therapies to treat disease and promote tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because patients with end-stage ankle osteoarthritis are in general 10 to 15 years younger than patients suffering of knee or hip osteoarthritis, making the likelihood of patients outliving current surgical treatment options a challenging clinical problem. Our contribution here is expected to be a 3D computational study to characterize ankle joint complex osteoarthritis by quantifying anatomical shape variation through Statistical Shape Modeling of the tibiotalar and subtalar joints. This new and substantially different approach to computationally evaluate ankle morphometrics is expected to allow us to overcome the current limitations of clinical radiographic evaluation of ankle joint complex osteoarthritis, thereby opening new horizons for more quantifiable methods to aid in treatment planning for patients with end-stage ankle osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), or chronic lung disease of prematurity, is the most common major morbidity of premature birth. Despite an absence of clinical research evidence to support its use, the diuretic furosemide is commonly used to treat infants with severe BPD, the worst disease severity class. This proposal seeks to address fundamental knowledge gaps in our understanding of furosemide treatment strategies in severe BPD, in order to subsequently design definitive clinical trials to support or reject its use in this vulnerable infant population.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, obesity) are a costly, pervasive problem for older adults, accounting for 90% of Medicare spending. This project will test the ability of voice-controlled "smart" technology to expand the implementation and sustain the use of a proven electronic health system (Elder Tree, or ET) for these patients; specifically, we hypothesize that older adults using ET delivered by a smart system (smart speaker plus smart display) will use and benefit from ET more than patients who access ET through a laptop because the smart system enables such easy use, even by those who have a tremor, poor vision, difficulty getting to a laptop, or other side-effects of aging. If successful, this smart system-delivered eHealth intervention will make ET more accessible and effective for older patients, improve their quality of life, and point the way to more impactful delivery of future eHealth innovations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using Smart Devices to Implement an Evidence-based eHealth System for Older Adults

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Translational control is critical for a variety of cellular processes and its dysregulation has been shown to disrupt development and cause many human diseases. Yet the molecular mechanisms that modulate translation, particularly in stem cells, are largely unknown. To achieve a comprehensive understanding of translational control networks, I propose to 1) develop a screening approach for studying translation that combines CRISPR with polysome profiling; 2) apply this approach to discover pathways that regulate global translation levels in stem cells; and 3) investigate selective mRNA translation using ribosome profiling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Minnesota-KPMP will recruit and follow-up study participants with chronic kidney disease due to diabetes or hypertension, the most common causes of chronic kidney disease, plus participants with type 1 diabetes who do not have clinical manifestations of kidney disease despite long diabetes duration. Underserved and underrepresented populations are disproportionately affected by chronic kidney disease, and the Minnesota- KPMP will engage a diverse patient population to evaluate and address barriers to enrollment in KPMP and to elicit the perspectives of our local participants on ethical issues posed by the KPMP, such as return of results and biobank governance. In a highly diverse metropolitan area actively confronting racism and disparities, this will add significantly to KPMP community engagement and ethics.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease prevention in Central America requires understanding how social determinants and place-based factors influence cardiovascular risk across the lifespan. It is critical to train and mentor the local workforce in identifying research questions relevant to CVD prevention, in the use of appropriate research methods to answer them, and in the dissemination of results to the scientific community, the public, and policy makers. Building on an established collaboration between INCAP and Drexel University, our training program will develop the research capabilities of trainees from the region and to build local capacity in the conduct of policy-relevant research on social determinants of cardiovascular risk across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This research is aimed at understanding whether vasomotor symptoms and sleep problems, major symptoms of menopause, are associated with declines in cognitive and brain health over time in women. Findings from this study can improve the understanding of the role of these symptoms in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and cognitive decline in women. They can point to female-specific markers that, if treated, may ultimately be able to be used to improve cognition, enhance brain reserve, and reduce the risk for AD in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy to treat Alzheimer’s disease (AD) by eliminating senescent astrocytes that contribute to inflammation and neurodegeneration. We will achieve this by determining the role of the glycolytic by-product methylglyoxal in driving astrocyte senescence and neurodegeneration in AD. These studies will develop novel therapeutic targets to inhibit cellular senescence in the brain and reduce the risk of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is the mechanistic characterization of enzymes from the human gut microbiome that are involved in polyamine biosynthesis. This project is relevant to public health because polyamine production by gut microbes is associated with disease states such as colon and pancreatic cancer. Enhanced understanding of gut microbe polyamine biosynthesis will open new targets for drug design leading to new treatment options for patients with these cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because redressing the ethical and regulatory barriers to HIV research with pregnant adolescents is crucial to providing safe and effective treatment for prevention and treatment of HIV and coinfections in adolescents and their offspring. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to reduce the burdens of illness and disability, through development of clear ethical and regulatory guidance for the conduct of morally complicated HIV research crucial to effective prevention and treatment of HIV in adolescents. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer deaths in the United States, with 133,000 new cases and 50,000 deaths per year. Thus, it is of critical importance to understand how colorectal cancer progress and metastasize because it is the metastatic disease that kill patients. Here we propose to determine how have an abnormality (called a mutation) in a gene called PTPRT drive colorectal tumor progression and metastasis. Knowledge gained from these studies may lay a foundation to find new ways to treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy to create neural interfaces that simultaneously minimize the electrical, mechanical, and biological mismatch between artificial devices with the nervous system and provide a unique opportunity to achieve long-term, accurate, real-time, and large-scale neural recordings and stimulations free of the foreign body response. Once such strategies have been developed, there is the potential for a significant advance in understanding brain development, disorders, and related behaviors as well as precise treatments to clinical disorders. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge of the nature and behavior of living systems and use it for reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The hormone FGF21 is strongly induced by ethanol in liver and acts on the brain to suppress further alcohol consumption and to maintain hydration. We postulate that through coordinate effects on brain, adipose tissue and liver, FGF21 plays a much broader role in protecting against the harmful effects of alcohol, including liver injury and hypothermia. The proposed studies will provide important insights into the mechanisms whereby FGF21 protects against ethanol-induced toxicity and aid in determining whether FGF21 can be harnessed pharmaceutically to treat alcohol abuse and its associated pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project characterizes the extent to which deamidation promotes deleterious oxidation and dynamics that ultimately lead to cataract-related aggregation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PTEN is the second most commonly altered tumor suppressor in human cancer but the full repertoire of its normal and tumor suppressive functions remains unclear, which is slowing down progress toward improving treatment strategies for a large segment of cancer patients. In preliminary studies we find that the phosphorylation status of the PTEN C-tail domain controls important tumor suppressive functions that provide protection against neoplastic transformation even when PI3K-PDK1-mTORC1 signaling is out of control. The proposed studies are highly significant because the insights gained will lay the foundation for development of new therapeutic interventions that will improve the clinical outcome of cancer patients with PTEN mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated lipid metabolism is a hallmark of epithelial ovarian cancer, which is associated with widespread and rapid metastasis throughout the lipid rich abdominal cavity. A key fact is that epithelial ovarian cancer cells can metabolically reprogram themselves to use other energy sources, such as lipids and fat cells in the abdominal cavity, to sustain their incredibly fast growth, metabolic changes that also help them survive after chemotherapy. We hypothesize that EOC cells store energy in intracellular lipid droplets and under metabolic stress use this stored energy to fuel growth and invasive cell migration; this hypothesis will be explored using a novel 3D culture model to track metabolic changes in chemoresistant EOC cells as well as to study their lipid droplet metabolism and autophagy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activating ERBB2 mutations are enriched in invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) of the breast, suggesting a crosstalk between ERBB2 mutations and the characteristic loss of CDH1 in ILC. Clinical trials have demonstrated promising efficacy using anti-HER2 tyrosine kinase inhibitors in patients with ERBB2 mutant ILC. The ultimate goal of the proposed studies is to characterize the functional roles of recurrent ERBB2 mutations in ILC vs IDC using innovative preclinical models and provide rationale for specific combination targeted therapy in patients with ERBB2 mutant ILC, in order to enhance anti-tumor activity and/or delay drug resistance.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Women and children in sub-Saharan Africa who have a chronic dietary reliance on toxic cyanogenic cassava are at heightened risk for the development of cassava neurotoxicity, leading to a debilitating disease with severe physical and cognitive impairments known as konzo. While factors such as nutrition, toxicity dose, water access and other environmental factors are associated with the development of konzo, the exact molecular mechanisms that contribute to disease pathogenesis remain largely unknown, despite large global health significance. Here we aim to determine the likely modulatory role of the gut microbiome by elucidating differences in composition and functionality in regards to host-microbiome metabolism between disease discordant siblings, leading to a deeper understanding of susceptibility and potential monitoring and preventative solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Distal Symmetric Polyneuropathies (DSP) are highly prevalent among clinic populations in Zambia compared to other world regions and preventable nutritional and other treatable comorbidities are suspected to be contributing. Our study is designed to identify clinic- versus population-based risk factors for DSP in this setting. These studies will help define appropriate intervention targets for nutrition-associated neurologic morbidity in Zambia and frame future observational studies to identify complex pathogenic mechanisms involved in asymptomatic and symptomatic DSP development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is aimed at developing and applying new approaches to understanding how mammalian subcortical brain circuits control evolutionarily conserved naturalistic social behaviors, which may be disrupted in human psychiatric disorders. Our objective is to construct better, high-resolution maps of neural activity dynamics in the brain during social behavior, by imaging from multiple brain sites in a circuit, and using machine learning algorithms (AI) to automatically extract and measure social behavior from video recordings, thereby enabling precise, quantitative correlations between distributed brain activity and behavior. We also propose to examine how intruder sex and behavioral decisions are computed and transformed as they are propagated through the network.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will scale (via a hybrid type 2 stepped wedge randomized effectiveness-implementation trial) and rigorously evaluate an interoperable clinical decision support system (CDS) across our collaborative CDS community for venous thromboembolism prevention. Via mixed-methods, we will study implementation guided by the EPIS implementation framework throughout scaling. Finally, we will pilot an approach for “Living Guideline” development and use that to update and sustain evidenced-based decision logic within a centrally- housed interoperable CDS knowledge repository.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Baccus, Stephen A. The retina and primary visual cortex are complex networks of many cell types. We know little about how the visual cortex processes natural scene information, particularly in the context of behavior. By understanding a detailed a quantitative description of how visual experience is represented in the visual cortex, we will have a better understanding of how this process breaks down in diseases such as amblyopia, strabismus, dyslexia and schizophrenia. Furthermore, by capturing the responses of these neurons under natural visual stimuli with accurate computational models, this research will be immediately applicable to electronic cortical prosthesis systems that aim to restore vision in cases of loss of vision due to damage to the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses mechanisms responsible for proliferation of Cryptococcus neoformans, which is a major fungal pathogen causing infection of the central nervous system in HIV/AIDS patients. C. neoformans requires septin proteins to respond to stress it encounters in the human host and the main goal of this proposal is to explain mechanisms through which septins contribute to pathogenicity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a complex disorder that impairs mobility and cognition in older adults, but often poor mobility may precede and predict Alzheimer’s dementia. Optimizing mobility as a biomarker and determining the pathologies and proteins which drive impaired mobility may explain why this phenotype predicts Alzheimer’s dementia. Targeting the drivers of impaired mobility can lead to new treatments that have the potential to prevent two of the most common concerns of older adults, immobility and Alzheimer’s dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring bouts of mucosal tissue damage and regeneration. This project is expected to identify mechanisms by which nuclear Adenomatous polyposis coli protein promotes mucosal healing through wound repair and restoration of the protective mucus layer. Such knowledge would serve as the basis for future design of novel therapeutic strategies for UC and other IBDs aimed to enhance APC’s wound healing activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to demonstrate the functional and biochemical consequences of a large number of variants of uncertain significance in the gene (KCNQ1) responsible for most cases of the congenital long-QT syndrome (LQTS), a genetic disorder of heart rhythm that carries an elevated risk of sudden death. Results from this study will be used to develop an artificial intelligence method to predict KCNQ1 dysfunction. Our work will enhance the value of genetic testing for LQTS and enable more informed medical decisions regarding this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant proposal is motivated by the need to improve the safety and efficiency of imaging patients with neural implants with MR scanners. 3T MR systems can produce high-resolution images, however, the specific absorption rate (SAR) or the power deposited in patients with metallic implants may cause unsafe tissue heating. The goal of this research, is to extend the use of MRI to patients with conductive implants, who currently cannot be scanned.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our goal is to gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of how external electric brain stimulation impacts the brain at the single-neuron and cell type-specific level. Using a number of techniques such in vitro multipatch electrophysiology and high-density Neuropixels in vivo recordings, this work will enable the design of novel stimulation protocols offering improved selectivity, specificity and efficacy of ES application in rodent and, uniquely, human single-neurons and cell types. Taken together, this effort will develop new and improved ES technologies with potential applications in treatment of neurological disorders such as epilepsy, dementia, and Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The underlying cause of multiple sclerosis (MS) remains elusive and is likely due to a combination of genetics and environmental exposures, with the growing appreciation that environmental factors, such as diet and the gut microbiome contribute to a large degree of the MS susceptibility risk. Alcohol is a common dietary factor used by MS patients and yet, despite its widespread use, potential for abuse and known gut, CNS and immune effects, alcohol’s role in MS is not well understood. The proposed research will begin to define alcohol’s dose-dependent effects in neuroinflammation by examining the immune system and the gut microbiome with the vision of generating hypotheses that can inform the direction and design of future diet studies in EAE and MS and expand the repertoire of available targeted MS probiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that drives climate change and represents an appreciable burden on human and environmental health. A promising route toward mitigating climate change exists in the particulate methane monooxygenase (pMMO), a copper-dependent transmembrane enzyme from methanotrophic bacteria that oxidizes methane to methanol, a desirable biofuel. This project involves the use of innovative membrane mimetics to render pMMO more amenable for study, addressing longstanding questions about this important enzyme and membrane proteins in general, which are underrepresented in structural studies and fundamentally important in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposal seeks to investigate the role of RAS/ERK signaling in sculpting the small non-coding RNA landscape via phosphorylation of Dicer1, Drosha and DIS3 to regulate and coordinate maternal transcriptome and proteome with oocyte-to-embryo transition and embryonic morphogenesis. Because meiosis I and role of RAS signaling is a fundamental and conserved process across metazoans, the knowledge gained from this research has implications to understanding both infertility and birth defects. Additionally, we find that ERK-mediated Dicer1 phosphorylation correlates with aggressive human endometrial cancers and unregulated phosphorylated Dicer1 activity leads to sterility in mouse models, this work will thus also inform mammalian biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Dysfunction of GABAergic inhibitory circuits has been implicated in many neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, such as amblyopia, epilepsy, and schizophrenia. This proposal aims to determine the role of Calbindin, an understudied plasticizing molecule, in reactivating developmental plasticity in adult inhibitory neurons. By elucidating the cell and molecular mechanisms underlying this rejuvenation, our work may open novel therapeutic avenues for brain repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells must activate a telomere lengthening mechanism to ensure proliferation and survival. 15% of cancer cells utilize a telomerase-independent pathway termed the Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT). The deregulation of ADP-ribosylation, a post-translational modification that regulates several cellular processes including transcription, metabolism, and DNA repair, inhibits ALT cancer cell survival. Despite the high importance of ADP-ribosylation as a modification found on proteins, recent groundbreaking studies have established nucleic acids as bona fide substrates of ADP-ribosylation in mammalian cells and this paradigm shift has significant implications for our understanding of the true physiological function of ADP-ribosylation. I identified that telomeres are endogenous cellular targets of DNA ADP-ribosylation and therefore, I seek to characterize the impact on the ALT pathway, as well as the consequences that its perturbation has on cellular physiology and cancer cell survival.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE a-Synuclein accumulates in the brains of Parkinson’s disease patients, and often coincides with immune cell infiltration from circulation into the brain. The proposed study will investigate whether autoreactive T cells targeting a-synuclein infiltrate the brain and contribute to neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration. This study has the potential to implicate autoimmunity as a driver of Parkinson’s disease pathogenesis, and point to potential immunomodulatory therapies for treatment of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal, will generate large integrated omics data sets, tools, and resources (including an integrated clinical research data management and informatics platform) to produce and test hypotheses on mechanisms underlying tissue destruction and healing in celiac disease. It will have a significant positive impact on human health, because it will provide a knowledge basis and resources to develop approaches for individualized patient care, and promote development of new therapeutic strategies for patients with celiac disease. Thus, this work will directly support the NIDDK mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disease, and improve the health of patients with digestive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: CRISPR-based genome editing technologies offer great promise for correcting genetic defects in humans, however, the potential application of this technology to gene therapy has been limited by low in vivo gene correction efficiencies. My group has pioneered high efficiency germline-based CRISPR-based gene-drive and allelic-drive systems that copy cassettes or favored allelic variants in the germline using the homologous chromosome as a DNA repair template. In this proposal, we extend this system to somatic cells analyzing the mechanism for unexpectedly efficient copying of gene cassettes and allelic variants in somatic cells of fruit flies, and human cells (albeit at lower frequencies than in flies), providing a novel system with the potential to transform gene therapy strategies wherein functional sequences on the homolog chromosome are used as a repair template to correct defective alleles.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Every year, approximately 6,800 and 37,000 Black women in the United States die from lung cancer and cardiovascular diseases, respectively. Lung cancer screening with low-dose computed tomography is an evidence-based approach to reduce lung cancer mortality and can be extended to the early detection of cardiovascular diseases. However, most Black women at high risk for lung cancer are currently ineligible for lung cancer screening. The overarching goal of this research is to conduct a single-arm pilot study of U.S. Black women with a history of smoking who may not meet current eligibility criteria to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and performance of LDCT screening for lung cancer detection among this population. In addition, we will validate a deep learning image analysis pipeline for cardiovascular disease detection among this population.

PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating the Feasibility of Lung Cancer Screening in High-Risk Black Women

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to develop new statistical models, methods, algorithms, and software for more effective analysis of microbiome sequencing data collected under a variety of experimental and survey designs. These new statistical tools will not only lead to better prediction of the health outcomes in modern microbiome studies, but also help decipher the roles of microbiome in various diseases and biomedical processes, such as in cancer and urinary tract infections. They will help advance toward the ultimate goal of personalized interventions on the human microbiota of patients to lead to improved health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ED GOAL is a 6-minute motivational interview conducted in the emergency department (ED), which engages seriously ill, yet clinically stable, older adults to address advance care planning (ACP) with their outpatient clinician(s) and avoids a time-consuming, sensitive conversation in the time-pressured ED environment. My NIA GEMSSTAR R03 project established that ED GOAL may increase patients’ engagement in ACP yet identified opportunities for refinement, including improving efficacy by involving caregivers of patients with cognitive impairment, adding care coordination components (hand-off document, etc.) to the outpatient clinicians, and broadening reach by adapting its use by specially-trained nurses. This study will allow me to refine ED GOAL to maximize its potential efficacy and scalability, and to determine the preliminary efficacy of ED GOAL on increasing ACP engagement (by self-report and in the electronic medical record) one month after leaving the ED in a pilot randomized controlled trial (N=120, 60 in each group).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Determining whether treating hearing loss can help reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) is important given that hearing loss is highly prevalent in older adults and hearing aids are widely available, underutilized, and not associated with any medical risk. This proposed follow-up study to the Aging & Cognitive Health Evaluation in Elders (ACHIEVE) randomized trial will determine the long-term, 6-year effects of hearing loss treatment on cognitive, dementia, and brain outcomes among 977 older adults with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Blood clots are a top contributor of harm in hospitalized children. We previously conducted a clinical trial that suggested that enoxaparin, a blood thinner, may prevent blood clots from a catheter in older children but not in infants. The CRETE Studies will investigate this newly identified difference in the efficacy of enoxaparin against blood clots between older children and infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this work is to unlock the investigation of enzyme catalytic mechanism at this finest level of structural and chemical detail. The enzyme systems targeted include pyridoxal-5’-phosphate (the bioactive form of vitamin-B6)-dependent enzymes, which have been implicated in health conditions and as targets for treating diseases such as Tay-Sachs, metachromatic leukodystrophy, Parkinson’s, and tuberculosis, and the β-Lactamases, which mediate antibiotic resistance to β-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin derivatives, cephalosporins, and monobactams. Understanding the catalytic mechanism of these enzymes at the atomic/molecular level will provide the necessary chemical details for developing them as important targets and may contribute to improved rational drug design of novel antibiotic, antidiabetic, antimalarial, and other drugs.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will develop and test LIVEBORN, an innovative mobile health application to reduce newborn mortality by improving bag mask ventilation in low-resource settings. LIVEBORN will collect real-time data on resuscitation events and provide automated feedback both during and after a resuscitation. This research seeks to shift the paradigm for improving bag mask ventilation from simulation-based training to complementary, guided bedside practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Veterans are a high risk AUD population and incur persistently limited access to efficacious family AUD treatments. This study will address longstanding gaps in the literature by examining the efficacy of Brief Family Involved Treatment (B-FIT), delivered via telehealth (i.e., videoconferencing), to maximize AUD treatment outcomes among Veterans in VA Substance Treatment and Recovery (STAR). This study will address an urgent public health priority, significantly advance the science in this area, and improve treatment access to reduce the prevalent, deleterious, and costly effects of AUD among Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The health effects associated with low-dose arsenic are controversial, and our knowledge of the molecular mechanisms underlying different individuals’ susceptibility to low-dose arsenic is limited. The proposed study will bring mechanistic insights to arsenic, aquaporin 3–induced DNA damage and mutations, highlighting the importance of studying the mechanisms underlying individual susceptibility to low-dose arsenic. This project will also identify potential early genomic biomarkers to predict long-term arsenic toxicology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nucleotides, like pyrimidines and purines, do not only provide cells with nucleic acids for growth, but also function as signaling molecules that control tissue inflammation. Although the immunosuppressive role of certain nucleotides is well appreciated in cancer and autoimmune diseases, their relevance in other inflammatory pathologies, like pneumonia, remains unclear. In this project, we will establish that host nucleotide metabolism is critical to prevent from infection caused by pathogens that exploit lung inflammation to persist, like the feared ESKAPE opportunists Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application proposes adding the Universities of North Carolina (UNC) and Arizona (UA) as a highly resourced KPMP Recruitment Site, enriched with rural, Black, Hispanic and Indigenous populations, and a particular interest in health equity and environmental health research. We will obtain kidney tissue obtained purely on a research basis, blood, DNA and urine from participants with acute and chronic kidney diseases to perform basic science studies to identify novel markers of different types of disease and the risk for progression, as well as potential targets for therapeutics. An area of focus will also be understanding how neighborhood and environmental risk factors interact with biology to determine the course and outcomes of these kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Ants exhibit highly evolved eusocial behaviors including stark division of labor among female castes, where the queen carries out all reproduction and worker castes forage for food and defend the colony. Interestingly, and of great relevance to aging research, the sterile workers are short-lived, while the reproductive queens are long-lived, with lifespans differing three to ten-fold between queen and worker. We propose to utilize ants to investigate the epigenetic and physiological basis of the dramatic lifespan differences between reproductive and worker castes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The high concentrations of nitrite in oral cavity as well as the nitric oxide released by inflamed periodontal tissues pose serious threat to survival of a periodontopathogen Porphyromonas gingivalis; therefore adaptation mechanisms to nitrosative stress are necessary for successful establishment and survival of the organism. So far our understanding of the adaptive and regulatory mechanisms governing this adaptation in P. gingivalis is rudimentary and the molecular, genetic, proteomic, structural and cellular approaches that I propose are expected to illuminate the mechanisms of Porphyromonas gingivalis adaptation to nitrosative stresses. This work is guided by the conviction that a cellular and molecular understanding of adaptation of P. gingivalis to nitrosative stress will give way to novel translational approaches for both treating and preventing adult periodontal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Most cells in the human body, including neurons, have an antenna-like projection called the primary cilium. When this tiny organelle does not function properly, this causes abnormal development and human disease, commonly called `'ciliopathies''. The proposed research program aims to understand how cells form their cilia and fine-tune their roles, as well as how specialized neuronal cells use their cilia to control brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Membrane curvature sensing is a crucial initiation step for many cellular processes, such as membrane trafficking. Defects in membrane traffic underlie diverse diseases such neurological disorders and cancer, thus making the proposed research relevant to public health. Research on basic biophysical mechanisms involved in membrane traffic is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will reduce burdens of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: INTERNATIONAL AGENCY FOR RES ON CANCER
PHR: Narrative The Programme of IARC Monographs on the Identification of Carcinogenic Hazards to Humans identifies the preventable causes of cancer by convening expert working groups to conduct authoritative, internationally respected evaluations of suspected carcinogens, encompassing chemicals, physical and biological agents, complex mixtures, environmental and occupational exposures, and other exposures of everyday life. The resulting IARC Monographs are made freely available online to the public, and results are also disseminated through the scientific literature and other media. The IARC Monographs provide governments and health agencies worldwide with timely, trustworthy, authoritative scientific information to support actions to prevent cancer through control of exposure to known, probable, and possible human carcinogens.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in FOXP3 cause loss of functional regulatory T (Treg) cells and the severe early onset autoimmune disease, immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked syndrome (IPEX). IPEX presents exclusively in males, has limited and suboptimal treatment options, and without treatment, is rapidly fatal. We will perform a phase 1 clinical trial to test safety and feasibility of an innovative gene therapy, CD4LVFOXP3, aimed specifically at providing functional autologous Treg-like cells as a treatment for patients with IPEX; at the same time, this trial will provide information on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of CD4LVFOXP3, instrumental for further clinical trials in IPEX and other rare or more common autoimmune diseases.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Phase 1 Study of Autologous CD4LVFOXP3 in Participants with IPEX Syndrome [revised IND and clinical protocol to be submitted to FDA by 10/11/2021]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed NARCH XII program at the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium (ANTHC) is designed to further ANTHC’s work to reduce health disparities in the Alaska Native population and to improve the capacity of ANTHC and our partners to conduct tribally-driven health research. The center includes an Administrative Core, a capacity building project and a research project, all designed in partnership with communities and tribal organizations to address needs identified in the Alaska Native population. In the long-term, the program is expected to have a lasting impact and improve ANTHC’s ability to fulfill its vision that “Alaska Native people are the healthiest people in the world.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The heterogeneity of major depression presents a problem for effective treatment. We propose to use a combination of lab- and smartphone-based data collection to describe the quantitative relationship between brain network connectivity, computational models of behavioral and affective dynamics, and depressive symptoms over multiple months. We will use theory- and data-driven approaches to elucidate the neurocomputational mechanisms underlying heterogeneity in the symptoms of major depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program aims to develop novel modeling methods, tools, and guidelines to incorporate racialized lived experiences into mathematical models of infectious disease transmission by explicitly modeling structural drivers of racial disparities in infectious disease exposure, susceptibility and severity, and consequences. This work will help inform the development and testing of structural interventions and decision tools to reduce racial disparities in infectious disease outcomes in the United States. This research will lay the groundwork to inform ongoing control of existing and emerging infectious disease pathogens and prevent the unequal health- and cost-related burdens on communities of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The precise integration of stress signals during the establishment of cellular quiescence is crucial to prevent cell proliferation disorders, such as fibrosis and cancer. However, it is unclear how stress responses are integrated during quiescence, in part, because of a lack of methods for simultaneously quantifying multiple stress pathways in single cells. To solve this problem, the proposed work will combine machine learning approaches with six color fluorescent microscopy to reveal the mechanisms by which stress responses coordinate quiescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Developing a mobile application that combines functional near-infrared-spectroscopy (fNIRS) and  electroencephalography (EEG) on one platform that could be used in less expensive and restrictive testing  environments to determine functional brain alterations in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is  very innovative. Furthermore, utilizing mobile application and developing cutting-edge machine learning  methods, will allow to determine novel functional brain markers that distinguish older adults with MCI from  healthy controls, which in turn can have major impact on knowledge and diagnostic procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney diseases affect 37 million Americans, their causes remain incompletely understood and treatments are limited. The Kidney Precision Medicine Project (KPMP) aims to identify new treatments for common causes of kidney disease by ethically collecting kidney biopsies and clinical information to create a kidney atlas with roadmaps describing cell function in health and disease. The Cleveland Chronic Kidney Disease Recruiting Site has been in the KPMP since its inception and will continue to recruit and follow people with chronic kidney disease from hypertension and or diabetes to create a cohort that represents disproportionately affected communities.

PHR: UCSF NORC Overview: Narrative The UCSF-Nutrition and Obesity Research Center (UCSF-NORC) is a highly integrated community of researchers spanning the spectrum from basic research through clinical implementation of new treatments. To achieve this, the NORC supplies, coordinates and oversees facilities and programs that bring these researchers together. Since its implementation four years ago, the NORC has increased the cohesiveness, and enhanced the visibility of nutrition, obesity and metabolism research at UCSF, thereby enabling the development of outstanding, cutting-edge and highly multi-disciplinary studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Prenatal exposure to perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) is ubiquitous in the United States and may increase the risk of adolescent obesity, elevated blood pressure, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance. Identifying biological markers of these effects is critical to ongoing regulation of PFAS and may reduce the impact of PFAS-related toxicities. This project will use sophisticated analytical chemistry and biostatistical methods to understand the links between prenatal exposure to PFAS mixtures, metabolomic biomarkers, and adolescent cardiometabolic disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The co-occurrence of prenatal alcohol exposure and reduced placental blood flow during pregnancy is a relatively common, yet largely unrecognized problem which can diminish a child’s ability to focus and learn later in life. This research project will employ a novel preclinical model combining moderate prenatal alcohol exposure and acutely decreased placental blood flow to investigate the adverse consequences of these combined prenatal insults on frontal cortical brain structure and functions associated with cognition in juvenile offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Worldwide women have a 2-fold greater risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease. The mission of the Perimenopause in Brain Aging and Alzheimer’s Disease Program Project is to discover why women are at greater risk for Alzheimer’s and based on that knowledge, create therapeutic strategies to prevent or delay development of Alzheimer’s disease. Further, our strategy provides a platform for a precision medicine approach to treating Alzheimer’s in both women and men.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project narrative: Castleman disease (CD) describes a group of rare hematologic disorders with limited treatment options due to poor understanding of its natural history and disease mechanisms. A team of physicians, researchers, and patients established ACCELERATE, an international, prospective longitudinal natural history study, in 2016 through a 5-year collaborative partnership that has now ended. We are proposing to leverage the data collected to date, build upon infrastructure from this multi-stakeholder collaboration, and continue enrollment and data collection to identify clinically-meaningful patient subtypes, clinical outcome measures, and novel treatment approaches.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: ACCELERATE: An Efficient and Innovative Natural History Study Addressing Unmet Needs in Castleman Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our purpose is to develop a clinical, inexpensive, safe (no ionizing radiation), high resolution, quantitatively accurate breast cancer scanner to address the issue of early identification of breast cancer patients to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. We propose to unite two advanced ultrasound technologies: 1) quantitative transmission ultrasound tomography (QTUS) and 2) Quantitative ultrasound (QUSB) backscatter analysis, the first of which is FDA cleared, into a single device to detect and monitor cancer and its treatment as effectively as MRI and CT without the concomitant danger from radiation or contrast agents. This technology is inexpensive and accurate and addresses the personalized medicine initiative, because it gives quantitative tissue information at the sub-mm level and early feedback on neo-adjuvant cancer therapy for the individual patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Deaf and hard-of-hearing (deaf) biomedical research scientists are severely underrepresented among the nation’s biomedical science researchers. The Rochester Bridges to the Doctorate for Deaf and Hard-of- Hearing Students program includes deaf master’s degree seeking students in research-intensive training and professional skill development to prepare these trainees --- who are part of a cultural and linguistic minority group --- for biomedical doctoral programs in preparation to enter biomedical science research careers. This unique partnership between the National Technical Institute for the Deaf at Rochester Institute of Technology and University of Rochester increases representation of deaf biomedical researchers and diversifies the biomedical science research community.
PROJECT_TERMS: bridge to the doctorate;deaf;hard of hearing;Students
PROJECT_TITLE: Rochester Bridges to the Doctorate for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing (D/HH) Students (RB2D).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Roles of ribonucleic acids for diverse functions in cellular processes continue to be discovered, calling for sophisticated approaches to investigate these central molecules in living cells. Splicing describes the process of diversifying gene expression, and a diverse group of RNAs is involved in this complex process that requires precise regulation in space and time. This proposal aims to expand the toolbox to interrogate ribonucleic acids live in mammalian cells using fluorescence microscopy and use them as the foundation for new insights in splicing function and regulation in health and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a major cause of acute and chronic liver failure and is now the most common reason for liver transplantation in the U.S. Historically, transplant centers have required at least 6 months of alcohol abstinence before considering patients with ALD for liver transplant; however early liver transplant for patients with severe ALD with less than 6 months of alcohol abstinence can save lives. This multi- center study will examine the patient selection process for early liver transplantation, identify strategies most helpful to prevent return to alcohol use and to optimize long-term health after transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex hormones are powerful regulators of gene expression, cell differentiation, and disease. We have discovered a critical role for T cell intrinsic androgen receptor activity in limiting the effectiveness of immunotherapy in prostate cancer. The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanism(s) by which androgen receptor signaling in CD8 T cells orchestrates T cell dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overactive bladder is a common, debilitating, chronic condition that affects over 33 million Americans. The impact on quality of life is significant, and access to management is often limited in vulnerable and underserved populations. Through a mixed-methods approach, the proposed research will provide a low-cost, scalable strategy to improve access and adherence to therapies, thereby improving OAB outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Melanomas are pigmented skin cancers that can be difficult to distinguish from benign moles, even for trained primary physicians and dermatologists, and can be deadly if overlooked. Based upon the genes and regulatory molecules that distinguish moles from melanomas, the proposed project explores new methods for detecting and preventing the transformation of moles into melanomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve alcohol use disorder treatment, particularly through precision medicine approaches, it is imperative that alcohol use disorder etiologic mechanisms are identified and assessed in a way that is reliable and valid across diverse groups of individuals. The proposed study will use a multimethod approach to develop and validate a computerized adaptive test of alcohol use disorder etiologic mechanisms. Ultimately, the goal of this work is to establish an efficient and comprehensive assessment of mechanisms that can be used in service of determining the optimal treatment, whether behavioral, pharmacological, or both, for a given person with alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Families of children with limited English proficiency (LEP) have been systematically excluded from autism spectrum disorder (ASD) research; yet they likely experience additional impediments to care compared to other minoritized families. The current application proposes the largest ever, diverse, multi-lingual national survey (n=2730) of children with ASD. The survey will validate ASD mechanistic and service use measures in 5 languages, and survey data will be used to understand language disparities in ASD service use. Qualitative and consensus methods will contextualize and give policy relevance to survey findings. Study results will inform current and future disparities reduction efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative  Frontonasal dysplasia (FND), also known as median cleft face syndrome, is a large class of craniofacial birth defects that profoundly impact the form and function of the face, nose, and mouth. FND patients require multiple corrective surgeries and often suffer life-long impairment. Using novel mouse models and innovative research approaches, this project will uncover the underlying developmental and molecular mechanisms and lead to significant improvement in molecular diagnosis, genetic counseling, and treatment of patients with FND and related craniofacial disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney Injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) impose a significant health burden worldwide, yet there is limited understanding of the injury pathways leading to these disorders. This has hampered the development of targeted therapies. The Mount Sinai Kidney Precision Medicine Project proposal seeks to recruit a diverse cohort of 40 patients with CKD and 20 patients with AKI each year over a 5-year period into a longitudinal biorepository and database of clinical and phenotypic data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because improved post-acute care for adults with serious mental illness has the potential to reduce rehospitalizations and wasted healthcare resources due to poor treatment engagement. Moreover, the proposed Hybrid Type 1 design aligns with NIMH’s Strategic Plan, Goal 4, as we will test the effectiveness of an innovative intervention while collecting data to support implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Saltational bursts of genomic instability represent a significant source of mutagenesis. Despite their implications for genome evolution and disease progression, the properties of these episodes, and the cellular mechanisms that contribute to their occurrence are not well understood. Our research will define critical qualities of these mutagenic events and provide a foundation for future avenues of investigation regarding how these mutagenic events contribute to the evolution of eukaryotic genomes and disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The oncoprotein transcription factor MYC is overexpressed in the majority of cancers and contributes to an estimated 100,000 deaths in the USA each year. This proposal outlines a strategy to define how MYC works with its co-factor WDR5 to drive gene expression changes that establish and maintain the malignant state. Completion of this work will expose unappreciated aspects of the molecular processes that drive cancer and how these can be therapeutically blocked in tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This program examines how stress changes the function of CREB and kappa-opioid receptor (KOR) systems in brain motivation circuits, and how these changes affect behavior. This line of work has provided a foundation for clinical trials of KOR antagonists to treat depression, an innovative approach which thus far shows great promise. Major goals include exploring whether alterations in CREB and KOR signaling are involved in the long- lasting pro-depressive effects that are caused by immune system activation during early brain development, a form of stress occurring widely during the COVID-19 pandemic, while examining factors that control stress susceptibility and resilience in animal models that are chosen because they use measurements and endpoints that are the same as used in humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Children born very premature (less than 32 weeks gestational age) have higher risks and vulnerabilities for developing behavioral problems. These behavior problems can occur as early as age 2 years and if untreated cause long term problems for the child and family. This study will test digital delivery of parent training plus coaching calls for parents of young children that were born very premature. Leveraging technology to deliver parent training and providing parents with brief, supportive coaching calls represent sustainable and feasible methods to deliver empirically supported parent training to improve social, emotional, and behavioral outcomes in these young children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood Hepatitis B (HBV) infection remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa, and this is driven in part by vertical transmission during childbirth. Few studies have characterized the immunogenicity and potential impacts of adding a birth dose of HBV vaccine to the current 3-dose vaccination schedule in sub-Saharan African settings. This proposal uses epidemiological and mathematical modeling approaches to determine the impact of an HBV birth dose vaccine in order to inform policy in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this project is to test a virtual reality experience designed to reduce relapse and drinking, increase future orientation, decrease impulsive choice, and ultimately elevate the quality of life for persons recovering from alcohol use disorder. Through increasing future orientation with a potent personalized experience, the intervention targets increased brain activation related to beneficial decision-making and positive future outcomes. The results of this study will provide vital information on the effectiveness and brain mechanisms of this recovery support intervention intended to facilitate recovery outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal heart rhythms are a major cause of death and strokes in the US. Our research focuses on how the heart acquires its normal heart rhythm during development, so we can apply this knowledge to better understand why abnormal heart rhythms form in the adult heart. Using this approach, we have identified a key protein ERBB4 that is essential to maintain normal heart rhythm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Innate lymphoid cells are relatively poorly understood immune cell populations that play important roles in host defense, inflammation, allergic responses, tissue remodeling and metabolic homeostasis. Our research goals are to understand the fundamental biology of innate lymphoid cells, including their immunological and nonimmunological functions, molecular mechanisms of their regulation and migration, and their interactions with both pathogenic and commensal bacteria. Knowledge gained from these studies is expected to lead to the significant development of new therapeutic strategies for infectious, allergic and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Approximately 26% of Americans have obesity and prediabetes. These conditions greatly increase the risk for the development of type 2 diabetes. Innovative lifestyle strategies to treat obesity and prediabetes are critically needed. If the aims of this application are achieved, this study will be the first to show that time restricted feeding can be implemented as an alternative to traditional dieting (i.e. daily calorie restriction) for long-term weight management. This study will also show that time restricted feeding can be used as an effective non- pharmacological therapy to improve insulin sensitivity and decrease metabolic risk in this population group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Turning on the right gene at the right time is essential for development and requires the dynamic recruitment of dozens of regulatory factors to specific genomic loci; defects in this process cause human disease. Emerging evidence supports a role for weak multivalent interactions in organizing regulatory factors into multi-component clusters that assemble and disassemble dynamically, yet these types of interactions have been difficult to study as they are only stabilized under specific conditions which enable cluster formation. Investigation into the mechanisms and functions of these weak multivalent interactions in the context of cluster formation will provide novel insights into a fundamental biological process with implications for developmental processes and aberrant gene activation in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Fluid intake is a cornerstone of prevention for patients with kidney stones yet few patients adhere to fluid intake guidelines. Patient adherence can be supported by technology that monitors drinking behavior and delivers just-in-time reminders when patients have not had a drink recently. This project evaluates the efficacy of a sipIT, a digital tool involving a smartphone, smartwatch, and connected water bottle, for increasing fluid intake in patients with urolithiasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Acquired hearing loss is prevalent throughout the world and accounts for, not only a significant cost to the lives of those living with it, but it also accounts for a significant monetary cost to individuals and societies. Hearing deficits can result from the loss of cochlear hair cells, which do not naturally regenerate in humans and other mammals leading to permanent impairment. Therefore, strategies to reprogram neighboring cells into hair cells will provide therapeutic targets for hearing restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Tuberculosis (TB) is a global health crisis that has frustrated efforts to treat and contain, and, unlike other bacterial infections that can be treated with a week-long course of a single antibiotic, TB therapy requires several drugs in combination for at least 6 months and often even this regimen does not work. In this project we will: (1) develop a better detection method for active TB in patient sputum samples through collaboration with a group in South Africa that works with TB-infected and HIV/TB-coinfected patients; (2) develop a better method for quickly and cost-effectively screening potential new TB drugs; and (3) conduct fundamental studies to determine how the outer layer of the pathogen that causes TB allows infection to happen. Our new method for clinical TB diagnosis should make it easier to determine whether TB drugs are working in patients; additionally, if they are not working well, new insight gleaned from this work may help us to better understand why.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding the age-associated changes which occur in both the epithelial and stromal cells during ovarian cancer initiation is critical to enable the development of early detection or prevention strategies in ovarian cancer. Our data suggest age-related changes occur in the stromal cells even before cancer starts and these stromal changes may promote the formation of cancer initiating cells (CIC) and invasive ovarian cancer. The goal of this proposal is to define the impact of age on interactions between stromal cells and cancer initiating cells (CIC) that drive ovarian cancer formation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Mitochondria and endoplasmic/sarcoplasmic reticula are “organelles” (structures) in cells that regulate cell metabolism and cell death. We have devised molecules that regulate proteins called mitofusins to alter the physical and functional relationships among these organelles and, thereby, influence cell death and metabolism. We propose in this project to (a) delineate mechanisms by which mitofusin modulators impact heart muscle cell metabolism and cell death and (b) test whether mitofusin modulators provide new therapeutic strategies for myocardial infarction (“heart attack”) and heart failure, the two most common and lethal heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial vaginosis (BV), an alteration in the vaginal microbiome, nearly doubles the risk of preterm birth (PTB), delivery prior to 37 weeks, and affects one third of women of reproductive age. In the US, women with HIV experience a two-fold increased risk of PTB compared to women without HIV and have been excluded from studies investigating the association between vaginal dysbiosis and preterm birth, contributing to ongoing disparities in this population. The proposed research will explore the role of vaginal dysbiosis in PTB among women with HIV with the vision that vaginal dysbiosis will be associated with a pro-inflammatory milieu, with altered cytokine and short chain fatty acid profiles, thus increasing the risk for PTB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States is currently experiencing a decline in life expectancy due to an increase in mortality from poisoning, suicide, motor vehicle-related injuries, chronic liver diseases and cirrhosis, pneumonia and diabetes mellitus– for all of which alcohol use is a causal risk factor. The proposed project will investigate the role of alcohol use in these developments, with a focus on socioeconomic status and race/ethnicity as modifying factors on the link between alcohol use and mortality. Through simulation of the effects of different alcohol control interventions, the proposed project will provide tangible approaches to reverse the current decrease in life expectancy in the United States, while focussing on preventing further increases in health inequalities.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project narrative Disease modifying treatments for multiple sclerosis (MS) have many known serious risks, and healthcare expenditures related to MS DMTs account for 40% of the $85 billion total annual cost of MS care in the United States. While there is biological evidence and clinical data supporting the discontinuation of DMT for certain patients, there are no biological markers or clinical support tools to aide with the complex decision to stop MS DMTs. We propose the development, validation, and implementation of a point of care decision support tool utilizing machine learning to address this significant unmet need in the field of MS care.

PROJECT_TITLE: A Decision Support Tool for the Discontinuation of Disease Modifying Therapies in Multiple Sclerosis

This work will determine how brain systems can be targeted to improve decision-making by increasing the ability to plan and decreasing impulsive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) afflicts 5.8 million in the USA, but there remains no disease-modifying therapy. Critical for symptom progression is the loss of synapses in the brain. We seek to define the molecular basis of this synapse loss, focusing on the role of metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5) activation. In AD mice rescued from synapse loss by a mGluR5 targeting compound, we will profile the expression of genes in hundreds of thousands of brain cells to understand the complex interactions underlying this improvement. Changes in the shape of mGluR5 protein caused by AD will be studied by cryo electron microscopy to define the initiating molecular steps in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early liver transplantation (eLT), defined as LT evaluation with <6 months of alcohol abstinence, is associated with acceptable outcomes for patients with severe alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) in retrospective studies. However, prospective, multi-center data including biopsychosocial factors on eLT for all patients with ALD in racially, culturally, and socioeconomically diverse populations are lacking. The INTEGRATE collaborative is a highly diverse investigative team that seeks to: 1) define factors influencing referral and waitlisting for eLT in ALD (selection); 2) identify which biopsychosocial factors are causally related and predictive of outcomes most important to stakeholders (outcomes); and 3) determine how integrated care among the healthcare team influences stakeholder-relevant outcomes in eLT for ALD (management).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Today, for lack of appropriate technology there is scant information on how genetically defined neuron-types coordinate their collective dynamics across multiple brain areas. To break this barrier, we created the ‘Octopus’, a robotic imaging system comprising 4 or more mechanically articulated arms, each a two- photon microscope, for simultaneous imaging of neural activity in multiple deep or superficial brain areas of individual rodent or primate subjects. In this project, we will enhance and prepare the Octopus for widespread dissemination by: (1) upgrading the optics, so that each arm incorporates optogenetics and can perform dual-color two-photon imaging at video frame-rates across an 800-µm-wide field-of-view; (2) refining the mechanical design of the articulated arm to simplify its initial assembly for new users and improve its versatility; (3) working with 7 beta-tester labs to iteratively improve the performance and usability of the Octopus and to validate its capabilities as a groundbreaking new tool for imaging multi-area neural dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood cancers account for approximately 10% of all malignancies and allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT) is a major curative therapy, but is limited by transplant related complications, predominantly graft-versus- host disease (GVHD) that is often fatal. The proposal will study and define rapidly testable therapeutic approaches to prevent GVHD based on preventing the initiation of disease (i.e. alloantigen presentation) rather than broad suppression of T cells in the late effector phase of disease, as is current practice. In this manner we will define new strategies to prevent the side effects of transplantation, whilst permitting the development of robust immunity to pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Martell project narrative (2-3 sentences) Technologies that enable the identification of which proteins reside in specific locations inside cells are critical for elucidating biological processes and disease states, including neurodegeneration, pathogenic infection, and cancer. One promising strategy to achieve this goal is proximity labeling (PL), but in order to enhance the sensitivity and specificity of proximal protein detection, improved PL catalysts are needed. We propose that hybrid biological-abiotic PL catalysts developed in our laboratory will enhance both sensitivity and specificity in spatially- resolved proteomic mapping, and we are employing these catalysts in neurons to benchmark their performance against existing methods and establish their broad utility as research tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative: . Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most prevalent and impactful diseases in the United States and throughout the developed world; currently there are limited therapeutic options available to treat AD. This project seeks to benefit public health by determining the mechanism by which the metabolite β-hydroxybutyrate modifies the pathogenesis of AD. The proposed work is expected to result in new information that can inform the development of new therapeutic strategies or treatments for AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to discover how biophysical adaptation mechanisms that permit the retina to adapt its computational function contribute to neural encoding.
