IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Rise to the Challenge Bridge to Health and Bioinformatics Program will prepare El Paso Community College students to transfer to the University of Texas at El Paso with the skills to successfully graduate with a Baccalaureate degree in biomedical sciences. The program will prepare them to conduct research and with the skills to enter the Bioinformatics and Health Informatics workforce. Given the location on the US-Mexico Border region and the large percentage of Hispanic students enrolled at both institutions, the program will generate a cadre of diverse biomedical professionals with a vested interest, and the skills to contribute to the improvement of the quality of life on the border and the health of the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increased rates of obesity and diabetes parallels the increased pesticide usage in the United States, especially the use of glyphosate, to date, no study has comprehensively examined the impact of glyphosate exposure on the development of obesity and diabetes. The current work will determine if glyphosate impairs metabolic homeostasis, and if this is due to changes in the gut microbiota. These studies will help understand the impact of environmental exposures on host metabolism and could lead to more targeted therapeutic approaches to treat metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Dissecting the mechanisms of Quaking-regulated RNA processing Project Narrative: Gene expression controls nearly every biological process and is essential for life. The Quaking family of RNA binding proteins regulate diverse forms of RNA processing during development and their dysregulation can cause disease. This proposal will use the QKI5 isoform as a model RBP to dissect the fundamental regulatory mechanisms it uses to regulate RNA splicing, localization, and stability/decay to better understand how it influences global gene expression.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s public health mission because it investigates how genetic factors and psychosocial stressors (i.e., spousal psychiatric disorders) come together to influence alcohol use disorder onset, remission, and relapse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building on our pilot work, this randomized clinical trial (RCT) will test the efficacy of a novel, remotely delivered mindfulness-based group intervention for tics (MBIT) for reducing tic severity and improving common comorbid mental health conditions and quality of life. It will also examine the mechanism by which MBIT reduces tic severity and explore its long-term therapeutic benefit. As ~60% of adults with Tourette Syndrome and persistent tic disorders (collectively TS) do not respond to first-line treatments, MBIT may serve as the first new evidence-based non-pharmacological treatment for TS in over 10 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 1p/19q codeletion is a molecular hallmark of oligodendrogliomas. This proposal will capitalize on metabolic vulnerabilities induced by the 1p/19q codeletion for oligodendroglioma therapy and for non-invasive metabolic imaging of response to therapy. By pioneering the development of a genomically guided precision therapy and companion imaging biomarkers of treatment response, our studies have the potential to significantly improve outcomes and quality of life for oligodendroglioma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is a neurological condition with an increasing burden in many low- and middle income countries (LMICs). The chronicity of the disease, seizure complications, poorly controlled seizures, stigma, coexisting chronic diseases and social isolation negatively impact health related quality of life. This project will build upon promising pilot work and capacity building conducted in Uganda to further test a self-management program that has the potential to reduce epilepsy burden in Uganda and other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Coronary artery calcium (CAC) testing provides a direct measure of an individual’s atherosclerotic burden that is robustly associated with cardiovascular disease risk and is recommended by national and international guidelines for the allocation of primary prevention medications. Currently, there is a lack of data on sex and race/ethnicity-specific CAC percentiles across the lifespan that is representative of the whole US population and there is no centralized website/resource to guide clinical interpretation of CAC scores. We will combine 10 datasets to create a harmonized CAC Synthetic Cohort Lifetime Pooling Project (CACSC-LPP) enabling calculation of sex and race/ethnicity CAC percentiles across the lifespan that will be translated into a website/app to serve as the definitive resource for interpretation of CAC scores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Epinephrine is the primary medication used when treating patients suffering from a cardiac arrest despite developing evidence that epinephrine may make neurologic outcomes worse. The objective of this study is to test a new endovascular therapy that can improve perfusion to the heart and brain in patients who have suffered a cardiac arrest. The results from this study will provide a greater understanding of the effects of epinephrine on the brain in cardiac arrest as well as provide the data required to determine if clinical trials of this endovascular therapy are warranted in cardiac arrest victims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biologic drugs have transformed the treatments of a variety of diseases, including diabetes, cancer, and heart disease, but they require injection into the body since these molecules are too large to easily diffuse through the tissue walls. Even though local administration of drugs is becoming increasingly necessary to provide therapeutic efficacy, no research or tools exist on understanding the flow of fluid into tissue. In this proposal, we will develop a computational model capable of predicting macromolecule drug distributions in tissue following an injection and a clinically translatable injection system that optimizes and standardizes injections into heart and tumor tissue.
